PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Philippines
PETITION.PARA: Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick) agreed to:
That petitions lodged with the Clerk may be presented this day.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Human Rights in the Philippines
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the following human rights violations are occurring in the Philippines:
1. The disappearance or extra-legal execution of a number of real or perceived opponents of the government.
2. Systematic torture of political prisoners.
3. The detention of political prisoners without fair trial.
4. The death penalty.
5. Arrests of people for the non-violent exercise of their human rights.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1. appeal to the President of the Philippines for the immediate release of prisoners of conscience.
2. appeal to the Minister of Justice of the Philippines, Mr Ricardo Puno, for fair and early trials for all political prisoners.
3. appeal to Pres. Marcos for the abolition of the death penalty and torture for all prisoners.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax Avoidance and Evasion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the continuing high level of tax avoidance and evasion is cause for grave concern for honest Australian taxpayers, and demands stringent and immediate action by the Commonwealth, noting in particular:
1. The latest estimate by the Australian Taxpayers' Association is that $7,000m a year is being lost in taxation revenue;
2. This figure can only continue to rise because of the timid approach by the Government in closing off tax loopholes; and
3. No effective inroads can be made until a comprehensive policy is adopted of levying tax from the date on which a scheme of tax avoidance is first used.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P.:

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M.P., a Commonwealth Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.9.82 the amount of principal had only been reduced by $395.06 since the 1.10.81 leaving a balance of $14,609.94.

(2) Your petitioners therefore request that the Government immediately make available similar generous terms to the many thousands of Home Buyers in Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to abnormally high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

(a) notes the refusal by the Government, communicated in the Acting Prime Minister's letter of 15 December, to comply with the Senate's direction to produce, subject to independent editing, certain papers relating to the Government's administation of tax evasion and avoidance laws;

(b) notes that this refusal is not based on any claim of Execution privilege, which claim would clearly under established law and practice be a matter for the Senate itself to determine, but upon a new and unprecedented claim-possibly capable of judicial determination-that the Senate has no constitutional power to require the production of documents relating to the exercise by the Executive of its law enforcement functions;

(c) is of the opinion that there is no foundation whatever in constitutional law or convention for any such claim, and that-subject only to reasonable claims of Executive privilege-both Houses of Parliament are fully entitled to scrutinise and demand accountability for all aspects of Executive behaviour;

(d) is further of the opinion that this latest obstructive stance by the Government, when seen in the light of the persistent obstruction and evasion which has occurred since the Senate first insisted on the production of the documents in question on 23 September, is now ample demonstration of the fact that the Government has something to hide which the documents in question would clearly reveal, namely that the Fraser Government was culpably negligent in failing to proceed effectively against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour and related tax avoidance and evasion schemes from 1976 on; and
(e) accordingly, censures the Fraser Government:
(i) for its unjustified failure to comply with the Senate resolution of 25 November; and

(ii) for its culpable neglect and mismanagement in failing to proceed effectively and expeditiously against tax evaders and avoiders at a cost of hundreds and possibly thousands of millions of dollars to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the proposed amendment to Standing Order 407A, relating to time limits on speeches, which is currently operating as a sessional order until 31 December 1982, be extended to apply until the last day of sitting in 1983.

DEBATE.TITLE: PLUMBERS, DRAINERS AND GASFITTERS BOARD ORDINANCE 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I give notice that it is my intention, at the giving of notices of motion on the next day of sitting, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Austin Lewis for the next day of sitting, to disallow the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board Ordinance 1982. I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned about notification of rights of appeal to persons affected by a decision to cancel or suspend a licence, and sought an assurance from the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) that a notification of such rights would routinely be made in all cases. The Committee understands that the assurance sought is in the post, and I give the notice of withdrawal solely on that basis. In accordance with the Committee's new practice, I seek leave to incorporate a detailed statement on the matter in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

When giving notice, on 17 November 1982, for the disallowance of the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board Ordinance, Senator Austin Lewis advised the Senate that the Committee was concerned with sub-section 33 (2) of the Ordinance, which provides that the validity of a decision of the Board to cancel or suspend a certificate is not 'to be affected by a failure to include in a statement under sub-section (1) a notification of appeal rights in accordance with paragraph 1 ( b)'.

While the Committee appreciated that technical failures should not usually invalidate decisions, it was concerned that, given the serious consequences of suspension or cancellation of a licence, a routine form of notification of appeal rights should always be given when advice of suspension or cancellation was sent.

The Minister advised, on 29 November 1982, that as the provision was being inserted in other pieces of Commonwealth legislation, he had referred the Committee's queries to the Attorney-General for direct reply.

The Committee, while noting that the Attorney-General would ultimately give advice as to the general policy of the provision, sought an assurance from the Minister that notification of a right of appeal will routinely be made to all persons affected by the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board Ordinance. The Committee understands that the Minister has unreservedly given the assurance, but awaits formal advice to that effect. As delays in giving the notice of withdrawal could cause uncertainty to those affected by the Ordinance, the Committee decided to make its intention to withdraw the notice of disallowance clear, subject to receipt of the assurance sought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes with grave concern-

1. That the Budgets introduced this year by Mr Howard and Mr Tonkin, the recently defeated Premier of South Australia, were both designed as election budgets and close examination now reveals the documents in both instances to be nothing more than huge confidence tricks.

2. (a) That on assuming office in September 1979 the Liberal Government of South Australia inherited a solid State economy with a Budget surplus of $6,453, 000 plus all the State's assets being intact; and
(b) that on assuming office in November 1982 the Bannon Labor Government inherited a rundown State economy with a Budget deficit of between $37m and $62m .

3. That the 1982 South Australian Budget figures do not give a clear picture of the State's rundown economy in view of the fact that the Tonkin Liberal Government had disposed of many of the State's assets in the form of land, houses, machinery and equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, relates to the proclamation of section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981. Section 90 provides for the deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory by the repeal of the Trading Hours Ordinance 1962. Does the Minister recall stating on 10 June 1981 that proclamation of section 90 would be deferred until the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on the proposed deregulation had been tabled and an opportunity for debate had been provided? In view of the fact that debate on the Committee's report has not been concluded, will the Minister give an assurance that proclamation of section 90 will not proceed before that debate has been finalised?

—I recall the debate back in June 1981. I recall many debates in this place following that time, particularly in the last few months. As to the specific statement which Senator Colston seeks from the Minister for the Capital Territory, I will refer that matter to him and seek his comments.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns a major Korean group which is in Western Australia negotiating with the State Government and with private industries for the purpose of establishing a major power station, an aluminium smelter and other resource development projects. Will the Minister give me an assurance that, when the relevant Commonwealth departments assess these projects under the guidelines that are the responsibility of the Commonwealth, due recognition is given to the employment and economic value of these projects to Western Australia and Australia as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Any project of the kind outlined by Senator Thomas would be subject to the usual procedures of the Foreign Investment Review Board which take into account the beneficial effects of any investment or new project. I think recently the Treasurer tabled or made public the revised guidelines for the Foreign Investment Review Board. These guidelines would be applied to any proposed project from Korea or any other country. Under those conditions I think I can safely give the assurance that has been sought by Senator Thomas.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given the Government's intervention today in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission case, does this indicate that the Government believes in a centralised wage fixation system? Has the Government made any progress to establishing what its attitude will be to wage fixation following the 12-month wages freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What can be interpreted from today's action is that all persons attending the Premiers Conference agreed that there should be intervention in the wages system at State and Federal levels to bring about a wages freeze in the private sector. The Commonwealth is intervening today as the result of the unanimous agreement on that principle at the Premiers Conference. This is a unique situation in Australia's history in that all heads of government are in agreement that wages should be frozen, although there is some difference of opinion as to the length of time. It is not to be interpreted in any other way. The Government will be contemplating the future system of wage fixation in the months ahead. In due course the Government will indicate its policies in this matter. I repeat that today's action follows the unanimous expression of the Premiers Conference.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In the light of the Acting Prime Minister's statement yesterday that more consideration will be given to the Federal Government's announcement on its attitude to the building of the Franklin Dam, and after the firm statements by the World Heritage Commission on the obligations of Australia arising from the world heritage listing and the further request by the Commission Chairman, Professor Slatyer, yesterday for a rethinking of the program so that 'some other procedure might be devised for satisfying the electricity requirements of the Tasmanian people', I ask: Does the Minister expect that Ministers will make use of the Christmas recess to study closely the evidence and conclusions of the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which the Senate has not yet found time to debate adequately so that totally misleading statements by Premier Gray that the dam is essential to the Tasmanian economy and that the Commonwealth has not the power and obligation to intervene may be corrected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the latter part of the question first. The Commonwealth Government will give very close consideration to the report of the Senate Select Committee. I have read the report, which expressed a view. It is not to be considered that that, in itself, is compelling. In the Commonwealth Government's view it is the right of individual States to decide what industries shall be attracted, how they shall attract them, what is the predictability of industries for the future and the power or surplus power they should have. The Select Committee has made some predictions. Those predictions will be given consideration. But throughout Australia over the past 81 years it has been a very old-fashioned and a very good view that the determination of all of these matters regarding the growth of industry and projections in that regard should be a matter for the State governments. I have no doubt that the Commonwealth Government would want to respect that principle. Nevertheless, consideration will be given to the report.

ANSWER.PARA: I said yesterday, and I emphasise it, that the Commonwealth Government will be very interested to receive a written report and, no doubt, a verbal report from Professor Ralph Slatyer. It will study the report and its implications in detail . In the light of that report the Commonwealth Government will look towards what the Government considers are the actions it might take, in conjunction with the Tasmanian Government, to ensure that the wilderness is managed in a way which will protect its vital parts. It is too early at the moment to go further than that because we have not seen the details of the report. I stressed yesterday that whilst we have the advantage of reports in the Press-Senator Missen will appreciate this-one needs the fullest details in this matter. I give an assurance to the Senate that the Government will give the closest consideration to the matter and will be very conscious of its indications in the past, that it is concerned that this wilderness area should be listed, which has happened, and should be preserved, which is our intention in terms of management and co- operation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate, or any other Minister who claims to understand, what Mr Doug Anthony means by a statement reported in this morning's Canberra Times and almost all other newspapers in Australia. Mr Anthony said:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no condoning the building of the dam by the Commonwealth and I wouldn' t like that to be the impression.
The first objective was to have the area listed. We want the area to be protected and don't want to see any further development.
The article continues:

He conceded that despite last week's announcement that the Commonwealth would not intervene, another approach to the State Government had been 'hinted at and suggested'. But reaction by the Tasmanian Government to renewed negotiations ' has been fairly negative'.
Will the Leader of the Government please tell me what that means?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Chipp, I think most Australians understand very clearly what this means because it is an expression of what the Commonwealth Government has been saying. Mr Anthony is saying that the Tasmanian Government has the right to make that decision and that was a right which was recognised in the referendum, in the State elections and in the ballot box. That decision was made. It is not for the Commonwealth Government to intervene and tell State governments whether they should have the attraction of particular industries or the building of particular power stations. Over the years there have been numerous discussions between the Tasmanian Government and the Commonwealth Government on various ways of providing additional electric power to Tasmania. It should be understood that Tasmania has no natural supplies of gas. There have been very strenuous endeavours to find gas off the coast. Tasmania has very little and very poor coal. If it were to import coal, the cost of coal-fired power stations would be very considerably above that of hydro- electricity with the result that the one primary responsibility of the Gray Government, that is, to put itself in a competitive position to attract industry , would not be there. So what Mr Anthony said is that, in effect, these things have happened. They happened under the accepted view of the Australian people. The decisions were made properly in the ballot box. These decisions were properly State ones. Equally, from the moment the former State Labor Government under Mr Lowe indicated that it would build the power station-it agreed also with the world heritage listing-the Commonwealth had always approached the listing in the knowledge that a sovereign State government intended to build a power station--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I fully appreciate that your powers to administer Standing Orders in respect of Ministers at Question Time are severely limited. But surely there must be some limit to the irrelevancies that Ministers can carry on with. If you followed the rulings you have given to their logical conclusion, Mr President, I could ask Senator Sir John Carrick a question about resources and he could, within your ruling, be relevant and in order by replying with an answer on the habits of the Australian dingo. Sir, there must be a limit to relevancy. I asked a simple question about what Mr Anthony meant by his rather quaint statement. If it is clear to Senator Sir John Carrick, it is not clear to me. I apologise to him for having an intellectual capacity lower than his, but I do ask the question.
—I call the Leader of the Government.

—Senator Chipp asked a question in four parts. I am very specifically and very narrowly answering in each of those four parts what was meant by 'condoning'. I have said that quite specifically. This kind of interjection, of course, is well understood. We felt we did not have to make a decision on this issue because the decision was made at the ballot box. I am sorry if that is not relevant to the first part of the question. The second part of the question related to listing. I was in the process of answering specifically the question on listing. I said that the Lowe Labor Government had indicated that it intended to build a dam, that it had acquiesced with the Commonwealth in the listing and that it had always been known that there would be a listing with a dam in the process of being built; and this has happened. What Mr Anthony was saying was perfectly consistent. Equally, from 1975 onwards, this Government has been indicating that it saw it as a major challenge to have a management program in place for South West Tasmania and it was interested to co-operate in that regard. Specifically that is so. I do not know whether any further details are necessary. I repeat that it is quite specific in terms of what the Commonwealth Government has been saying and doing over the past seven years regarding this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Sir John Carrick to explain what is meant by this statement:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Anthony conceded that despite last week's announcement that the Commonwealth would not intervene, another approach to the State Government had been 'hinted at and suggested'.
I ask: Hinted at and suggested by whom to whom?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it another approach by the State Government or to the State Government?
—To?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot interpret what Mr Anthony said.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have had our laugh let me say that I believe that Senator Chipp is referring to a report of an interview on the steps of Parliament House. It probably means, as I said yesterday, that it is likely that in the weeks ahead discussions will take place between the Commonwealth Government and the Tasmanian State Government on the management and protection of the area.
—That is not what he said.

—I can understand the embarrassment of these people in this regard. The Australian Democrats are arguing that they are the champions against the dams and that they led the fight in the Flinders by-election. They are trying to prove the point of the Flinders by-election where, being the champions, they fell. I am sorry to say that I cannot interpret that. I have my difficulties--
—I did not ask you to do so. I just want you to interpret Anthony, not us.

—I understand that fully. I believe that what he means is that the Commonwealth Government intends to have discussions with the State Government on the management and protection of the area. I said yesterday that the first thing that would be necessary would be to get the Slatyer report. If it would be helpful I will refer that part of the question to Mr Anthony for interpretation, as indeed I refer the Democrats' statements on the Flinders by- election to them for interpretation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. While I recognise and welcome the return to the 20 per cent government preference in favour of Australian manufactured goods for government use, will the Government further consider the state of the local industry and the consequences for local employment before awarding contracts to overseas suppliers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator Watson's welcoming of the return to the 20 per cent preference. I must say that Senator Watson is very consistent in his advocacy on these matters. I would have expected him to welcome that advantage to Australian industry which has been restored by the Government as part of its response to the very difficult employment situation which we have. The honourable senator raised a very large matter, namely, that we should go beyond the 20 per cent preference which is given to Australian suppliers in letting contracts for the supply of goods and that we should look at the state of local industry and presumably make even greater concessions where employment considerations warrant it. I will ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce, whom I represent in this place, to consider the point which has been raised by the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose that in a sense the Government has responded in the way which is suggested by Senator Watson in his question when one looks at what has been done with respect to the Williamstown dockyard, where the Government has gone to considerable trouble to try to reach a situation where destroyers for the Australian Navy can be built in Australia. I should not make too much comment because I do not represent the Minister for Defence Support, the Honourable Ian Viner, who is responsible for that matter. However, there have been recent reports of the efforts of the Government to achieve management practices and labour practices at that dockyard which will make it possible for those ships to be made in Australia. I would think that that sort of action is in line with the sort of suggestion which was raised by Senator Watson in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for National Development and Energy follows the answer which he gave Senator Missen earlier in Question Time. Has not the Minister on numerous occasions used his portfolio to comment in this Senate in relation to demands for electricity in States such as New South Wales and Victoria and to criticise the governments of those States in respect of their capacity to fulfil demands at various times? Has not his ministry kept a continuing overview of the likely demand for electricity in Tasmania? Has there not been advice to him that the projected demand for electricity in Tasmania is declining on the basis of his Department's own assessments? What is now the current estimate of demand in the 1990s? Finally, I ask a question in respect of the first part of the Minister's portfolio-that of National Development. The Minister in his answer to Senator Missen referred to industries which might be attracted to Tasmania as a result of the building of the Franklin Dam. Can he indicate any industries which he as Minister for National Development and Energy knows would be likely to be attracted to Tasmania in that circumstance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has asked a very lengthy question which is made up of five parts. The first part is whether I, as Minister, have intervened to draw the attention of the States to what might be bad or inequitable practices in not having a sufficient volume of electricity, not having a sufficient maintenance and operational program and not having a sufficient pricing policy in order to get the proper capitalisation in order to attract industry from abroad. The answer is yes. Indeed, three years ago we had very dusty answers, particularly from New South Wales which is now applauding what we have done. It is the job of the Commonwealth to look at assessments in a national sense and to offer information to the States but not to force that information upon them. We have done so.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, I was asked whether we have looked as an overview at the States and at Tasmania in particular. It will be very well known here that my Government and I set up the Zeidler Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generating and the Sharing of Power Resources in South-east Australia to look at a south- eastern Australia grid and to see whether in fact it was feasible to link Victoria and South Australia and to run a cable to Tasmania. We have therefore been looking at an overview of Tasmania's needs. Indeed, the Zeidler Committee looked at that matter and said that there was a good possibility for a secondary type of grid linking Victoria and South Australia-that would be important for Tasmania-but at this moment it would be premature to have a cable. We have, indeed, looked at an overview of Tasmania's needs.

The fact is that, until about a year ago, the prospects for Tasmania were increasing and promising. Indeed, the Government based its thinking on expanding electricity upon the fact that two major industries, including the paper industry, were going to expand very significantly. It is sad that, because of the recession, industries have made negative decisions at the moment. But the fundamental situation is that nobody should take those negative decisions and project them into the future. That is destructive and negative thinking. The fact is that no one can say better than the State Government concerned what that Government has in mind for attracting industry and by way of providing a stimulus to industries that might come to Tasmania. The fact is that Tasmania has some grave disabilities because of its remoteness from other States. One of the very few potential stimuli that it has is its potential ability to provide cheap electricity with, one would hope, application to relatively small factories in labour intensive industries. I have no doubt in the world that that is what is aimed for.

As to the question of declining demand for electricity, the answer is yes. Of course, New South Wales at this moment is desperately putting down its electricity prices. In fact, it has a policy of decreasing electricity prices for industry. Is it suggested, therefore, that New South Wales should not at this moment be building power stations which will provide power which is massively surplus to demand? Let us get that matter quite straight. New South Wales and Victoria are building power stations to provide for future demand. The answer to the question as to declining demand is that one should disregard the immediacy of the recession and look to the future as other States, including Tasmania, are doing.
Finally, the fact of the matter is that industries such as those that prior to the recession had indicated that they would establish--

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them.

—I will get the names for the honourable senator. One industry, of course, is the paper industry. Let me just say this: A Tasmanian senator, Senator Grimes, does not know the two industries that were to be established. Let him tell us about the situation. Everybody in Tasmania knows that those two industries were to be established and, in fact, withdrew because of the recession. There are industries such as those. As to the five questions, it is quite clear that the decisions made by the Tasmanian Government are very sensible indeed. I will get the names of those two industries for the honourable senator.

—I ask a supplementary question. My question was about planning. I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: Has not his Department revised downwards the projected demand for electricity in Tasmania in the 1990s?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department indicated that because of the change of decision of those two industries as well as others--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Australian Labor Party were disputing the fact that the industries had made that decision and now the very report that is before the committee condemns them on this matter. In fact, there is at this moment a temporary decline in electricity demand. But the report goes on to say that if, of course, there were to be a pick-up from the recession and industries could be attracted to Tasmania the demand for electricity would be significant. Of course, it is interesting to watch Tasmanian Labor senators knocking Tasmania 's future and its development.
—Don't you say that. Tell the truth.
—Bear in mind that there would have been full support for this dam from the Labor Party if the Lowe Labor Government had won the last election. That is the key situation.
—Tell the truth.
—I tell the truth. Mr Hayden is on record in Launceston as saying that the building of the dam is a State matter.
—You lie again.
—Order! Senator Grimes, that language is most unparliamentary. I ask for an unconditional withdrawal.
—It is most unparliamentary for him to behave in that way.
—Order, Senator Grimes! I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw.

—We are having quite a few questions, as we have had for a number of weeks, on a certain area of Tasmania. I recall that in the past we had an Ord River scheme and we had a Dartmouth and Chowilla exercise; we now have a Franklin River exercise. I appreciate the emotions that are involved with these issues, but I ask all honourable senators to heed the fact that it might be late in the session but it is still fairly early in the morning.

—I will quote from the Launceston Examiner of 7 July 1981. If it is alleged that it is an untruth, it has never been denied. It was repeated in the House of Representatives in front of Mr Hayden and he did not deny it. The article is entitled 'Hayden petitioned to halt dam row' and states:

ANSWER.PARA: A vocal group of Hydro-Electric Commission workers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a similar point of order to that raised by Senator Chipp earlier in Question Time. I asked a very simple question: Has the Minister's Department revised downwards Tasmania's estimate of demand for electricity in the 1990s? Presumably, the answer is yes or no.
—It was alleged that what I said about Mr Hayden and his claim that the matter was one for the State of Tasmania alone-it was alleged by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition--
—I asked the question.
—I understand that. I now intend, within the Standing Orders, to reply to that. I repeat that the Launceston Examiner of 7 July--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Did I understand the Leader of the Government to say that he was replying to the interjection?

—Order! No, Senator; there is no point of order. I will not repeat what I said earlier in Question Time, but I suggest to the Leader of the Government that a lot of time has been spent on a particular issue and I hope that we can soon complete the answer to the question. I am not directing the Leader how to answer it.
—Never- theless, when veracity is challenged I think that every honourable senator in this chamber has the right to make such a statement.
—I am not disagreeing with that.
—I will finish my reply to the question in that regard in due course. I repeat that the article in the Launceston Examiner of 7 July 1981 headed 'Hayden petitioned to halt dam row' states:

ANSWER.PARA: A vocal group of Hydro-Electric Commission workers on Saturday called on the Leader of the Federal Opposition (Mr Hayden) to intervene in the State power wrangle.
They made their appeal in a petition presented to Mr Hayden before he opened the council meeting.
But Mr Hayden, while agreeing to discuss the matter with the Premier (Mr Lowe), made it clear that it was a State Government concern.
He said he would support a Federal Parliamentary inquiry into the power needs of Tasmania.
It went on to add:
It was not possible, however, for him to play a role in influencing the State Government.
Any suggestion that what I said yesterday or today is wrong is, of course, refuted in this statement. This was repeated in front of Mr Hayden in the House of Representatives and it was not refuted.

I was asked about my Department. My Department said, quite clearly, that the estimates had to be revised downwards because of the withdrawal of those two industries and the recession. The Department went on to add that the future demand for electricity would depend upon the capacity to attract industries. That, of course, is a decision that will be made by the State Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of a headline in the Australian today which says: 'Work damage may make heritage listing invalid'? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: South-west Tasmania could be dropped from the United Nations World Heritage list within the next couple of years because of irreversible damage caused by work on the Franklin dam.

The World Heritage convention includes a clause under which listed properties may be deleted 'where the property has deteriorated to the extent that it has lost those characteristics that determined its inclusion'.

So that this area may continue to be on the World Heritage List, will the Commonwealth Government re-examine its attitude towards supporting the Tasmanian Government's desecrating of this part of our world heritage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted that the Australian Government went to the World Heritage Committee having made a clear statement that it recognised the right of the Tasmanian Government to build the dam proposed for the South West. The World Heritage Committee listed the region as a wilderness of world consequence in the knowledge that there was an intention to build the dam. That is quite clear. I have said that we will look at what Professor Slatyer has to say and determine what are the responsibilities of the Commonwealth, in conjunction with the State of Tasmania, to preserve the wilderness to the maximum extent possible. We will do everything within our power to ensure that there is a management plan which conforms to the World Heritage Committee and which preserves the wilderness. The possibility of that being done must have been in the minds of those who listed the area; otherwise it would not have been listed at all.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The article says that the area will be dropped from the World Heritage List if deterioration occurs. Surely the Minister is aware that Fraser Cave will be flooded. Surely that indicates that the area can be dropped, because it will be desecrated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that the World Heritage Committee knew of this. It had available to it information on what the flooding would do. Secondly , there is now a major responsibility to look at the management of the area to ensure that absolutely minimal interference with the wilderness takes place. That will be done.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Government given consideration to the fact that the $100m promised to the States for public housing has caught the State housing authorities by surprise, given that the States have been denied funds for so long to develop adequately serviced building blocks. Is the Government aware that most of the land available to the States for public housing is available only on the fringe of capital cities and that these areas lack basic community facilities because this Government has cut back moneys for urban development programs? Will the Government provide additional funds for community amenities so that the mistakes of the past will not be repeated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question might more sensibly be directed to the State Ministers who are responsible for providing community facilities. It is probably broadly true that in the past public housing developments have taken place on a wide area basis, when housing has been provided without the requisite other facilities, and that has given rise to real social problems. I think the State housing authorities have learned from that problem of the past and many of them are now changing their procedures. For example, they are adopting a pepper and salt approach to State housing, ensuring that they build not in broad acres but in lots which are scattered among non-housing commission houses.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the $100m is concerned, I do not think there is any reason at all to doubt that the States have the ability to pick up the additional money and to use it productively within the next 12 months. Indeed, a number of States have rejected offers from private industry to build houses. I think the South Australian State Government, for example, has a large number of builders available and ready to work. It is my understanding that the capacity of the industry is such that it can certainly build additional housing at relatively short notice. I have not had any suggestion from any State that the funds cannot be put to work quickly and effectively.

Senator Childs is concerned about a problem which is unlikely to exist. I think it could well be true that the States could absorb further funds for welfare housing if more funds, rather than less, were available. I do not think any other aspect of the question needs attention. This is an area in which the Commonwealth and the States have, by their joint efforts, managed to achieve substantially better results this year than last year. The additional $100m will , of course, add to that. I believe this is an area in which Commonwealth-State co-operation is effective and is producing very useful results.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. It is prompted by the fact that in many States, as Christmas approaches, drivers will be allowed to have less alcohol in their blood than they were able to have. Is the Minister aware that in some States of the United States a dramatic drop in the death rate has been obtained by lifting to 21 years the age at which people are allowed to drive? If the Government seriously wishes to save lives on the road, will it investigate this matter and discuss it with the various departments of transport in the States of Australia?

—The Government has a very great interest in motor accidents, the problems that are caused to society as a result and certainly the very significant costs of a social kind that flow from such accidents. On the specific point that has been raised, I have no information about the situation in the United States. It is an interesting suggestion and I will pass it on to the Minister for his consideration.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services inasmuch as the Australian Federal Police come within the purview of that ministry. By way of explanation I say that I received in my office yesterday some of the most virulent anti-Semitic material I have ever seen which is obviously designed to spread hatred throughout the community. I have also ascertained that many honourable senators have also received such material. Has the Minister seen this material? If so, what action has he taken? If not, can he advise honourable senators as to what action they and other members of the community ought to take if they come into possession of such material?
—I saw that material only very briefly because it immediately went from my table to the bin. I suggest that all honourable senators put the material in the bin.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Is it true that Telecom Australia has been forced to waste thousands of dollars on the installation of a low power transmitter at Nowra on the south coast of New South Wales? Is this transmitter part of a temporary facility to enable a telefinder paging system to be operated in the area? Is it a fact that at present a local medical practitioner is the only potential subscriber to the proposed service? Was the telefinder system to have been installed before the end of June 1983? Has the erection of this temporary facility resulted only because of pressure exerted by the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair?
—It will not surprise honourable senators that I will need to refer the question to the Minister for a detailed answer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources aware that, following an initiative introduced by the previous Labor Government to impose an export duty on coking coal, the duty is still levied on some coal mining operations in Queensland? Does the Minister realise that this $ 3.50 per tonne export duty costs the Queensland mining operation of the Utah Development Co. between $60m and $70m per year? I point out that the mines in New South Wales, however, do not pay any coal export duty on coking coal. Will the Minister please enunciate the Government's intentions regarding the present export duty? Does the Government not feel that it discriminates against some coking coal mining operations in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to say, with the best of good will, that there is no intention to discriminate between any States. Senator Bjelke- Petersen will understand that the Queenslanders' estate is blessed by not only rich deposits of coal and coking coal but also very accessible deposits, largely in open-cut. She will also know that in New South Wales the deposits are largely in underground mines, extraction from which entails very high expense. So, of course, they have two different cost projections, which should be kept in mind. The Government has moved over a number of years to reduce the effect of the coal export levy originally imposed by the previous Labor Government, but the extent of the changes has been limited by broader budgetary considerations.

ANSWER.PARA: In July the Minister for Trade and Resources announced the Government's intention to exempt from duty all coals previously dutiable at $1 a tonne. As far as Queensland was concerned this included all underground export coal in that State, all steaming coal, all coal from new projects, and coal from deep open-cut operations such as those being developed by Utah Development Co. with new technology. So, contrary to the suggestion in the latter part of the question, Queensland received a significant benefit from this. The change announced in July followed discussions with the Premiers of New South Wales and Queensland and coincided with actions by State governments in the areas of State revenue from the coal industry which reflected the States' own assessments of where action was necessary. The Senate should bear in mind, also, that the States themselves have placed imposts on coal and other mining, particularly in regard to railway freights and indirect matters. The Government will review the remaining coal export duty, when framing the next Budget, in the light of budgetary circumstances. Beyond that I can give no specific assurances. Both the companies concerned and the Queensland Government are aware of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the document.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it true that the Government has not consulted the Australian Consumers' Association about the structure of the proposed National Health and Medical Research Council? Is it also true that the proposed structure for this Council includes no scope for representation of consumer interests by the Australian Consumers' Association, which the Minister acknowledges has some standing in the community and is financially assisted by the Government? Will the Minister explain the Government's attitude on this matter, particulary its ignoring organised, committed and recognised consumer interest? I am aware that the Minister, particularly, regards the question of consumer interests as having a very valid place in the question of medical care.

—I am certainly aware that the structure of the National Health and Medical Research Council is a live issue at present. Honourable senators may, like me, have received a considerable number of representations on the matter. It is under consideration by the Government, but we are not in a position to make a decision yet, nor are we ready so to do. As to whether or not the Australian Consumers' Association has been consulted, I shall have to ask the Minister whom I represent. I simply do not know whether he has consulted the Association. I understand that he is consulting widely with bodies that have an interest in the NH and MRC. The difficulty is that it represents an interface between the different governments. So there needs to be extensive Government representation on the Council. It has a technical/expert role to play, so there need to be a certain number of expert representatives on the Council as well. I think the value judgment that will have to be made is as to how big the Council should be and how wide its membership should be. As I say, the matter is one which has yet to be considered by the Government and is, I imagine, still in the preparatory stages.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the great emphasis given by the media to the so-called generosity of the Polish military junta by its announcement that martial law could be suspended, but not abolished, for the Christmas period , meaning that the Polish people will still be subject to a total dictatorial rule of the junta, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, approach the Polish ambassador in Australia and, through our ambassador to Poland, express the deep concern of, and total condemnation by, the Australian Government and the Australian people of the junta's detainment of thousands of Polish citizens without proper trial and the maintenance of martial law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — One part of the question will need to be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In general, the Minister noted the announcement that martial law in Poland is to be suspended on 31 December. This followed the welcome release from detention of a number of detainees. Taken at their face value, these moves seem to be a step towards reconciliation and away from confrontation. The Government sincerely hopes that martial law will be lifted entirely and that all the elements of repression, which have prevailed in Poland in the past year, will be removed. But it is too early to judge whether that will occur.

ANSWER.PARA: The developments now taking place bear close examination and their implications will need to be carefully weighed. That process may take some time. Australia has consistently called for the ending of martial law, the release of all detainees and a return to circumstances in which the people of Poland would find a solution to their economic and political difficulties on the basis of consensus and reconciliation. The divisions and bitterness in Polish society resulting from the imposition of martial law last year remain. They will be difficult to overcome unless the Polish people are able to make their own choices free from internal intimidation and external coercion. In that regard General Jaruzelski and others in the martial law leadership bear a very heavy responsibility not only to the Polish nation but also to the international community. If Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, wishes to make some comment on the suggestions made by Senator Lajovic I will see that he is advised accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Which Government repudiated the 1975 joint Federal-State Liberal Party agreement spoken of by Senator Peter Rae on 2 December which stated that it was important that early action be taken to preserve the South West wilderness area and promised federal aid for a management plan and compensation for Tasmania if it gave up plans for the construction of dams in the area? When was the agreement repudiated? Was this agreement broken unilaterally by either the State or the Federal Liberal Party? Was there any discussion before this firm policy commitment of 1975 was reversed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that any policies put forward by the Federal Government have been repudiated. I will take the matter in hand. It is a matter for the Prime Minister because, of course, any arrangement between the Prime Minister and the Premier would be a matter for the Prime Minister. I will draw it to his attention and seek an answer.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a brief supplementary question. Am I to understand that the Minister is saying that there was no such policy commitment and that there was no firm commitment of the type spoken about by Senator Peter Rae?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The use of a supplementary question to put a hypothetical and rhetorical question, of course, is nonsense. That was not my answer at all. I said that I would refer the substance of Senator Grimes's question to the Prime Minister, because it is a matter involving the Prime Minister and the Premier, and that I would get an answer for the honourable senator.

—Has the Minister for Education read the editorial appearing in today's Canberra Times relating to education funding? If he has, is he able to say whether it is an accurate description of the funding situation? If not, will he advise us accordingly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the editorial in today's Canberra Times entitled ' Children's Education'. I thought it was a very fair treatment of what has been a difficult matter. For some time we have been saying that there are three funding partners in education in Australia-the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and private sources. We have been saying that one has to look at all three sources to get any kind of accurate idea of the funding situation. The editorial in this morning's Canberra Times reiterates that point. It goes further and states:

ANSWER.PARA: The fact the ALP spokesmen make it a practice never to refer to total funding trends, and the fact that when those trends are considered the party's statement that government schools are being deprived by non-government schools reverses the truth, suggests deliberate deceit.

I think that is a fair summation of what the debate has been about. There are three funding partners in education in Australia. When the three are considered together it will be seen that government schools are thriving, as they should be . To mount an argument that government schools are deprived or in some way disadvantaged simply is playing with the truth. We are very grateful for the editorial. I believe those interested in the education debate will want to read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education, also arises from a report in the Canberra Times this morning. As the Minister has read the editorial he has probably also read the report that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has made a decision to stop taping private meetings in order to circumvent the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act. I would like the Minister to confirm first of all that such a decision has been taken by the Authority, and secondly, to say whether it is government policy that public bodies or parts of the bureaucracy should be able to circumvent the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act in this Way.

—I read several stories in the Canberra Times this morning. I noticed that the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation has indicated that it is going to back the Australian Labor Party in the next election.
—Surprise, surprise!

—Surprise, surprise! I say all power to it. I agree with the comments made by Mr Cornwell in the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, who observed that many teachers would be unhappy with having themselves, through their union, allied with the Labor Party and its divisive policy on education. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is in charge of its own procedures; they are not matters which are referred to me as Minister. They are not matters in which I would want to be proscriptive. I would expect the Authority to observe the proper procedures and I am sure it will comply with all the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that a survey which was carried out in all States showed that a substantial proportion of imported cheese contained chemical additives not permitted to be used in Australian manufacture, through regulations of the National Health and Medical Research Council? Is it correct that the matter has been referred to the State Ministers for Health for their consideration? If so, what result has been achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A survey for control of the quality of imported cheese was conducted by the Chief Dairy Officers Committee, a body composed of the chiefs of the dairy divisions of State agricultural authorities and the Federal Department of Primary Industry. I do not think the survey was done through the NH and MRC. The survey showed that a significant proportion of imported cheese and cheese spreads contained additives not permitted under State and Territory food legislation. The thrust of the honourable senator's question can be confirmed. It can also be confirmed that the report has been submitted to all State health authorities. I am not aware of any action resulting from the referral.

ANSWER.PARA: Imported and locally manufactured foods are equally required to comply with State and Territory food legislation. In practice, State and Territory health authorities have difficulty policing such matters once the products have been distributed in the market place. Federal involvement is limited to the powers under the Customs prohibited import regulations and the Quarantine Act 1908. Authorities in either of these areas are not in a position to act except when a specific health risk is involved. Where complaints have been received by the Federal Department of Health, the complainant is advised to supply specific details to State and Territory health authorities for direct action. This issue is to be submitted for further consideration to the inter-departmental committee on imported foods, representing Federal Departments of Health, Industry and Commerce, Primary Industry, Science and Technology and Trade and Resources. I can confirm that a survey has been carried out and that some imported cheeses have been found to have this problem.
Sentor McLaren-I ask that the document read from by the Minister be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I table it.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that on 1 December the medication Prantal powder was removed from the free pharmaceutical benefits list? Is the Minister further aware that the hundreds of age pensioners who are prescribed this medication for skin conditions now have to pay $4.02 for each prescription? Is the Government totally unaware of how difficult it is to live on the age pension? Can he explain why pensioners who are finding it very difficult to make ends meet now have to pay for medications which until this month were free?

—I think Senator McIntosh is correct to the extent that a new list of pharmaceutical benefits was due in about December. I take it that he is saying that the new list does not contain a particular product-I think Prantal powder. The list is made up not of all available medications but of those which after a careful assessment are thought to be either essential, life saving, or products which are known to be efficacious and safe. The list changes in each new publication. The committees which make up the list add to it and also delete certain products from it. I am not aware that Prantal powder was on the list before or that it has been deleted. If it has been deleted, I imagine that it would be for one of two reasons: First, there might have been a reassessment of the value of the agent in terms of whether it does any good or, secondly, it might be that its cost is below the contribution level. If the honourable senator says that its cost is $4.02 it is unlikely that it has been deleted because it is too cheap to be on the list. It might be best for Senator McIntosh if I refer the question to Mr Carlton, the Minister for Health, so that we can get some detailed information about the factors which lie behind the listing or the delisting of Prantal powder.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time I made a number of statements on Tasmania and its power needs. One was in regard to two major industries that had decided to defer their building program. That statement was challenged. I also made some statements regarding a submission from my Department to the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, which were challenged. I now report to the Senate that one of the two companies involved, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd, is to build a major mill at Wesley Vale. That is a fact. What I said was right. The plans have not been rejected; they have been deferred. Therefore, further future demands for power by that company are very possible. The other organisation involved is the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Tasmania Electro Metallurgical Co. Pty Ltd which has plans for a ferro- manganese plant. There was some derision of the suggestion that the submission of the Department of National Development and Energy had indicated that Tasmania's power needs depended upon the future ability to attract industry. I will read very briefly the relevant paragraphs. They state:

ANSWER.PARA: The future industrial strategy of the State must also be taken into account. The mainland States' ability to attract energy-based industries has been an important factor in the growth being experienced in this area. Tasmania, too, may have a need to expand electricity generation capacity in order to provide for potential expansion in energy based industries.
The submission also states:

Any significant change in the level of demand for electricity in the State as a consequence of changes in the level of operations of the manufacturing sector could affect the time frame in which the provision of further hydro-electricity generating capacity will be required.
It goes on to state:

It should be emphasised that all forecasts of this nature must be subject to qualification. Adjustments can be argued depending on basic assumptions adopted , especially changes in economic growth rates, major individual projects and energy prices and related elasticities.
That is precisely what I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 December Senator Sibraa asked me a question about drought relief and the introduction of an unemployment assistance scheme which would provide work in country towns. I gave an answer at that time which I will now supplement. The question of a special rural employment relief scheme for drought affected areas has been re-examined but it remains the Government's view that it is more appropriate to try to preserve permanent jobs by maintaining farmers' liquidity through the provision of carry on finance. Such finance enables farmers to conduct their business in a more normal manner despite drought induced difficulties. The benefits flow through to other sectors, thus assisting to maintain activity and employment. The expansion of carry on loans to small businesses in drought affected rural towns, as has been proposed to the States, assists in a similar way. Unemployment is affecting both urban and rural areas and is being handled as a problem separate from that of drought. The Government believes the problem should be handled in a comprehensive way and not by initiating relief unemployment schemes in selected areas.
