DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE ON DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT AND OCCUPATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is a welcome report to the extent that it deals with a very serious problem in Australian working life-the matter of discrimination against minority groups and women. The Australian Labor Party, of course, believes that the elimination of discrimination in employment and occupation is very important. However, I must again express my serious reservations about whether the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation or its constituent State committees can be effective in eliminating such discrimination while they have no powers of enforcement. They certainly serve a useful purpose in documenting those cases of discrimination which are brought to their attention and, to a minor extent, are able to offer some assistance to people experiencing discrimination through their conciliation activities. However, it is quite clear that the extent of discrimination in employment in Australia is such that committees of this kind alone cannot deal effectively with the problem.

If we are to be serious about combating discrimination federal legislation in this area is necessary. As honourable senators know I have attempted to make a move in this direction by introducing a private members Bill outlawing discrimination based on sex and martial status. That Bill, the Sex Discrimination Bill 1981, was introduced into this House in November last year. The most important aspect of the Bill is the prevention of discrimination in employment on the grounds of sex or marital status. Of course, employment is the most important area in which we should be attempting to overcome discrimination because employment is the major determinant in securing an adequate income and standard of living for all groups in society. Women, Aboriginals, migrants, numerous minority groups and certain handicapped people are disadvantaged in the area of employment and occupation. Such groups ought to be able to rely upon the Federal Government to establish effective mechanisms to protect their rights in this crucial area of employment. However, the Government has failed to establish such effective mechanisms.

Whilst acknowledging that the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation functions under the difficulty of having no real powers, I do commend the useful work that the Committee carries out. The report documents the Committee's co-operation with the various State anti- discrimination and equal opportunity agencies and with the Commissioner for Community Relations and the Human Rights Commission. Such co-operation is, of course, useful and should lead to more comprehensive statistical material covering the area of discrimination in employment.

I welcome the Committee's interest in discrimination in employment in the defence forces. The changes in defence forces policy outlined on pages 9 and 10 of the report represent a marginal improvement in women's access to jobs in the defence forces. Women may now be employed as musicians for the Defence Force bands, which is a better situation than that which prevailed before when they could not apply for such jobs. It is to be hoped, and I hope that the Government will ensure, that the new Army apprenticeship school at Albury will allow the Army to take on female apprentices. The Royal Australian Navy will now employ female engineers and it is hoped that the Royal Australian Navy will soon be in a position to recruit male nurses. The Royal Australian Air Force is reported to be introducing a policy which will enable the recruitment of married women. So to this extent the report is welcome. I am glad to see that the defence forces are slowly moving into the twentieth century but of course they still have a long way to go.

It is the view of the Australian Labor Party that true equality of opportunity in the defence forces, as in all areas of employment, will not be achieved merely by the occupation of this Committee but by the introduction of proper wide-ranging federal legislation in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ACCOMMODATION AND CATERING SERVICES LTD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Labor Party welcomes the appearance of the first annual report of the Human Rights Commission which covers the seven-month period from July to December 1981. We commend the work done by the Commission in that period. However, it must be acknowledged that the report is a rather circumspect document. I think it reflects the nature of the Human Rights Commission itself.

Although the objectives of the Human Rights Commission are important, it is an agency which has been given no real powers to implement its responsibilities. So it is not surprising, I suppose, that an agency which has no real powers to implement its charter will appear rather timid. In saying that I am not implying that the Human Rights Commission lacks dedicated or well-meaning commissioners or staff. What I am saying is that the Commission has no coercive powers. It cannot bind the States and it cannot implement any penalties. An interesting comparison can be made with the National Companies and Securities Commission which, of course, does have the power to make orders and apply penalties if those orders are not complied with. So obviously in areas in which the Federal Government believes that action is important it is prepared to give powers. In other areas, of course, and in this all important area of human rights, the Fraser Government is not prepared to give implementing powers.

The Commission, of course, recognises the limiting factors on its work and in fact cites three major limiting factors on page 3 of its annual report. The first one is a federal Constitution which lacks entrenched rights. This is a major difficulty which we acknowledge and which, when in Government, we will change. My colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, has outlined our comprehensive approach to the protection of human rights in Australia, which includes the enactment of a national Bill of rights, first as a statute and ultimately, through referendum, as a part of the Constitution. This is a course of action which a government with a serious intention to protect human rights in Australia in an effective way would of course follow.

The second problem to which the report draws our attention is the existence of eight sovereign political entities. A lack of co-operation on the part of various States makes it virtually impossible for a commission with no coercive powers to protect human rights effectively. This was brought out very strongly in the reports of the former Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Grassby, and echoes of the same concern are expressed in this report. Two States in particular, Western Australia and Queensland, have demonstrated absolutely no interest in protecting human rights. On the contrary, both are infamous for their more outrageous violations of human rights-for example, Noonkanbah in Western Australia and the activities of the Queensland Government in relation to Aboriginal and Islander reserves, its Commonwealth Games Bill, street march laws and so on. The High Court decision in the Koowarta case provides a sound constitutional basis for human rights legislation which will be binding on the States. Without such legislation the Human Rights Commission works under a severe handicap. The Government's failure to provide such a sound basis for protecting human rights demonstrates once again the well-known failure of this Government to deal effectively with the States on matters of national interest and concern. Yet again we see that States rights are obviously more important to this Government than human rights.

A third area of difficulty documented by the Commission's report is the interrelationship of the two Houses of the Federal Parliament. By listing this as a peculiar problem in the protection of human rights in Australia, I can only assume that the annual report is referring to the long and difficult passage of human rights legislation in this country. On page 4 the report in fact gives a brief history of human rights legislation which outlines the first atempts to introduce human rights legislation in 1973 by Labor's then Attorney-General, now Mr Justice Lionel Murphy of the High Court. It was not until 1981 that the emasculated piece of legislation we now have was passed, and passed only after a long struggle fought by the Labor Party and others in this place trying to strengthen it.

The real impediment to the protection of human rights is not, I believe, the interrelationship between the two Houses of this Parliament, but the lack of any true bipartisan commitment to the effective protection of human rights in this country. An example of how the Human Rights Commission could be used effectively to protect human rights is contained in my private member's Bill outlawing discrimination based on sex and marital status. That Bill gives the Human Rights Commission real powers to hold inquiries into complaints, impose penalties for non-co-operation and, in the final instance, to initiate proceedings in the Federal Court where the Commission believes this is appropriate. The Commission must be armed with such powers if it is not to continue to be ultimately ineffective.

A major shortcoming of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 is its failure to include under the jurisdiction of the Commission the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. Civil and political rights and the rights of children and the disabled are to be upheld under conventions annexed to the Human Rights Commission Act. However, the right of women to equality is not. Again the Federal Government has distorted the basis for the protection of human rights. I understand that the Commission works closely with anti-discrimination and equal opportunity agencies in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and that many complaints received on the grounds of sex or martial status can be referred to these agencies. But this leaves without protection women in Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania.

Volume 2 of the annual report contains the report of the Commissioner for Community Relations for the period 1 July to 9 December. This represents the last five month period of independent operation of the Commissioner before the Office was officially subsumed into the Human Rights Commission on 10 December 1981. This report documents another excellent chapter in the work of the former Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Al Grassby. Mr Grassby's work in proposing and seeking to eliminate discrimination over the last seven years has been truly outstanding. In particular, I commend his work on behalf of Aboriginal Australians. Mr Grassby has been the most vigorous and effective campaigner for human rights that Australia has ever had. I should place on record my view that the Government's failure to reappoint him to the Human Rights Commission is disgraceful. It is further evidence that the Government would prefer the Commission to be a low profile body that will not rock the boat .

On page 5, volume 2, of this report Mr Grassby puts forward four recommendations for amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act which would make that Act more effective. I hope that the Government will take up these recommendations so that a more effective attack on racial discrimination in this country can be mounted. Such action is particularly important in the current climate in which, in recent months, we have seen an increase in racial violence in this country, some with a tragic outcome. This resurgence of racism is even more distressing when it is fanned by such bodies as the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and individual members of that Government. I refer in particular to the activities of the Speaker for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, Mr Les MacFarlane who, in recent weeks, has led a racist march in Katherine and is well known for his racist statements and activities in the Northern Territory.

Racial discrimination at this level-in fact, at all levels-is very difficult for any Commissioner for Community Relations to combat without the full, enthusiastic backing of the Federal Government. Of course, Mr Grassby did not always enjoy such serious backing in the past. The Australian Labor Party urges the Government to give strong backing to the new Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Jeremy Long. His job will certainly not be an easy one and we wish him all the best. Mr Long, of course, has a hard act to follow because of the outstanding work of Mr Grassby. On behalf of the Labor Party I wish Mr Long every success in continuing the excellent work established in this area by Mr Grassby.

In volume 1 of this annual report the other activities of the Human Rights Commission are documented. During 1981-82 the Commission performed some very useful work. For example, it carried out a review of the Australian Capital Territory Mental Health Ordinance in order to ensure that this piece of legislation does not infringe human rights of citizens in my electorate, the Australian Capital Territory. Another significant matter to which the report draws attention at page 20 is the inconsistent and discriminatory way in which various Federal Government Departments treat de facto couples. This is certainly an area in which the Labor Party advocates reform.

In conclusion, I commend the useful work done by the Human Rights Commission in its early months. I again reinforce our view that without a stronger statutory base the Human Rights Commission, although it does have laudable objectives and a dedicated staff, will not in fact be able to be a truly effective protector of human rights in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first instance, I deny any restriction at all on human rights, as stated by Senator Ryan, in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. Only biased people would ever suggest such a thing. I can think of many better examples than those given by Senator Ryan of human rights implementation. Of course, the first example is the protection of the life of the unborn in this country. I note that the Human Rights Commission has made an attempt, at page--
—What about commenting on what your Liberal Western Australian Government does to Aboriginies?
—Order, Senator Gietzelt!

—Wait until I turn my hearing aid off, Mr Deputy President. At pages 28 and 29 of volume 1 of the Human Rights Commission report I note that the Commission has made an attempt. It calls it a provisional attempt, but it seems to me that what it is trying to do is to sit on the fence. I am indebted to the Commission for drawing attention to a couple of things in this argument that had escaped me in the past. It drew attention to the American Convention on Human Rights which declares that the right to life shall be protected by law and , in general, from the moment of conception. One does not need much of a memory to recollect that that is exactly what I wanted to do when the Human Rights Bill was originally before the House of Representatives. The Commission also drew attention to an inter-American commission on human rights which found that laws which permit abortion, even if it would appear subsequent to viability, do not infringe either the article or the convenant that we are speaking about.

SPEECH.PARA: To me, there are some quite definite equivocations in the attitude of the Commission. I would certainly prefer that it carry out the commission given to it by this Parliament in the sense that it investigate, foster and make a clear decision about the protection of the right to life of the unborn. I would hate to think-I am referring particularly now to page 29 at which in vitro fertilisation is mentioned-that the Commission was bowing to pressures from Professor Carl Wood and his 'anything goes' lobby in Victoria. They are the people who are conducting experimentation on human subjects, even to the point of destruction of those human subjects. I hope that future reports by the Commission will have something serious to say about the problems, unanswered as yet, of in vitro fertilisation and foetal medicine. Until they do, I think it is fair to suggest that the Commission will not be fulfilling the function given to it by the Commonwealth Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the appearance of the Australia Council annual report at this stage. I note that it is on time. I commend the Australia Council for its prompt reporting to the Parliament. The Council's reports have not always been on time. A significant time improvement in making this report available to the Parliament is something that should not escape notice. I presume that Senator Hamer, who takes an interest in these matters, will agree with me. The report is welcome because it documents in a very thorough way the issues in the development of Australian culture and the areas assisted by the Australia Council in the last year. Most importantly, I think, the report documents very clearly the decline in funding and staff available to the Australia Council to carry out its work over the past few years. I draw the attention of honourable senators to a summary of this situation on page 18 of the report which sets out the realities of the financial situation of the arts. The report states:
In the last five years, government funding through the Australia Council has lagged:
12 per cent behind inflation;
14 per cent behind increases in wages;
23 percent behind total Federal Government support for cultural activities;
27 per cent behind the growth in the budgets of the Council's client companies; and
16 per cent behind growth in total Federal Government expenditure.

Ironically, the steady reduction in available funds has coincided with a marked growth in awareness of and demand for the arts-largely as a result of the injection of government funds earlier in the decade, and also of a five per cent increase in the population between 1977-78 and 1981-82.

I hope that very clear statement of the financial situation of the Australia Council will lead to a more generous treatment of it in next year's Budget. Of course, if it is a Budget brought down by a Labor government the Council will be treated more realistically than it has been by the Fraser Government in the past . I hope that the Government takes note of the seriously disadvantaged position the Council is now in and, indeed, has been in for the last few years. It is in an area of Government activity which is absolutely essential. I think in this chamber it is a bipartisan view that Australian culture ought to be supported as it is by the Australia Council. Clearly, there is a growing interest in and awareness of the arts and a great demand by Australians in all parts of the country for their share of the arts dollar. There ought also to be a recognition of this growing and dynamic area in funding decisions that are made by government.

The inadequate funding of the Council does not mean only that new projects cannot be supported. It means also that the Council or its boards often have to make invidious choices. For example, the year before last the Council had to decide to redress the funding balance towards individuals rather than companies. It had previously been able slightly to increase funds available to the performing arts companies but had not been able to increase support for individuals, so that individual artists depending on public assistance in this way were slipping well behind. That decision was reversed and the Council decided to increase funding to individual artists but, because of its own inadequate funding, it had to reduce funding for companies, again creating huge organisational and employment problems for people working in performing arts companies throughout Australia. The point I am making is that once certain activities are set up and certain forms of assistance are established it is very difficult for the Council and its boards to make decisions to withdraw support. Of course, whenever such decisions are made they are controversial. Senators and members of Parliament get lobbied and a lot of time and resources have to be diverted to re-establishing the level of grants that were previously available. I think the whole development of arts activities in this country would be a lot more efficient and fruitful if a reasonable amount of funding were available for this purpose.

I comment too on the new structure that has been established within the Australia Council under the chairmanship of Dr Timothy Pascoe. The Australian Labor Party endorses the objectives of the new structure which are to streamline the operations of the Council, make more efficient use of the staff available to them and improve and rationalise the services available to clients of the Council. However, I have expressed from time to time some reservations about the new structure, mainly about the speed with which it was introduced and the very little consultation that was engaged in with the staff and clients of the Council before the restructuring was imposed. It is my view that if the progress of restructuring had been handled more slowly and with more consultation some of the dislocation which, undoubtedly, has been experienced by the staff and clients of the Council could have been avoided. However, as I said, we endorse the objectives of the restructuring and, of course, we wait to see whether those objectives will be achieved.

The Australian Labor Party welcomes the priorities that have been stated in the Australia Council report, in particular the statement that it is now a priority of the Council's activities to widen access to the arts. Of course, that conforms very much with the Australian Labor Party's view of the responsibility of a Federal funding agency in this area. We are all very well aware of the high standards attained by some of our major performing arts companies such as the Australian Ballet, the Australian Opera and the large theatre companies in Sydney and Melbourne. However, we also recognise that many Australians will never have access to those performing arts companies. People will be denied access for example by geographical factors. If they live in the north west of Western Australia, Northern Queensland, or the Northern Territory they will not be able to get access to companies based in Sydney and Melbourne. There are other factors such as lack of educational opportunity, socio-economic and cultural reasons which will prevent many Australians from having access to these mainsteam large companies. Therefore, we think it is important that the Council look at other ways of giving everybody in the Australian community access to arts experiene and, specifically, access to programs funded by the Australia Council. That objective of the Council is very welcome to the Australian Labor Party.

It is also welcome that the Australia Council has decided that its national programs for the forthcoming year will be on the themes of multiculturalism and art and working life. Clearly both of these areas are areas where very vigorous arts activity is possible but where, in the past, there has been a neglect of support by Federal agencies. Therefore, we look forward with hope to seeing some very interesting developments both in the multicultural area and the area of art and working life. It is welcome too that the report has drawn attention to the employment potential of this area. At a time when we have record unemployment and when the Government seems to be unable to see the areas in which employment growth is possible the attention of the Government ought to be drawn to the fact that the arts industry currently employs about 100,000 people and could employ many more with a minimal increase in funding. I hope that when the Government is deciding what to do with the money it has saved by imposing a wages freeze on Commonwealth public servants it will look very seriously at making some of that money available to the arts area for two reasons. The first is the obvious labour intensive character of the arts and the second is that it is a constructive activity welcomed by communities. Of course, that activity would be particularly welcome in those communities which so far have been relatively disadvantaged.

I draw honourable senators' attention to the enormous diversity of activities which are documented in the Australia Council report. If evidence were needed for the case that the arts deserve a better deal in the funding area I think that evidence would be found in the list of activities supported or assisted by the Australia Council. There really is no important area of cultural life now in any part of Australia that does not receive some assistance under one of the programs of the Australia Council. For that reason I think the Australia Council deserves our congratulations, deserves a better deal in Federal Government funding than it has achieved under the Fraser Government.

Finally, I welcome the higher public profile that the Council has achieved in recent months. One of its primary functions ought to be the advocacy of the arts in Australia to not only the Government but also the Australian public, so that we can have a very informed and lively debate about cultural life in this country and a continuation of the regeneration of Australian cultural life which was begun in the Whitlam period.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to make a couple of points in respect to the report, and to the Special Broadcasting Service generally. I think one could say that in its two years of operation the Special Broadcasting Service has not reached the potential that it could very well have reached. The cause relates very much to problems of overburdening administration as well as divorcement from the community which it is supposed to be serving. The criticisms are varied and have long been held by members of the community in the capital cities of Melbourne and Sydney where the Service, especially the television service, operates.

Specifically, the main area of criticism relates to the administration and the divorcement of that administration from the community. When one looks at who is in charge of the Special Broadcasting Service one finds that people have been appointed not for their ethnic community involvement but for their service to government and, in the case of Mr Petro Georgiou, for his personal service to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). That divorcement of the head of the Special Broadcasting Service has led, as I said earlier, to problems in respect of programming where people have not been all that happy with the content of the television service, in particular. When one goes through the Special Broadcasting Service report one finds aspects of programming mentioned therein that, from my understanding of ethnic communities in Australia, would not in part be all that acceptable.

Before I go on to deal with the positive parts of the Service about which I am concerned I wish to deal with an aspect mentioned on page 10 of the report. We seem to have a developing international film club which has been sponsored by the taxpayer. It has been acknowledged in the report that officers of the Special Broadcasting Service are travelling overseas to attend film festivals. In October 1981 officers went to Milan and in April 1982 to Cannes to select films. I do not think it is a function of the Special Broadcasting Service to send people overseas on taxpayers' money to indulge in exercises of that sort.

On the positive front, I mention that there has been acceptance by the community of, for instance, the series Women in the Sun-a series that has been highly acclaimed-for which the Special Broadcasting Service should be given credit. It should be given credit also for its sports program and news service. I believe that it has probably one of the best news services on television in Australia.

It has been suggested from time to time that the Australian Broadcasting Commission is the most appropriate channel to handle multicultural television. I reiterate in this respect the attitude of the Australian Labor Party, adopted in July of this year at its federal conference, that it would extend the services of the Special Broadcasting Service nationally. Since that conference was held the Government has adopted a very similar stand. Historically the ABC has not shown an interest in or involvement with the ethnic component of the Australian community, nor does it seem to want to do so in the future. One need look only at the statements of the chairperson of the ABC, Professor Leonie Kramer as reported in the Melbourne Age on 10 November this year. When she was asked whether she thought the idea of multicultural television was misguided, she stated:
Yes, in a sense I do. The motion that by showing Continental films you are really helping the process of adjustment, I think, is not right.
She went on to say that she thought multiculturalism was an 'abstract rhetoric' which had little relation to the reality of non-English speaking people in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I notice that the troglodytes from Western Australia are agreeing with her.
—There is only one Western Australian here.

—I should say then that Senator Martyr, the troglodyte from Western Australia, is agreeing with Professor Kramer. The point is that Professor Kramer, by her comments and public statement, shows that she does not understand the composite nature of the Australian community and the fact that over 30 per cent to 35 per cent of Australians have an ethnic background and have particular needs and services which should be provided by government. Her statement and her lack of recognition of responsibility by the national broadcaster to that very important section of our community shows that she is not fit for the job of Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn very briefly to the extension of the service involving television to South Australia. I was involved in the campaign that was run in South Australia earlier this year to have the Special Broadcasting Service and multicultural television extended to that State. We do not need to have the radio section extended to South Australia because radio station 5EBIFM is respected throughout Australia as being the best run community broadcasting station in South Australia. It is run extremely well and has extremely high recognition and acceptance by the community in our State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that funded by the SBS?

—In fact, it is funded, as Senator Messner says, by government through the SBS. That, of course, comes out in the SBS report. The point I make in respect of ethnic television is that EBIFM in South Australia operates well because of community participation and involvement, something which is lacking in respect of multicultural television. Over 10,000 South Australians signed petitions earlier this year to have multicultural television extended to our State. As a consequence, on 25 July the Government announced an extension to South Australia which will take place in the 1983-84 financial year. We are not far off that time. Despite being six months off it we have not had any sign of the extension of the service or any planning with the community within South Australia.
—No one is watching it.

—Of course no one is watching it; we have not got the station yet . The fact is that there is community support for the station. The community has shown that it can be involved in programming, organising and the production of a television station. But with such little time left before the extension of multicultural television to South Australia, no community participation has taken place. I placed questions on the Notice Paper in relation to this matter and have still not received any answer. This is not the only aspect of participation by the community in general that we should look at. We have a very viable film industry in South Australia which has, over the last two years, put submissions to the Special Broadcasting Service in respect of films that it could produce. In this case I refer to the South Australian Film Corporation. The South Australian Film Corporation can produce films of an ethnic nature for programming. The film industry received a reply from the Executive Producer of the South Australian Film Corporation to correspondence to the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Bannon, in May 1982. The reply received from SBS was that it was not interested in contracting work out of Sydney and Melbourne. That is rather scandalous when one looks at the viable nature of the South Australian Film Corporation. It has been the leader in film production in Australia since the early 1970s and is recognised world wide as a producer of good quality films . To be rebutted with the line that there will be no contracting work out of Sydney and Melbourne is, in fact, an insult to that Corporation. This is especially so when one looks at the Federal public dollars going into the film industry. Honourable senators will note that 95 per cent of federal funding for the film industry normally ends up in Sydney and Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I come back to is that we do have the potential in South Australia to participate fully in an extended ethnic broadcasting service. To date the Government has made a very bland announcement of an extension of the service. But it has shown absolutely no public interest in involving the community, whether it be on a general administrative council level or whether it be in the area of film production, in the extension of that service.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ACHIEVEMENTS IN ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND NATURE CONSERVATION 1972- 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is an important paper. I wish to comment on certain aspects of it which touch on my area of interest. I refer to social security prosecutions. The report on the general guidelines to be adopted by the Commonwealth for prosecutions are very welcome in the light of experience in many areas but particularly in the area of social security offences or alleged offences. The document states that a major consideration is whether the public interest requires the institution of the prosecution. It states further that regard should be had in the prosecution to many factors which include the seriousness of the offence and the youth, age and so on of the offender.

We know rather more about alleged social security offenders since the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on social security prosecutions. The report particularly concentrated on the year 1978-79 when a survey was made of such prosecutions. There were 1,386 defendants, of whom 10 per cent were prosecuted for overpayments of less than $140. In Western Australia a 43-year-old married man with two children on unemployment benefit was charged with failure to disclose full time employment. He had been overpaid $2,231 and was sentenced to 270 days in prison. He gave 'financial difficulties' as the reason for his offence. Most of the offenders were, like him, male and married, half with dependent children, and their average age was 31.

I think we need to reconsider, as the report says, whether public interest required the prosecution and that man's imprisonment and the imprisonment of others like him. Repayment of such overpayments is, of course, mandatory and proper. But I think more thought needs to go into the value of imprisoning a family man for nine months. We are not the only people who have been concerned about this aspect. The Fisher committee in the United Kingdom, which inquired into the abuse of social security benefits, stated in its report in 1973:

There is not much point in fining a man or woman who is already on supplementary benefit. To send a man or woman to prison particularly if they have young children may inflict severe hardship on the whole family and reduce or destroy the prospect of getting them off social security.
A solicitor in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office is quoted in an Australian Law Reform Commission report as saying:

. . . A lot of our cases do result from our existing economic conditions and the effect that has on the people who offend against the Social Services Act . . . I am thinking of the married man, or the man with a de facto wife who has four or five kids to support and who can't manage on his salary . . . I don't see that the fine or sentence of imprisonment achieve anything, because if you fine the man all you're doing is depriving his family further and if you imprison him, you're depriving them of any form of livelihood except some other form of pension.

Of course, there have been other social security problems in this area. One could not go past the alleged social security conspiracy case of which much has been said in this place. The prosecution policy guidelines make sensible recommendations in respect of conspiracy cases. This year has seen the end of one of the most monstrous and expensive hearings of a conspiracy case that we have seen in this country, more than four years after 183 people were arrested in Sydney and after the expenditure of many millions of dollars. I expect that the guidelines are an attempt to prevent such a thing happening again, after almost $15m had been wasted on this atrocious attack on the good name of Australian pensioners of Greek origin. The guidelines, I hope, will make sure that it does not recur.

On the final day when the general conspiracy charge was dropped by the Commonwealth, the magistrate castigated the two people who had concocted the stories on which the Commonwealth's prosecution was based. They were the informant, one Chris Nakis, and ex-Detective Chief Inspector Thomas. I will come back to them. In future conspiracy charges will be laid with regard to the practical difficulties, particularly the length of the hearing involved in a trial of numerous defendants. Attention is to be directed at the persons most seriuosly implicated and the conspiracy charges limited to them. A decision on whether to prosecute must take many things into consideration. There is a list of factors which should not influence the prosecution. I hope that the Government will stick to this outline.

I am glad that some lessons have been learned from the sorry history of this four-year conspiracy case against Greek pensioners. The guidelines suggest that before a decision is made to grant an indemnity or recommend a pardon to a prospective witness alternative courses, such as trying some of the witnesses' offences, should be considered. If this had been done in respect of the informant in this conspiracy case, it would never have got out of hand. In this case the magistrate said that Nakis's credibility was 'zero or less than zero' and that would have been discovered at an early stage if he had not been so effectively protected. Of course, the driving force behind the arrests and the conspiracy case was Inspector Thomas who, the magistrate stated, had behaved with the 'highest impropriety'. In the magistrate's final statement he said:

I propose to bring the circumstances of these actions by Dectective Chief Inspector Thomas as he then was to the notice of the relevant Attorney-General with a view to proceedings being taken against former Detective Chief Inspector Thomas for conspiracy to pervert the course of justice or for perjury or for both.

I have raised this matter with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), and his representative since the Attorney has been ill, more than once since the magistrate made these remarks on 7 June last. I raise it now in the context of these guidelines because I question the wisdom and propriety of any prosecution decision being made by an office which has worked closely over several years with the ex-Detective Inspector as a result of which the shambles which this conspiracy case ended up in finally hit home to us. Ex-Detective Chief Inspector Thomas worked with the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office from 1977 onwards, from the earliest time that the reward for Nakis-one may remember that it was a considerable reward-was being considered. I think that a future edition of these guidelines should consider what action should be taken to give a totally objective assessment of prosecution action when a potential defendant and the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office are so closely intertwined.

The charges and the remarks made by Magistrate Brown were very serious ones. It is now six months since he made them. I repeat: He referred the case to the Attorney-General to see whether former Detective Chief Inspector Thomas should not be charged for conspiracy to pervert the course of justice or for perjury or for both. It seems to me that considerable time and considerably more care has been taken to avoid charging former Detective Chief Inspector Thomas than was ever taken in considering whether to charge the 183 people who were originally charged in this case. I think it is about time that the Government looked at its own guidelines which it has now produced to see whether it should not take action as a result of the magistrate's very harsh words.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDICATIVE PLANNING COUNCIL FOR THE HOUSING INDUSTRY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry is additional to an earlier report which was presented to the Parliament only a short time ago. The report updates the assessments that were made by the Council in that earlier report which was designed, of course, to have regard to the problems facing the building industry in the current financial year. As the report itself says, the forecasts reflect new data and major developments occurring since the preparation of the annual report. The report is concerned largely with the Government's approach to the housing industry arising out of the 1982-83 Budget.

I believe the Council is to be commended because of the initiative it had taken to prepare and publish an additional report to take account of the Fraser Government's housing initiatives-or should I say lack of housing initiatives- announced in the Budget. However, these initiatives, limited as they were because there was again a substantial inadequacy in respect of funds of housing, have been overtaken by the rather dramatic deterioration in the general economic conditions in the country. Of course, this depressed state of the economy has had a dramatic effect on the already depressed housing industry. As the Council itself remarks in a letter to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Peacock , it has to take into account the current deterioration in economic conditions and prospects and that this has had a substantial bearing on the Council's forecasts. The Council has taken the step of making available a supplementary report to the Parliament.

I want to make a very brief reference to some comments which probably have some bearing even though from time to time the Fraser-Howard Administration seeks to dissociate itself from the Treasury. I keep reminding myself of the statements made by the head of the Treasury, Mr Stone, who from time to time has criticised the amount of both public and private investment in housing in Australia. He has made the suggestion, which I find remarkable and unacceptable, that we are spending too much money in this country in providing accommodation for our citizens. This is a view which certainly the Australian Labor Party will have no truck with and repudiates. One of the features of the policies being pursued by the Fraser-Howard Administration is the degree to which funds for housing, particularly public housing, have been reduced in the seven years of the Fraser Government. The very acute problems associated with housing finance, particularly in regard to interest rates which have increased by almost 50 per cent in recent years, have had a disastrous effect upon the housing and construction industry generally. There is a tremendous housing shortage in this country and interest rates are inhibiting the ability of people to become part of the home owning process.

What are the major conclusions in this report? The report shows that there has been a drop of 17 per cent in total dwelling commencements-that is, from 133,000 in 1981-82 to 110,800 in 1982-83. This is on top of a fall in commencements of 11 per cent in the previous year. There has been a drop in private house commencements of 3 per cent and a drop in 'other' private dwelling commencements -as referred to in the report-of some 35 per cent. That section in the report deals with flats and townhouses, both of which are important supplements in providing for the housing problems facing our country and both of which are popular forms of housing accommodation for many of our citizens. There has been a slight rise in public sector construction, however, which in no way comes near to countering the private sector decline. The recent decision of the Government to make available $100m will have a minor effect upon this whole housing crisis which we are facing in this country.

The report indicates that the States hardest hit are New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia. So, of course the report has regard not to party politics but to where the problems exist. It shows clearly that they flow from the disastrous economic policies being pursued by the Fraser Government. In the area of housing finance it is expected that the total amount loaned for housing in 1982 will actually increase but that the number of loans will decrease. We cannot be in any way satisfied with that nor can this Government be complacent about the way in which its economic policies are working. Those policies are just not working. They are affecting one of the most vital industries in this country-the housing and construction industry which has not only a responsibility to provide accommodation but also the capacity to get some regenerative processes within the Australian economy.
The dwelling prospects are dealt with in the report on pages 8, 9 and 10. In summary the report says:

The housing industry entered 1982-83 with dwelling commencements estimated to be running at the lowest quarterly level since 1978. The available information suggests this low level of activity persisted into the December quarter 1982.

Of course, the evidence has shown that that projection in this supplementary report has been borne out. The need is, therefore, for a response by the Commonwealth Government if it is to put into effect its policies of governing for all of the people. A decline such as this in the housing industry demands a response from a responsible government. We know, as the Government's policy is tied in with the monetarist policies which are disastrous in so many other countries, that there is no chance of any satisfactory response from the Fraser administration. The public housing measures announced this week by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney-using funds which are supposed to come from the proposed wage pause-are not that response which is needed. We need a lot more than that.

Labor, of course, welcomes the boost of funds to the public sector housing industry. In fact we have argued that in both the House of Representatives-it has been argued by Mr Hayden, Mr Uren and others-and in the Senate where I have advocated it. We say, however, that the Government has left it a bit late to recognise the value of public funds for housing. It has ensured that real payments to the States for housing will not solve the problem because there has been this substantial dramatic drop in payments during the Fraser Government's term of office. In 1974-75, for example, real net payments to the States for housing were, in 1982 constant prices, $652.2m. In the current year, apart from that extra $100m which has been allocated, the amount of money that is available is $103.6m. This shows the dramatic decline in Commonwealth contributions to public housing. Clearly, the Commonwealth Government has allowed the housing industry to decline in a manner that even its own advisory committee has been forced to outline in its original report and now in this latest report. If this Government were really concerned it would go about stimulating the housing industry, not only giving assistance to the private sector but also pursuing policies which would assist the public and the private sectors to make their contributions to housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I will speak very briefly to the 1981-82 annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission. It reports a deficit of $73.6m which is worse by $ 10m on the deficit of the previous year. The Chairman's report notes that this result is a reversal of what has happened in previous years when there has been a slight reduction in the operating loss each year. But there has always been a very great loss from this most inefficient organisation and this is a matter of very great concern to me. Quite simply, it means that taxpayers are being bled for a grossly inefficient operation that the Government should not be in at all.

For the 4 1/2 years that I have been a senator, I have served on the Estimates committees that have dealt with the present Department of Transport and Construction and operations of this body have come before us. I am rather nauseated by the platitudinous statement in the Chairman's report which follows the same line of reasoning that we get every year. The Chairman states:
The Commission has entered into the new financial year determined to pursue its task of becoming a well activated and dynamic commercial enterprise . . .
Really! We are interested in performance, not platitudes. The Commission has had more than enough chance to demonstrate its commercial abilities.

This year's loss-$73.6m-is very great. Looking at the operations of this body over a period, I believe that it is quite obvious that management makes no attempt at all to control its outgoings; it makes no attempt to balance the input for those outgoings and to run in a normal commercial way. This year, the Commonwealth has provided $68.2m by way of subsidy to go part way towards meeting that loss. The rest will be carried forward as an accumulated debit.

The importance of this attitude is illustrated by this comparison: The Australian Government and the Australian community demand that the airlines pay their way. We have the cost recovery doctrine for air navigation charges and all the rest of it. Anyone who flies on an Australian airline or anyone who ships freight on an Australian airline pays the true cost for the service. I do not see why Australians who use airlines have to operate on a different financial base from those who wish to use rail travel. In fairness to Australian National Railways there is nothing different about its operation from any other railway in Australia. The State operations are every bit as inefficient and incompetent as the Federal one. The only thing that the Australian National Railways has done is to establish for itself an accumulated provision for long service leave of $25.3m, a superannuation provision of $24.997m and about $50m for its own welfare. However, there is but scant recognition of the needs of the shareholders of this company who are, of course, the people of Australia. I think it is time that the Commonwealth withdrew support for the Australian National Railways Commission and allowed the market to sort out this inefficient operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not join Senator MacGibbon in castigating the Australian National Railways Commission. I think each year the honourable senator castigates the Commission. I have done that on other occasions in respect of parts of its report but not in the in-depth way in which the honourable senator has done it. It is all very well to stand up in this place and to criticise the Commission and its report, and sit down without offering any alternative, only saying that we ought to let the market place solve the problems. Senator MacGibbon does not realise that the railways are here as a service to the people-in particular, the farming community. I do not know how much farmers would have to pay to cart their produce, superphosphate and every fuel that they have to use if we abolished the present railways structure and turned the Commission over to the whims of private enterprise. Not too many farmers in outlying areas of Australia would be able to operate at the charges that would be imposed on them by private enterprise. The Australian railways, be they the Australian National Railways or the State railways, give a service to the community. We should not be worried too much about whether those services run at a profit or a loss, as long as they provide the service and keep people on the land.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon should take cognisance of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill, passed by the Senate just this week. That legislation will contribute millions and millions of dollars towards the construction of roads for private transport. Nothing is ever said about the cost of that. Yet the railways incur losses because they have to construct and maintain all their own permanent ways; there is no contribution through direct grants by way of legislation passed here. That is shown up in their profit and loss accounts every year. So, in my view the railways are doing a sterling job. Instead of criticising them for having losses every year we ought to be doing all we can to support them and not just give a lot of support to private enterprise. Some mention is made of that in the report.

At least one thing can be said for the railways, be they State or Federal: They pay their employees award wages and provide them with decent working standards. That cannot be said of private trucking operations. Some of the drivers on these trucks, working for private enterprise, do not see a bed for months on end. They sleep in their cabins and work all sorts of hours. At least the railways are miles ahead of these operators, who exploit their employees.

I am also disturbed by a report published in the Australian yesterday. We see the heading: 'Pay rises push ANR losses up by $10m'. Of course, that is completely misleading. The ANR report shows that pay rises were responsible for about $6.1m but a lot of that was taken up in restrospective payments-wage and salary adjustments-which go back a long time. People reading the article in the Australian would think that the whole loss of $10m, which Senator MacGibbon referred to, was taken up in wage payments. That is not so. We have to realise that a lot of that $6.1m mentioned in the report comes back into the Treasury by way of taxation on wages. It comes from the pay-as-you-earn workers, who always pay their tax. Those whom Senator MacGibbon supports, the bottom-of-the-harbour people, do not pay any tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not refer to that matter when dealing with this report.

—A lot of people on the Government side supported the bottom-of- the-harbour people during the debate on the taxation Bills and advocated that they not pay any tax at all. They supported these people as much as they could. We saw those on the other side fighting, day after day, to protect their private interests.
—Stick to the report.

—I am sticking to the report. I am saying that a lot of this $6. 1m incurred by way of retrospective wage payments to railway employees comes back into the Treasury by way of tax paid by those people. They cannot avoid it. The other thing in this report that I want to mention is that Mr Ralph Taylor, a foundation member and national secretary of the Australian Railways Union, resigned from the Commission in July 1981. The Commission records its thanks for his splendid contribution and wise counsel. I am sure that all colleagues of mine on this side of the House will join with the Commission in those words of thanks.
—And so do I, Senator.

—I am very pleased that Senator Rae has said that he does, too. The resignation of Ralph Taylor will be a great loss to the Commission. Although we are under time restraints, I want to congratulate the Commission for at last doing something about a computerised passenger booking system. I have said in this Parliament on many occasions that the passenger service operated by ANR has been underutilised because of the archaic way of allocating seats.
—It was a conscious policy.

—It was a conscious policy. I want to read a part of the report under the heading 'Computerised Passenger Booking System'. It states: Earlier plans for an 'in-house' developed computerised passenger booking system for Australian National were abandoned in favour of an established system. With a view to eventually achieving the compatability required for a nationwide booking scheme this system should be operational in the 1982/83 period.

SPEECH.PARA: Initiatives by Australian National have resulted in discussions at Railways of Australia (ROA) level concerning the requirements for a nationwide system. These discussions are continuing and it is anticipated that the prevalent problems of under-utilisation of train accommodation will be reduced once a computerised system is implemented.

I hope that that computerised system is implemented as quickly as possible. As I have said before in the Parliament, I have travelled on railways in other parts of the world. I think the passenger service run by ANR is second to none: It cannot be bettered by any other system in the world. We always hear about the Canadian passenger trains over the Rockies, but their service cannot compare with that offered by ANR.
There is another reference in the report to road transport and the reduction in the workload of ANR. The report states:

The reduction in cattle van numbers was caused by an overall reduction in the cattle population in South Australia plus very heavy road competition on the Marree line and the South Eastern areas of South Australia.
The report also states:
The reduction in sheep van numbers was caused by heavy road competition.

As I said earlier, the Government is making money available to construct roads for these great juggernauts to travel on. They compete with a semi-governmental enterprise, the Australian Railways Commission. They are taking work and revenue away from the Commission; and yet senators criticise the Commission because it cannot show a profit.

I am very pleased that Senator Peter Rae is in the chamber because this is one report that he will not be able to criticise for being late. The Commission ought to be congratulated because this report is right on time. Looking through the report I noted a photograph of the opening of the Loxton Freight Centre in June. That shows how up to date this report is. One person would be most disappointed with the report. Whilst he positioned himself at the opening of that freight centre to have his photograph taken I see that the Commission, in its wisdom, cut him out of the photograph. He was not supposed to be on the platform. I said to him at the opening: 'You are a shrewd politician going up there to have your photograph taken'. But the Commission, in its widom, deleted his photograph from the report. I think the Commission did a very good thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to intrude for one or two moments to comment on the annual report of Australian National Railways Commission. I think it is fair to suggest that Australian National, in common with other businesses and industries throughout Australia, has suffered as a result of a significant increase in salaries. I do not think we can ignore that. In fact, these increases accounted for approximately $6.1m, which indicated an average railway wage increase of about 18 per cent-a lot more than Australian National estimated it to be. We have to have regard to that fact. It is a significant matter. The wages pause that we are to deal with will be reflected in a better report, I hope, next year. Part of Australian National's deficit was due to the fact that industrial disputes cost it some $3.5m last year. This was mainly due to the activities of Transport Workers Union members in July and August 1981. As the report notes, very little was due to the action of Australian National staff.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that has to be borne in mind is the effect that drought has on Australian National freight. I think Senator McLaren mentioned that point. In fact the grain tonnage moved in 1981-82 was 18 per cent below that recorded in the previous year. Livestock movements also decreased and as a result revenue dropped by approximately $16m. I believe we will see an increase in coal transportation as a result of the new power station being built in Port Augusta. I hope this will be reflected in a better situation next year. However, I pay tribute to the general manager, Don Williams, and his senior officers for the work that they are doing to try to overcome these tremendous difficulties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

During the discussions at the seminar, I dare say that the Australia-United States Bilateral Agreement on Co-operation on Anti-Trust Matters was discussed. I have some criticism of that agreement. After the agreement was signed, various articles in the Australian Press pointed out that it had definite limitations for Australian interests. Australia has agreed to provide the United States with confidential information on any new export policies that it may adopt in the future which might violate United States anti-trust laws. Also, the Federal Government undertook to adopt a more co-operative approach to United States court subpoenas for documents within Australia.

The commitments are the quid pro quo for a restricted agreement by the United States Justice Department to intervene in future private anti-trust actions against Australian companies. As was pointed out in an article in the Australian Financial Review in June, the agreement provides that the Australian information is to be treated confidentially in Washington but it provides no guarantee that the United States Justice Department will not prosecute if it feels the policy violates United States anti-trust laws. In return, the United States Government has agreed that it may intervene in some private anti-trust cases against Australian companies if it sees fit. The question of intervention will be decided on by the United States Government after consultations with Australian officials.

If a case such as the Westinghouse Corporation anti-trust case had taken place since the agreement, the agreement supposedly would offer protection to Australian companies. I dare say that it does offer some type of protection-it certainly does not substitute for a clawback Bill going through this Senate, something that has been lying in the Attorney-General's Department for goodness knows how long. When the Westinghouse case was determined, we found that although, according to the law, Westinghouse was well enough protected, nevertheless it settled out of court. The fact that Westinghouse settled out of court shows that the existing law obviously did not offer sufficient protection for Westinghouse to decide not to settle out of court. It settled out of court, and therefore I am urging that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) take another look at the clawback legislation, look at such legislation in Europe, the United Kingdom and elsewhere and do something about chasing it along. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so, I wonder sometimes why the Family Law Council bothers-the Council itself must wonders why it bothers-to produce reports of this kind. This is the sixth in the series. Like its predecessors, it is chock-full of useful analysis as to how the system works and is not working and of proposals for amendment of the law in the numerous areas in which it has now become obvious that is necessary. But here, as in so many other areas of the administration of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), the administration of the law has been lethargic in the extreme. Years go by; nothing happens. With each passing year of inactivity, the Family Law Council wearily saddles up again and produces reports of this kind, but as each successive 12-month period draws to its close again it finds itself with very little to applaud in terms of what has actually happened.

Let me give four examples of areas in which activity which ought to be taking place is not taking place. The first and most obvious of them is the amendments to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981 which were proposed in this place over 12 months ago. It is an absolute disgrace that in the 12 months that have elapsed there has been no more than three hours of debate on this Bill in the chamber and the Bill has simply kept on disappearing from the Notice Paper. Powerful lobby groups seem to have no difficulty at all in getting speedy results. But thousands of individuals are affected by anomalies and difficulties in the way the Family Law Act is presently operating, not as to its fundamentals-because I see Senator Martyr itching to get to his feet and give us yet another diatribe on the fundamental aspects of family law legislation-but as to the procedural aspects of the way in which it in fact operates.

There are many ways in which people are being prejudiced by those anomalies. Let me indicate just briefly some of them. A wife whose husband receives superannuation some time after the divorce receives absolutely no share in that benefit. The custody of an adopted child has to be determined by the Supreme Court of a State while the custody of natural children can be determined by the Family Court. The Family Court is not obliged to take into account the wishes of children under 14 years in relation to custody matters no matter how important or obviously relevant those wishes might be. In the absence of fraud or injustice, matrimonial property orders cannot be varied even in cases where the parties agree or their financial circumstances change significantly. Under the present law a person other than the parents of a child is prevented from bringing in the Family Court proceedings for custody or guardianship, even when the welfare of the child requires it. Those are just some of the matters which are addressed in this legislation. They are manifestly of importance and it is manifestly outrageous that the Government has taken the lethargic and lackadaisical attitude it has towards the processing of that legislation.

The second example of Government lethargy in the family law area has been the fabled matrimonial property inquiry. It was announced in October 1981 in terms of the recommendation a year before of the parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. On 13 September this year Senate Estimates Committee A was told that the inquiry would not start until 1 January 1983. In fact, it now seems doubtful whether even that deadline will be met. There is a rather sordid series of undercurrents to this saga which I will not stop to retail again now. I have done so previously in this place. I simply indicate that this is another demonstration of the unwillingness of the Government to move effectively in this area.

There is also the matter of the reference of powers by the States. Time and again cases are coming to the High Court of Australia and other courts in the system involving unedifying jurisdictional disputes between the Family Court and State supreme courts, particularly in custody matters. A unified family law jurisdiction is obviously needed. One way of doing that would be by constitutional amendments, which are presently being discussed. Short of that, the Federal Government could accept a reference of powers from the States. The Labor States-particularly New South Wales and Victoria-have indicated that they are willing to make such a reference. However, negotiations have been dragging on for years. The present Government seems utterly unwilling to bring this matter to a sensible conclusion. In the process, of course, it is causing hardship and distress to many people.

Finally, there is the saga, which I mention briefly again, of the United Nations Convention for Recovery Abroad of Maintenance. In 1977 interdepartmental consultations were completed concerning the legal formalities necessary to enable the performance of Australian obligations under the Convention governing the recovery abroad of maintenance. Five and a half years later-now nearly six years later-it appears that the implementation of that Convention is no closer to fruition. There are many illustrations of both a general and a specific kind that one could adduce as to the continuing neglect and incompetence of this Government when it comes to family law administration. I only hope that when the next Family Law Council report is put down in this place there will be something better and more constructive to report. I suspect that will only be the case after the election of a Labor government, as the Australian Labor Party is genuinely committed to getting some rational and effective reform in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, that windy but personally pleasant prophet, correctly says that I will again take up fundamentals, but I will do so only briefly. The Family Law Council's annual report once again shows how effectively marriage as an institution is being destroyed in Australia. The Family Law Council has done nothing and will, I suggest, do nothing to stabilise and preserve marriage; neither will its slave organisation, the Institute of Family Studies. I think both bodies should be abolished and replaced with a continuing joint committee of this Parliament. The simple reason for that contention is that I believe lifetime marriage to one person is still the cornerstone of the family and therefore our society. I submit that nothing less than Parliament, the law giver, is worthy of handling the vital matter of marriage and the family. The stability of marriage and the family is the basic answer to many of the domestic and social security problems that Senator Grimes spoke of before. These matters are frequently raised by others in this Parliament. It seems to me that until Parliament grasps this nettle we will have continuing difficulties in this area. We cannot expect bodies-even though they are judicially appointed-which are outside and not connected with this Parliament to have the absolutely fundamental application that is necessary to solve this problem of the breakdown of marriage which, as I have said, is the cornerstone of our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — In adding to what Senator Martyr has said, I believe that the tragedy of divorce shows up in statistics of children affected by divorce. These are indicated in the table shown on page 17 of the Family Law Council annual report. It is very sobering indeed to read of the enormous number of children who are affected by divorce. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that well over 300,000 children have now been affected by divorce since the Family Law Act came into operation in 1975. I believe that is an indictment of the provisions of that legislation. I and a number of other honourable senators will take the opportunity early next year-when amendments to the Family Law Act come before this Parliament-to put down other amendments which will be designed to strengthen marriage and give greater protection to innocent victims of divorce.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report on Insurance Contracts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report by the Australian Law Reform Commission deals with insurance contracts. One of the minor miracles in this country is the way in which the Commission, despite its starved resources, despite the indifference and indeed even sometimes hostility with which its recommendations are greeted by the present Government, nonetheless continues to produce reports of outstanding quality, wide in reach and great in depth and enormous in the credibility and respect that they have been able to generate from professionals in all the fields with which those reports have dealt. I think it is a great tribute to the fortitude, industry and capacity of the members of the Law Reform Commission and particularly, of course, its indefatigable chairman, Mr Justice Kirby, that this should be so. Another splendid demonstration of the quality of the Commission and its reports is this report on insurance contracts. This 350-page document, which contains numerous recommendations aimed at completely overhauling and updating the law of insurance, is now brought before us.

There is no time in the 30 seconds which I think remains available to me in this debate to canvass in any way the substance of those recommendations. Suffice to say that they are far-reaching and they deserve immediate legislative attention by the Government. I simply hope that these recommendations, and the report as a whole, will meet a better fate than that which was meted out by the Government to the earlier report of the Commission on insurance agents and brokers which, it will be remembered, attracted the support of the Senate in private members' legislation but which so far has been treated by the Government with contempt and a complete refusal to legislate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement concerning the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

On 23 November the Committee presented its first report to the Senate covering the demand for and supply of power for Tasmania, the significance of the archaeological discoveries near the Franklin River and the Commonwealth's obligations and powers in relation to South West Tasmania.
The terms of reference of the inquiry are:
(a) The natural values of South West Tasmania to Australia and the world; and

(b) Federal responsibility in assisting Tasmania to preserve its wilderness areas of national and international importance, including appropriate financial assistance consistent with the State's development needs and options for the State's energy requirements.
There are a number of matters within the terms of reference on which the Committee has yet to report. At a recent meeting, the Committee resolved that it will continue to examine:
(a) The natural values of South West Tasmania; and
(b) the environmental effects of the electricity supply options.

The Committee also resolved to establish a sub-committee consisting of Senators Archer, Coates and Primmer to examine other land uses, such as mining, forestry, tourism and recreation, which may affect the preservation of Tasmania's wilderness areas of national and international importance.
As much of the information on these matters has already been obtained, the Committee expects to present its second report to the Senate by April 1983.

(1) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce has completed its Report on the Development of the Australian Fishing Industry-
(a) the Committee may send the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act due to illness or other cause, to the Deputy President;
(b) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate and the President or the Deputy President be authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation; and
(c) in such event, the President or the Deputy President lay the report upon the table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1982BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982BROADCASTING TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 December, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these Bills. But we believe that they could be improved in some ways. That matter can be dealt with at the Committee stage. I begin by explaining essentially what the Bills do. Firstly, they introduce supplementary licences for television and amend the existing provisions which have not yet been used in the Broadcasting and Television Act in relation to so-called supplementary licences for radio. Secondly, they increase the maximum size of the membership of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal from five to eight. That is not a matter of any contention. A supplementary licence, which is what the Bills refer to, is one granted in the same area to an existing licensee of a television or radio station. It is not subject to the normal ownership and control provisions; that is, for the purposes of the ownership and control provisions it would be seen as being one with the existing licence held by a commercial operator for those purposes. The legislation does not apply to the five mainland State capitals. No supplementary licences will be available for commercial radio and television licence holders in any of the five major capitals on the mainland.
