SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides that the supplementary licences for radio must be FM licences and for television they should be either for UHF or VHF. Radiated subscription services are permitted. This means that, potentially, a total of 99 commercial FM radio services and 36 commercial television services could be established under the provision of this legislation, in addition to what is currently available. The important thing about this legislation is that it is designed to provide additional services and, it is hoped, additional choice predominantly in provincial areas of Australia. That is a very important objective with which the Opposition concurs. There is no reason why the four million Australians who live in these areas-other than of course for important cost reasons that have applied very significantly in the past-should not have available to them the same sort of services and the same choice of services as those who live in the metropolitan areas. I regard that as a desirable objective which should be sought by governments and which, in a sense, this legislation is a step towards.

I want to say at the outset that we think that there is a very important policy consideration in this legislation, and the policy consideration is to get new services into the regions and to maintain local content elements in both an Australian sense and a regional sense. That is to say that the contributions which television and radio stations make to local communities should be continued and, if possible, enhanced and those regional and television operators who provide those services should not be swamped by networks operating out of the major capital cities because they provide some diversity, some choice and additional opportunity, which is a very important factor. I think it is important again to make the point that we are talking about commercial radio and television services only. Other ways exist of providing additional services for regional areas in Australia. The Australian Broadcasting Commission could provide additional services, particularly in radio, by the development of a second radio network. Public broadcasting licences could be offered to regions on a more extensive basis than they have been in the past. The development of new commercial services is not the only way of attaining the desired object of getting new services into the regions and maintaining, as far as possible, local contributions which are relevant to the local community as distinct from the contributions which may come from the networks.

I might say, in passing, that much of the argument about the provision of supplementary licences arose out of apprehension that the satellite would be used in the not too distant future for the provision of networking across Australia by direct broadcasting and that that would debilitate against the interests of regional operators of television and radio stations. I want to make it quite clear that while the satellite has many attractive uses, it would not be attractive to the Opposition to see regional radio and television operators inhibited or destroyed by the operation of network services across Australia because of the localism provision and because of the community services that they can offer at the local level.

As I say, the intent of this Bill, which we applaud, is to get new services into the country areas. But the legislation in some ways, because it considers only commercial licences, does not take into account the broadcasting system as a whole. If new services cannot be obtained by the commercial sector, then it may be that public or national broadcasting services could be offered to provide additional choice and additional local or regional input into programming.

I said that the legislation deals with supplementary licences. That means that it creates licences for services as distinct from the existing system of licences for transmissions. The effect of that in simple terms is to offer existing television and radio operators in the regions a supplementary licence which entitles them to provide for local consumers a second and alternative level of programming to that which they already provide. If a local television station obtains a supplementary licence it will have two sets of programming going. It is to be hoped that that will provide additional choice. The same sort of thing can be said about local commercial radio operators.

Under the existing Broadcasting and Television Act there are procedures for dealing with applications for licences. This legislation provides some new procedures in relation to supplementary licences. In talking about the provision of new services in regional areas, I should say that there is an enormous backlog in the Department of Communications in dealing with planning matters. I am not blaming the Department for that. I am just saying that the previous Minister in an answer to a question I asked indicated that there was an enormous backlog, maybe due to staffing shortages and things of that kind. It is important that that be considered or borne in mind when we consider the method of applying for new licences and the delays which have been occurring in recent years.

Two notions have governed on a bipartisan basis the development of broadcasting in Australia. They have been accepted since the Broadcasting Control Board was established in 1935. The first notion is simply that local content on regional or local television and radio stations is desirable. The second important notion , which I think this legislation recognises, is the so-called test of viability. It is no good establishing a proliferation of broadcasting stations if they are not going to be viable, that is to say, profitable. If they are not profitable they will not produce good programs and good services and ultimately will lower the standards rather than improve the standards of choice and programming available to consumers in particular areas. The notions of viability and of localism are very important in developing or approaching the whole question of broadcasting services and overall policy considerations in that development.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same argument can be used against cable television.

—Yes. Senator Tate points that the same argument can be advanced against the introduction of cable television into Australia. The legislation provides procedures whereby supplementary licences can be obtaind. The essence of those procedures is that an existing licensee applies to the Minister for a single supplementary licence. I make the point that under the legislation a consortium of licensees serving the same area may also apply. That is a very important consideration in relation to the amendments which the Opposition will be moving to this legislation because it is relevant to the question of viability. For example, in a single station radio market there may not be an independent operator who can viably and successfully operate an independent licence. But it may be that a consortium of licensees serving the same area could do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I indicated that the Opposition generally approves of the legislation before the Senate which deals with supplementary licences for regional broadcasting and television stations. We approve of the legislation because it is a method of providing additional services to communities which have largely been dependent on one television service and one radio service in the commercial area. This legislation opens up the prospect of additional services being provided. I again emphasise that it is the commercial sector about which we are talking.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other ways in which governments can provide additional services, whether by provision of public broadcasting licences or by provision of an Australian Broadcasting Commission second network in radio-a course which the Opposition advocates. But, insofar as commercial services are concerned, the rationale behind this legislation is that in many markets it would not be possible for new independent operators to establish themselves in competition with existing operators and gain sufficient advertising revenue on a local basis or on a wider basis to make the new independent operator viable. In other words, there is insufficient advertising revenue in many of these markets to support two radio stations or television stations. The solution provided by the Government in this legislation is to suggest that the existing operators should have supplementary licences not only because a lot less cost is involved but also because they would not be competing for advertising revenue with existing operators.

There are two important notions in this legislation. The first is the importance of providing additional services to regional communities. The second is the notion of the importance of local content, an argument about which there is a lot to be said on both sides but which I do not want to go into now. Of course, there is the third point that the legislation enshrines the principle of viability which is inherent, I think, in both parties in the sense that it is desirable that all stations operating in these markets should be profitable and, if they are not profitable, they will not provide a good service for the community concerned. Supplementary licence legislation is a device, if one likes , to deal with that situation. It seems to me to be a sensible device. When one talks about the so-called principle or importance of viability of radio and television stations, I record in passing that it is a matter of regret that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal completely abandoned that test of viability, if one likes, in its report on cable and radiated subscription television services. I hope the Government, in its response to that report, will take account of that departure from long-standing broadcasting policy.

I want to say one other thing in general at this stage of the discussion which I will deal with in greater detail at the time when this Bill is is debated in Committee. It is simply this: As far as possible, the Opposition's view on broadcasting policy is that one should consider all the parts together in terms of provision of community services and that governments should be responsible for the structure and the regulatory mechanisms. Within that context, in the commercial sector there should be as much freedom as possible to develop new services whether they be in the form of supplementary services or whether they be in the form of competitive services. That is so. It is desirable that as far as possible people be placed on an equal footing. Two of the amendments the Opposition will be moving go to that very question; the need to place a potential independent applicant on the same footing as an existing licence holder in respect of starting proceedings to determine whether a new service is desirable and what form that service should take.

I think it very important to remember the second set of amendments which the Opposition will be moving in the Committee stage, relating to the concentration of ownership in a particular area. We do not think that in a town-let me take a hypothetical town which I will call 'Og', and I do not want to offend any of those proprietors out there-where one person owns the radio station, the television station and the newspaper, it is right for that person to be offered an additional radio or television licence to the exclusion of anybody else. Instead of having three media outlets in a town controlled by one person or one company, under this legislation as it presently stands one could have four media outlets controlled by one person or one company.

I have referred to the mythical town of Og. Such towns exist in Australia, where the entire local media-if I may call it that-are in the hands of one proprietor or company. It is not right, in our view, to extend the supplementary licence concession in that situation. It is undesirable that that happen. Independent operators should be invited, in that circumstance, to establish an alternative media outlet in the town of Og. If no independent operator is prepared to do that, that community should not necessarily be deprived of an additional service; the additional service could be provided in another way, by looking at other areas of the broadcasting spectrum. The service could be provided by the Australian Broadcasting Commission, by a public broadcasting licence, or by another commercial operator operating in a contiguous region seeking an independent licence in that area and operating both areas on a regional basis. We think that is desirable. I guess we have been listening to the free enterprise rhetoric of this Government for too long. It has suddenly been abandoned with this legislation. Like all other aspects of free enterprise in Australia, everybody is in favour of it until it gets a bit hot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just when you were being persuaded.

—Surprising as it may seem to Senator Missen, I have always been a mixed economy man. I think that in regard to the private enterprise aspect of the economy there is much to be said for the provision of competitive services in a situation such as I have been describing.

SPEECH.PARA: Our views on concentration of media ownership in a particular region are nothing new. The effects of concentration of media ownership are potentially that the consumers in that region really have only a very limited choice of programming, programming style or content. The second consequence of an undue concentration of media ownership in a town is the effect on business, because commercial media is sponsored and supported by advertising. Business in a one market town where the proprietor owns all the media outlets do not have available to them a choice as to where they take their advertising. That is very important, both in terms of competitive prices and, perhaps, of an alternative approach to advertising content.

The views of the Opposition on this matter have guided governments of both political persuasions since 1935. I notice that the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown), when this legislation was debated in the House of Representatives said that it would be very difficult for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to determine what 'media' meant in this context. He said that members of the Tribunal would really have to put their thinking caps on to define what 'media' meant. With respect to the Minister, that is a statement made out of sheer ignorance. In this place ignorance in debates is sometimes bliss but statements such as that should not be uttered so blissfully by a Minister. The Broadcasting Tribunal has already dealt with these issues.

Prior to the amendments relating to public interest in 1981 the Broadcasting Tribunal in the Townsville case and in the 2HD case, and to some extent in the Hardiman's case, had dealt with the question of cross-ownership of media and expressed concern about the undesirability of cross-ownership of media in a particularly concentrated market. I mention these matters because there is a need for consistency in broadcasting policy in Australia. I have said that before. I do not wish to make a repetitive charge but one of the saddest things about this Government in relation to communications policy is that in seven years it has had no communications policy. I heard the Minister in Melbourne a month or two ago make a plaintive plea that perhaps the Broadcasting Tribunal assist the Government in developing a broadcasting policy for Australia. That is not the function of the Tribunal. We should all be very grateful for that after reading its report on cable television. That is the function of government. It is sad that the Government has no consistent policy on broadcasting. In our view the development of a policy in broadcasting basically involves the development of the sorts of criteria which have guided broadcasting administrative bodies for a long period and adapting those criteria in the light of changing technology and the development of new technology. That is not a task beyond the wit of man but it seems to be beyond the wit of the present Government.

I conclude by saying that we support the broad thrust of the legislation. We think it is a device for providing additional services to regional communities. It is a device which is based on the notion of the desirability of the viability of broadcasting and television stations and a device which recognises the important principle of localism. It is a device which has been developed and spurred on, as it were, by new technology in a sense in the threats which were perceived as a result of the development of satellite technology. From our point of view, because it does have regard to those factors which I have mentioned- local content, viability, importance of broadcasting services in a regional community and the need to provide additional services-it has our basic support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and associated Bills. They provide for amendments to the broadcasting and television legislation so that the Government's decisions on supplementary licences can be implemented. Speaking generally, the Government is providing, particularly to country areas, additional services and programs, which have been needed for many years. The Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) in his second reading speech on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill in the other place said:

SPEECH.PARA: A constant source of complaint over many years by people in country and regional areas has been the imbalance in broadcasting and television services available in those areas when compared with the five mainland State capital cities. Apart from national services, these people often have access to only one commercial broadcasting service and one commercial television service.

Most Australians would agree that it is undesirable that there should be monopolistic situations such as this, where they can be avoided. In so far as this legislation helps to widen the field of choice for people who wish to watch television and listen to radio, it is good. The Minister further said:
A major difficulty in attempting to redress the balance has been the inability of many of these areas to support fully competitive stations without endangering the viability of existing services.

I think this comes very much to the principles about which Senator Button was speaking with which we must have general agreement. Two things must be considered. One is the viability of another station to operate. If we had two stations operating poorly, employing poor and cheap services and not giving citizens the opportunity to hear and see things I think we would have failed in our purpose. So viability certainly is essential. The second thing to be considered is an expression of localism-the need to provide services that have a particular relationship to a locality and which cater for the interests of the people in that district. That is another thing that this legislation provides.
There is provision in the Bill, of course, for supplementary licences to be offered to existing holders. The Minister, in his second reading speech, also said:
Once the Tribunal receives an application from the Minister-
That is, an application which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has to consider-

it may conduct a public inquiry into the grant of the supplementary licence, and must determine whether an idependent commercial licence would be viable in that area, and if so, whether it would be in the public interest, on certain specified grounds, to invite applications for such a licence.

That is excellent. But honourable senators will notice that once the Tribunal receives the application there is a problem. I will have something to say about this problem later. An existing licence holder may decide to avoid competition by not applying for an additional FM licence and thereby deprive other people of the opportunity of seeking to obtain a separate commercial licence in the area. There has been some discussion and correspondence between me and the Minister on this subject in regard to constituents of mine over some years.

It seems to me that the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill certainly should be supported. Sometimes the initial criticisms which are made are not justified. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am Chairman, brought the situation up to date in its twentieth report in respect of the criticisms which it made when the Bill was first sighted. It was the feeling of the Committee that substantial discretions were left with the Minister in determining matters, such as whether he would refer an application to the Tribunal, dismiss it on technical grounds and so forth. The Committee queried this extensive power. The Committee's twentieth report, which I invite honourable senators to look at, records the substantial reply from the Minister indicating the history which these powers have undergone and the extent to which previous reports, such as the Green report on the structure of the Australian broadcasting system and associated matters and the actions of the Broadcasting Council indicate the necessity for those powers. I am quite satisfied that the criticisms raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee have been met in the answer which the Minister has given.

I turn now to one matter that has concerned me to which, likewise, I have received a substantial answer today which I hope will be helpful to those people involved. I have been concerned for some years to press the desire by some of my constituents, who come not from the legendary city of Og but from the very real city of Mildura, to break into the radio monopoly and get a licence for another station there. Licences for most of the other forms of communication in that area are held by one particular group. These people have been frustrated over many years. I have spoken at some length on this subject in adjournment debates in the Parliament and have urged action by a succession of Ministers so that they would have the opportunity of seeking a separate licence, appearing before the Tribunal and being heard. When the Bill was first introduced their reaction to it and my reaction was that it did not offer very much more hope for them. The people applying for the particular grant-the Mildura News Group Pty Ltd-said to me in a letter dated 26 November that they were concerned that existing licence holders might not apply. The letter states.
We are concerned that there are no positive steps to have a public hearing in Mildura, if the existing operator does not, as is likely, apply for a supplementary licence.
Why would he in an area, one of the few in Australia, apply for a supplementary licence, when he knows there will be strong opposition . . .

Also, it is obvious that areas where there has been no concern for FM broadcasting and no likely opposition, will get a service on the air, under the supplementary system, many months, perhaps years, ahead of an area such as Mildura where debate will eventuate and an expression of interest and documentation from the community has been before the Minister for nearly four years.
In other words, why should Mildura not have some priority over areas where there has been no interest shown, once legislation is passed.

So there was a concern that the Mildura News Group might not get to first base because there might not be an application from the existing holders and, therefore, the matter may never be referred to the Tribunal and the whole examination, as to whether there was room for a separate licence, conducted. Also, there was a feeling that those who had been trying for years to get a licence might be superseded in the rush for licences. There are many applications to be considered and many areas have an interest. Consequently, I wrote to the Minister for Communications and complained in similar terms to those of the letter from the Mildura News Group. I received a reply from the Minister today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most timely, actually.
—It is a most timely and encouraging reply to my complaint. I would like to read the Minister's letter to me of 16 December 1982. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: You wrote to me on 29 November 1982, concerning the supplementary licence legislation, and the Mildura News Group's desire to establish an independent station in Mildura.

Your concern relates to the fact that the legislation does not provide a guarantee that the Minister will invite applications for an independent licence in any area where the existing licensee does not express interest in a supplementary licence.

My intention is to invite applications pursuant to Section 82 of the Broadcasting and Television Act and pursuant to my responsibilities under Sections 111C and 111D of the Act where after a nominated period, there is no expressed interest in a supplementary service, and where I have received a firm and appropriate proposal for the establishment of an independent service. As you know, the Government is introducing the supplementary licence scheme in order to increase broadcasting and television services in non-metropolitan areas.

I shall be making a statement in Parliament as soon as possible, outlining the timetable and planning procedures associated with the scheme. This statement will deal in more detail with the type of situation you describe.
I hope these comments meet your concerns on this matter.
I enclose copies of Sections 82, 111C and 111D of the Act for your convenience.

Having gone through the sections and the powers, I certainly am satisfied that the Minister seems to have the power to do what he proposes. That seems to fairly fill in this gap which otherwise might exist if present holders do not take up the offer and submit themselves for trial before the Tribunal as to whether there is room for a separate commercial licence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any reason why it should not be in the legislation, which in a sense is a charter of rights for those concerned, is it not?

—I think there could be a strong argument for saying that it might well be in the legislation. It is not, but I take the letter as a clear statement of the policy of the Minister, an indication that he will do this. I feel that, under the very strong powers that he obviously has under those sections, he will act accordingly. I do not think it makes a great deal of difference whether or not it is in the legislation. Certainly, it is a clear declaration that the Government proposes not to let this gap remain, not to do an injustice to people who have a viable proposition and can satisfy a tribunal that there is room-as I believe there is in Mildura-for additional services, people who have been trying for some time to achieve this end.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently, I warmly support the legislation for what it will do in a general way for so many communities throughout Australia. I am also pleased to see that we have now clarified some of the difficulties that otherwise would have been left unresolved. I hope that the general result of this legislation and of the declarations that the Minister has made today will be that we will have a better , fuller television and radio service in country and regional districts of Australia, that this will lead to a worthwhile improvement in those services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to hear Senator Missen raise his concern for the people of Mildura. Mildura happens also to be one of my constituencies. We also have received representations from the people of Mildura. We are, in fact, very concerned about the aspect of the Bill that Senator Missen covered so well; namely, that it takes an application from an existing licence to trigger the whole mechanism in this Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill. We have had discussions with the Department of Communications and the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown). We were assured that this problem will be overcome by the Minister in due course. I wish to elaborate on that later on in my very brief remarks concerning these two Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills are intended to allow non-metropolitan radio and television station licensees to apply for supplementary licences for additional services. The Government intends that these additional services will include FM radio. The Opposition has foreshadowed amendments designed specifically to make sure that people who are not licence holders can apply for a licence under the legislation and that no undue concentration of media ownership will occur in provincial areas. Essentially, the Government and the industry argue that in many areas an independent FM radio station or second television channel would not be viable. Senator Button covered that point. The industry and the Government argue that the choice in these areas is between services provided under a supplementary licence arrangement as we have in this Bill or no additional services at all. They argue that the additional overheads of a new station would, in many cases, render it non-viable.

The Australian Democrats find themselves in a not unfamiliar situation where we are being forced to resolve a conflict between two principles. The first is the fundamental principle that Australian communications policies should include the widest possible spread of ownership; that the ownership of our broadcasting stations should be in as many hands as possible. The second conflicting principle as we see it is that as many Australians as possible should have access to modern telecommunications and that should include FM radio. It would be idle to deny that broadcasting today, particularly in country areas, is generally experiencing very difficult times. Indeed, we have had representations from many radio station proprietors over recent months which state that they are facing the prospect of having to close down. The reasons for these problems, I think, are very obvious. The continuing depression is having its effect, particularly on rural enterprises. This, of course, affects advertising. The drought has been a very significant factor without any doubt. Finally, the continuous population drift from country areas to the cities has caused provincial radio stations and TV stations to suffer a declining market in relative terms.

One could mount a reasonable argument, we believe, to allow unfettered competition between radio stations and between TV stations. In fact, if one were to accept the logic of the Government, which is the basis behind the Davidson, Bradley and Campbell reports, it might be expected that the Government would bring in legislation that would allow, apart from assurances of certain technical viability, anybody to set up a radio station and that there would be free and unfettered competition. That is the principle that the Government never tires of preaching to us and to anybody who will listen to it. However, the Government has not adopted that principle in this legislation. We believe it is unlikely to adopt such a principle because it would probably well and truly destroy rural broadcasting.

The Australian Democrats do not accept the logic behind the Campbell, Bradley and Davidson reports. We believe in this situation that unrestricted competition could be only counterproductive and would undoubtedly represent a waste of resources. We believe, in the case of telecommunications, as in so many other fundamental areas, indicative, co-operative and national long term planning is absolutely essential. While the present broadcasting system could hardly be described as an ideal example of long term planning, we would be reluctant to be a party to destroying the present system without having first seen something put in its place.

Broadcasting planning is one of those areas which has firmly remained under political control. This Bill does nothing to change that situation. At present if an individual or an enterprise wishes to start a radio or television station, as has been pointed out, he or it must convince the Minister for Communications that a need exists in a particular area. It is then up to the Minister to exercise his prerogative and invite applications for a licence. The application is then passed on to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which determines the application after a public inquiry. We understand that many people would like to see this ministerial prerogative removed. We agree. For too long the National Party Minister has been able to exercise extraordinary patronage in areas with, we might say, breathtaking cynicism. Also, we believe these problems have not yet been completely solved by the Department, even in spite of the earnest and sincere efforts of the present Minister.

However, this Bill does partly depoliticise the supplementary licence application process because the Minister is now able to decline an application only on purely technical grounds. The Tribunal itself would then determine the application.

The first step is to decide whether an independent application is viable. If an independent application is not viable the question of the concentration of the media stops there and then; the Tribunal must reject the application. Therefore, the existing concentration of the media in that area remains. That is basic. The question then facing the Tribunal is simply a choice between having a service as it is or issuing a supplementary licence.

Senator Missen raised the problem of the mechanism to trigger the approval of a supplementary licence. As I said, it is a vice in the Bill of which the Democrats are very much aware. We have had extensive discussions on the matter. It must be made clear that the application must be made by an existing licence holder to trigger the process. If an existing licence holder has a monopoly in an area the chances are that he may not wish to issue the application and prima facie he can maintain his monopoly in that area. We are assured of two things. Firstly, competition between areas would make it very difficult for the monopolistic operator to refuse indefinitely to apply for a supplementary licence. Secondly, the Minister assured us in his second reading speech that the Government would issue guidelines for the implementation of a supplementary licence scheme as soon as possible after the legislation has been passed by the Parliament. Why must we have to wait until this legislation is passed? This is, to say the least, a very odd statement for the Minister to make. The answer we have been given is that the Department wishes to determine the number of responses before committing itself. We suggest that that is an inadequate answer . The Democrats will certainly be very closely monitoring the performance of the Minister, the Government and the Department in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, Senator, he has given me a pretty definite assurance today.
—Indeed, he has. I was delighted that the letter was read out to the chamber just a moment ago because I think it goes a very long way towards assuring us about this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Having outlined the circumstances relating to this legislation as we see it-the problems and the good parts of it-we think on balance that we should accept the Bills as they stand. We therefore will not be supporting the Australian Labor Party's amendments although I cannot stress too strongly that we have a great deal of sympathy for its stand on the diversification of the ownership of the media. In fact, without wishing to be presumptuous in any way, I commend the Australian Labor Party on the stand it has taken on this issue. I believe it is a very brave stand. The Democrats do not see that the Bills can be amended along the lines that the ALP wished to amend them. We believe that the amendments suffer from a logical paradox. One cannot grant a supplementary licence to someone who does not already have one. 'Supplementary licence' means an additional licence. If someone does not have a licence how can he be granted a supplementary licence? That may sound semantic but the whole thrust of the Bill is written around the issuing of supplementary licences. We believe simply that the insertion of a phrase saying that an individual or a firm can also make a supplementary licence application is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, can I interrupt you for a moment? This Bill amends the Broadcasting and Television Act. If you look at this Bill as part of that Act, which it would be if it were passed, do you still maintain that view because I do not think you logically can?

—We have discussed this matter in some depth with the experts in the Department and we were drawn to the conclusion that it was just too difficult to amend this legislation. I say very sincerely that this is an area that requires very careful attention. I hope that the Department will be able in the future to address itself to spreading the ownership of the media in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The remaining ALP amendments can be considered as a whole. They purport to prevent the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal from granting supplementary licences in situations in which the Tribunal determines there exists undue media concentration. This means, in effect, that the ALP is prepared to deny people in rural areas access to FM or second commercial television stations on the basis of undue concentration. It really gets down to the fact that, as I have tried to argue, we believe, on balance, that is not a fair choice to put to people in some rural areas. For that reason we are not able to support the Labor Party's second group of amendments. We believe that this is a difficult situation. Politicians undoubtedly have to be aware not only of means and ends but also of consequences. A significant consequence of these Bills is that perhaps as many as a dozen supplementary licences from provincial cities for FM stations and other broadcasting will be issued within the next few years. This legislation will allow that to happen. That is a process that we do not, under any circumstances, wish to see delayed.

Let me just quickly conclude by saying that the legislation is remarkably ambiguous and complex. I am informed that a major reason for this legislation is the need to clarify the exclusions from the supplementary licence scheme. We were, in fact, relieved to see that the legislation makes it plain that licensees of stations in the five mainland State capital cities will not be granted supplementary licences. A study of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal' s annual report shows that outside the mainland State capitals the media groups- that is, the Packer, Fairfax, Herald and Weekly Times and Murdoch groups-have remarkably little impact. Most regional broadcasters are independent or at least belong to a loose grouping of organisations formed purely for programming reasons.

We are aware that the life of a country broadcaster is difficult. We are aware also that some country broadcasters have an incestuous relationship with the National Party-a fact which to my regret I have found in certain areas over the years. But most, in fact, are fiercely independent, jealous of their prerogatives and extremely reluctant to be associated with the big media groups. Only around 10 per cent of provincial stations are owned by the big media groups . There is no particular reason, as far as we can see, why this percentage should increase, at least in the medium term. The Fairfax group, for example, can increase its number of radio stations only by one. That is the present situation.

We commend the Minister for a constructive, if far from perfect, piece of legislation to meet the legitimate aspirations of many country people and to allow them perhaps to get close to enjoying the same broadcasting facilities as metropolitan Australians. The Democrats support the legislation with the reservations that I have already expressed. We await further initiatives of the Minister with a great deal of interest and anticipation. We are very disappointed that this legislation has not addressed itself, as Senator Button pointed out, to the problem of public service broadcasting-a vital area. We hope that that receives the attention of the Department as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate is considering the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982 and related legislation. This is a piece of legislation from the Fraser Government designed to provide a capacity for more services, particularly to provincial Australia. I am grateful to honourable senators who have taken part in the debate and for the general support that has been given to the legislation. It is to be welcomed. It offers the prospect of new and better services. For that reason, it is productive and constructive legislation. The main business which the Senate will have to consider will be amendments to be moved in Committee. I will reserve my comment on those issues until we get into Committee. There seems to be no point in raising them here.

SPEECH.PARA: I make only one point in the summing up. I go back to the letter which Senator Missen has received today from the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) which I have just been looking at. The third paragraph reads:

My intention is to invite applications pursuant to Section 82 of the Broadcasting and Television Act and pursuant to my responsibilities under Sections 111C and 111D of the Act where after a nominated period, there is no expressed interest in a supplementary service, and where I have received a firm and appropriate proposal for the establishment of an independent service. As you know, the Government is introducing the supplementary licence scheme in order to increase broadcasting and television services in non-metropolitan areas.

I read that as having a more general application and not being limited in its application simply to the particular matter which Senator Missen had brought to the attention of the Minister. Finally, I say that I understand the difficulty which honourable senators have had. We are trying to put together two principles -one is that there should be a broad spread of ownership in the media and the other is that there should be a capacity for viability in whatever we do. It is an attempt to reconcile those two principles that has led to the Government producing this legislation in the form in which it has. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1982
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, clause 8, proposed new section 82A, sub-section (1), line 6, after 'licence', insert 'or any other person'.
(2) Page 4, clause 8, proposed new section 82A, sub-section (2), line 14, after 'licence', insert 'or any other person'.

Without going to the terminology in the legislation I will explain the point of the amendments. The point of the amendments is to put a potential independent operator on the same legislative footing as the holder of a licence in respect of the process of initiating an inquiry into the granting of a supplementary or an independent licence. As the Bill stands at the moment only the holder of an existing licence in a particular market may initiate an inquiry. Senator Missen' s correspondence from the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) relating to the cause celebre of Mr Thorburn in Mildura indicated that it would be the Minister's intention at some time if a holder of an existing licence did not apply for a supplementary licence-in other words he just sat on his existing licence and did not initiate an inquiry-to call for independent licences.

What we have in the legislation as it stands is a situation in which the holder of an existing licence has a statutory right conferred on him by this legislation to initiate an inquiry into whether or not he should have a supplementary licence. The potential independent applicant has no statutory right. He is dependent on some declaration by the Minister. If we are spelling out in legislation statutory rights for one legislation we should spell out statutory rights for the other. That is what the legislation contemplates. it contemplates dealing with the rights of existing licensees and it contemplates dealing with the rights of potential licensees of independent licences. They should be placed on the same footing. If we are talking about a free market situation in which the rules should apply with equity to all those who are interested in extending services in a particular market, the legislation should provide that they apply with equity.

I want to make just two other points. Some arguments can be addressed against the amendment. Firstly, it might be said that anyone can apply now to the Minister to invite an application in respect of a licence under the existing legislation. There is no formal process for this; it is just a request to the Minister whose power it is to determine what he will do with that application. But this Bill gives the right to apply only to an existing licensee. The same right should be given to others. Secondly, it might be said that we are creating a new automatic right and therefore taking planning powers away from the Minister. That is not the intention because it would be the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that determines whether an independent is viable and it would be the Tribunal that would then make a recommendation to the Minister that he call the licence.

If we had wanted to, we could have put up an amendment making it mandatory for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to grant an independent licence, which would be a parallel process to the grant of a supplementary licence. We have not put up any amendment making it mandatory for the Tribunal to do that; all we have said is that the Tribunal may make a recommendation to the Minister in respect of that matter. As I have said, we argue this basically on the question of equity between people who either are competitors established in a market or are seeking to enter the market. We say they should have the same statutory rights about initiating a process to determine whether there should be a new licence of one kind or another in a particular community. We would have thought that, in the operation of a free enterprise system, in order to facilitate that operation it would be a fair amendment which promoted equity between two contestants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support the amendments. The difficulty we have is that we are not looking at extra licences; we are looking at supplementary licences. We have done that because of the questions of viability raised by Senator Button and mentioned by all the other honourable senators who spoke in the second reading debate. The supplementary licence scheme is based on making existing licensees eligible to apply for a second licence to increase services in an area which would not support an additional independent licence. The advice I have is that very few areas would be able to support a supplementary licence with profit .

SPEECH.PARA: Sentor Chipp-Independent. You said 'supplementary'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, an independent licence. I am grateful to the honourable senator.
—That is something for the determination, isn't it?

—That is right but it is fundamental to the scheme that a supplementary licence be related to the commercial licence to serve the area because significant economies of scale probably will be necessary to make the whole thing viable and make it a goer.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that the proposed amendments take into account the ability which other persons may have, under the provisions of the supplementary licence scheme , to take action. First, they can object to the grant of a supplementary licence at a public inquiry into the licence grant by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and, secondly, they can apply for an independent licence when the Minister invites applications for an independent licence as a result of a refusal by the Tribunal to grant a supplementary licence on public interest and viability grounds. There is then a subsequent recommendation by the Minister. That should be taken in association with the third paragraph of the letter we received today which indicates that the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) has an intention, if existing licences do nothing, to consider whether he should call for applications. The proposed amendments also, I am advised, would have the effect of telescoping into one public inquiry two independent inquiry processes involved in the scheme. The Tribunal would then be required to decide at the one time whether an independent licence is viable and in the public interest, and whether a supplementary licence should be granted to an existing licensee; also, if an independent licence is viable, which applicant should be offered the licence. The Government thinks these issues can be properly resolved only by--

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be subsequent. That would take place later.
—We think there should be two separate public inquiries.
—So do we, and that is what would happen.

—I suppose that is not central to the point we are making. The Opposition expressed concern that existing licensees could frustrate the potential for choice, either by way of a supplementary licence or an independent licence, simply by not applying for their supplementary licences. It is said by the Opposition that amendments (1) and (2) would enable another interested party to set the process in motion. Several points can be made about this. For example , in only very few cases-perhaps just a handful around Australia-is it likely that an additional independent service would be commercially viable. The whole point of the supplementary licence scheme is that the possibility for additional choice in most areas-not just a little handful but in most areas-must come through the co-operation of the existing licensee. Supplementary licences, we think, will be cheaper and will give extra program offerings in many areas. We think that the supplementary licence route is likely to be more productive.

SPEECH.PARA: The supplementary licence scheme is a voluntary scheme. It is up to each licensee to decide whether to apply. It would achieve very little in the vast majority of cases if another party were able to initiate the process because, if the Tribunal were to find that an independent licence would not be commercially viable, the existing licensee could not be forced to invest in a second station. In the end, only community pressure can persuade a licensee to co-operate or to seek a supplementary licence if he is not minded to do so. In those few cases in which an extra independent licence might be commercially viable the existing licensee would have a strong incentive-I ask honourable senators to think about this situation-to apply for a supplementary licence anyhow. He would do that in order to argue against a recommendation that applications for an independent licence be granted. Even if it is viable to have an independent licence, it will probably be even better to apply for a supplementary licence. I would think that , in those circumstances, the existing licensee would, in his own interests, want to get the supplementary licence process under way.

In any event, the Minister retains his overall planning powers and will be able to invite applications-again I refer to that letter-for an independent licence if a licensee in a wealthy market procrastinates or will not act. I understand the difficulty in trying to marry the principles-the spread of ownership, opening up of access, and viability-but on balance the Government does not find the amendments acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like my colleague Senator Siddons, would like to compliment Senator Button and members of the Australian Labor Party for the work they have done on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill-we applaud their intention-by way of these amendments and the other set of amendments that they will move. The amendments fall into two parts. The part we are debating now concerns the Labor Party's desire for the right to be given to any person or group of persons to initiate an inquiry so that they can get a piece of the action in country towns. We certainly applaud that motive, but we will not support the amendment for the reasons Senator Siddons gave and for the reasons I propose to elaborate on at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us remember what this legislation is doing. I commend the Government. I think this is terrific legislation. I give it as high a commendation as I can. What we have lost sight of a little in this debate is that this legislation will be fantastic for people in rural and provincial areas. Even those of us who sometimes spend a night or two in Canberra would occasionally welcome a supplementary licence being given to the commercial television station here, for variety.

The main thrust of this Bill is to allow more television channels and FM radio stations in country and suburban areas. Let us remember that it does not apply to the five mainland capital cities. It applies only to Tasmania and to rural and provincial areas in the other States. Let me refresh the Committee's mind about the procedure. Any holder of a current licence, be it radio or television, in a rural or provincial area may apply for a supplementary licence to open a new radio or television service. Senator Button and the Australian Labor Party say: 'That is okay, but why not give that right to apply for another licence to someone else?' That is the nub of the problem we are debating. Before coming to that matter, however, let me continue on the procedure.

The licensee applies to the Minister for a supplementary licence. The Minister must refer that application to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, unless there are technical reasons which lead the Minister to believe that it is not a good thing to do that. Then an inquiry is conducted by the Tribunal. At that point any outsider can come in--

TALK.START.PARA: —And object.

—And object. He can say: 'Look, you should not give this supplementary licence. I have the wherewithal, the money and a company all ready to set up an independent competitor to this one'. At that point the Tribunal has all the evidence before it. As I understand it, the inquiries are conducted in public. The Tribunal may well conclude at that point that it will not grant a supplementary licence to the licensee but will grant an independent licence. We should get this matter into perspective. I have only the word of the Department of Communications. I do not mean to be deprecatory about the Department's word on this, but I have confirmed it with the industry-which admittedly has a biased view. I am told that, as the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has said, there would be two country towns or provincial areas, or perhaps three, where a fresh television licence could be granted-which amazes me, but that is the information I have-and 10 or 11 where radio stations could open. That is the magnitude of this problem, and that is the group for which Senator Button is caring-only two towns for which an extra independent television licence could be granted, and perhaps 10 for radio. I am not saying that that is no reason why he should be objecting; I am just putting the matter into perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button and the Labor Party say: 'Why should someone interested in setting up a new radio or television station in a country town have to wait until the licensee of the existing radio or television station applies for a supplementary licence'? If he had said that that is not the best system, I think he would have made an unanswerable point-and I think he did so. I cannot argue with it. To compound his concern, as I have just been commendatory of the Government and the Department, let me put the 'but' in now and be critical. The second reading speech states:

The Minister for Communications intends to make a full statement of planning guidelines for the implementation of the supplementary licence scheme as soon as possible after the legislation has been passed by the Parliament.

I think that is one of the most extraordinary sentences ever to have appeared in a second reading speech. The Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) and the Department are saying to Senator Button and the Labor Party: 'You have a real concern. You have a real problem with what you raise about who can apply and who can play the game; but after you have passed this legislation we will bring in the guidelines to tell you'. I have no doubt that the present Minister, for whom I have deep admiration, will immediately start issuing these guidelines . He will go to the country towns and flush out the fat cats among the television and radio licence holders. He will virtually force them into the situation where they have to apply for a supplementary licence. I understand that the Minister will have that power. I am worried about what would happen if we had an unscrupulous Minister in that situation.

I pay the highest respect to Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen who is in the chamber, but I say that it has not been unknown for some National Party Ministers for communications to use their powers notoriously to continue National Party ownership of country town television and radio stations. It is time that rort was ended, but whether we have a good Minister such as Neil Brown does not matter. The point is that this Parliament is being asked to give the ministry and the bureaucrats a blank cheque. I do not like that. I would not have thought that champions of the Parliament, such as Senator Missen and Senator Harradine, would have liked the Minister's statement either. The Minister has said that, not until we pass the legislation, will he disclose the planning guidelines for the implementation of the supplementary licence scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be changed by the alteration of the legislation. Surely you cannot complete those things until you know what the legislation is.

—That is not my understanding of it. I would be far happier opposing Senator Button's amendment, which I will, if I knew now what the guidelines were and that there was to be some sort of rhyme or reason for how the Minister and the Department will go after the fat cats who now hold lucrative licences in country towns and who possibly will not apply for supplementary licences. I can understand Senator Button's concern in a flash about the owners of supplementary licences who are doing very well. From looking at their profits when compared with a ratio of shareholders' funds one can see that they are doing remarkably well and one can understand why they would not want to apply for supplementary licences. One can understand why they might like to sit on their laurels, corner all the advertising and not worry about additional capital expenditure. But most of them know that they live in a dynamic world. Most of them know that unless they act something could well happen. The Minister might well force them to call for supplementary licences which might result in independent licences being granted in their towns and, therefore, competitors. They know that the satellite will soon be operating. Rumour has it that, for a cost of about $1,200, people will be able to interrupt a signal from a satellite from their backyards. Where will the local television or radio stations be then? Those sorts of inbuilt motivations are part of the technical developments that surround us.

SPEECH.PARA: What has not been mentioned-I am not disclosing anything in secret-and what is, I believe, the most compelling reason why we cannot accept Senator Button's amendment, is that I understand that something like 700 applications in the pipeline have not yet been processed by the Department for one reason or another . I have some misgivings about opposing the amendment of Senator Button and the Labor Party because I like its motivation, but I think it will add chaos to an already chaotic situation. We might say: 'Let us wait until the guidelines come down'. What would that mean? That would mean mid-February and by mid-February we will be in the throes of early election speculation. I am not saying that inefficiency in the Department has caused this backlog. It is simply the result of the facts of life. Given such a backlog on its books and the granting of an ' open sesame' for anybody to apply for an independent licence in any country or provincial town of Australia, the Department will be inundated and the work of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal clogged. The very thing that the legislation is required to do, namely, give a better and bigger service to people living in country towns, will be frustrated. For that reason the Democrats, although sympathising with the motivation of the Labor Party, regretfully cannot support its proposed amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to deal with one or two of the issues that have been raised. We are dealing with legislation which seeks to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942. If the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982 is passed its provisions will be inserted in the Broadcasting and Television Act at various points. We will then have, as it were, a new consolidation of the Broadcasting and Television Act and will read it as such. It will provide, until it is amended again, a code relating to broadcasting and television.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendments is to give existing licensees and those who aspire to become licensees, as independent operators, the same statutory rights in terms of initiating an inquiry. In answer to that Senator Peter Baume, repeating what was said in the House of Representatives-which was glib rather than informed-says in effect: 'You cannot, in dealing with supplementary licences, just say that. This Bill deals with supplementary licences and is therefore different from the Broadcasting and Television Act'. I think people are sometimes mesmerised by headings in Bills. The heading on page 4 of this Bill 'Applications for Supplementary Licences' would not appear in the Broadcasting and Television Act if these proposed new sections were adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: — But that's what it is.

—I know, Senator. I am saying that proposed new section 82A, if approved, will be inserted in the Act without any accompanying reference to supplementary licences, except insofar as they might be alluded to in the text of the new provisions.
—But the whole text is drafted around the supplementary licence; that is the problem.
—Yes, I know. But proposed new section 82A just adds another provision relating to the granting of licences.
—It's got a heading: 'Application for Supplementary Licences'.

—Which will not be in the Broadcasting and Television Act, Senator Chipp, if this Bill is adopted. That heading will not become part of the Act. The second point I make is that a great deal of concern has been expressed about licences. People say: We are really talking about only ten radio licences and three television licences'. That is a precise function of this Bill that people like us should not talk about. That should be the subject matter of a proper inquiry by the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. It is not for us to make assessments as to how many areas might be viable in terms of supporting a new operator.
—But they are not unrealistic figures, are they?
—They may not be unrealistic if a new operator is starting in a particular market. Take a town like-I will try to think of a nice neutral, safe town-
—Alice.

—Alice Springs, yes. I do not know what happens in Alice Springs. Let us call it 'Alice' rather than Alice Springs. Take a town like that. We may make judgments about whether a new operator, one who has never been in the business and who is starting in Alice Springs, would be viable. Assuming an existing viable radio or television station was operating at Ayers Rock, there is no reason under this legislation why the Ayers Rock proprietor should not come into Alice Springs and say: 'I want to be an independent here as distinct from the existing operators'. He would be viable because-
—Not necessarily.

—Assuming he has a successful operation at Ayers Rock and he wants to operate in Alice Springs as well, the chances are that he would be viable. We can look at somebody in a contiguous area as a potential applicant under this legislation. It does not have to be anybody who has never been in the business before. I say that because these speculations are not things for us appropriately to take into account here; they are matters for determination under the legislation itself. I do not think we should be guided by considerations of that kind or by the consideration raised by Senator Chipp that there is a backlog in the Department of Communications and that if this legislation is passed with the Australian Labor Party amendments there will be a vast rush of independent operators applying for licences. That, with respect, is unrealistic. The proposition that because there is inefficiency in government one should not adopt correct principles in legislation is, I find, absurdly at variance with the basic motto of the Australian Democrats when they first came into this place that they would keep people honest. It is the legislation which should be honest and which should provide a correct set of principles. One should not take into account factors such as incompetence or delay in the Department at a particular time as a reason for not adopting that correct set of principles.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 7, clause 9, paragraph (e), proposed new paragraph 83 (6) (e), line 6, after ''supplementary licence'', insert, ''and the Tribunal has not refused to grant the licence under paragraph 83 (6) (g)''.
(4) Page 7, clause 9, after paragraph (e), insert the following paragraph:
''(ea) by adding after paragraph (f) of sub-section (6) the following word and paragraph:

'or (g) the Tribunal is satisfied that, where the licence is a supplementary licence, the granting of such licence would result in undue concentration of influence, whether direct or indirect, on the part of the applicant, having regard to the ownership and control of other media serving the area to be served by the licence.'; and''.
(5) Page 7, clause 9, paragraph (f), proposed new sub-section (8A), line 29, after ''paragraph (6) (e)'', insert ''or after having refused the grant of a licence under paragraph 83 (6) (g)''.

These amendments deal with undue concentration of ownershp. No. (4) is the key amendment. The other two are related to it only insofar as they are necessary if amendment No. 4 is adopted because they relate to the question of outcomes. We suggest in this amendment that a licence should not be given to a licensee if he is part of a cross-media grouping in a particular region or town. I do not have to enunciate my own views about that. I just say that since the inception of legislation governing broadcasting ownership and control in this country in 1935 the legislation has always contained provisions concerned with preventing undue concentration of ownership or control. Those views, which have been bypassed, have been supported by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the Townsville case and the 2HD case in Newcastle, by the High Court when the 2HD case was taken away from the Tribunal and sent to it, and in Hardiman's case relating to Channel 10, as it now is, in Melbourne.

Let us take the Townsville case because that dealt with a regional situation. In that case the Broadcasting Tribunal expressed concern about a town in which a newspaper, two radio stations and a television station were owned by one proprietor. The case did not involve just the one town; a station at Ayr near Townsville was involved in one of the applications. The Tribunal was concerned for very obvious reasons. There are two reasons why one should be against undue concentration of media ownership in one town. They are simply these: The consumers in that town are entitled to alternative sources of information and programming. There is no guarantee that they will get alternative sources of information or programming from a media situation in which one proprietor owns the newspaper, the television and the radio station.

TALK.START.PARA: —Other than the ABC, of course.
—No, because there is no such situation.
—I'm sorry; they have already got it.

—There is an alternative. But in a sense this legislation deals with the commercial market. I am putting a classic argument against restraint of trade, which has been at the centre of the philosophy of some sections of the Liberal Party, as I understand it, for a long time. That is why we are concerned about this question of undue concentration of ownership. I find it sad that I have to put the free enterprise argument in this chamber in relation to this legislation. This is nowhere better expressed in factual terms than by a decision, which is not of very long standing, of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in relation to the town of Launceston. I want to tell the chamber what the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal said about this issue in that decision. The proprietor of the media in Launceston, Tasmania, is one Mr Rouse. I have never met him; I have no objections to him. I am sure he is an impeccable proprietor who disseminates a wide range of views and opinions. But the Broadcasting Tribunal, with regard to Mr Rouse, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The power which now rests in Mr Rouse, insofar as it affects his position in Launceston radio and television, is clearly far greater than it previously was. As a result of the transaction the only two television licences in Tasmania are controlled by the one person and group. This concentration of power is unprecedented in modern times. The ownership of Tasmania Television almost certainly is permanently locked into one group.
The Tribunal went on to refer to a statement made on 3 June 1981 by the then Minister for Communications, Mr Ian Sinclair. The Tribunal's decision, referring to what Mr Sinclair said, reads:
. . . made it quite clear that concentration of ownership was only to be considered in non-metropolitan areas (i.e. outside the six State capitals).
The Tribunal then quotes what he said in the House of Representatives as follows :

With regard to the concentration of influence on radio and television in regional areas, honourable members should be aware that the principal Act already applies much stricter limits on ownership in metropolitan areas than in regional areas. It is not possible for any individual to hold prescribed interests in more than one television station and one radio station in any one State capital city within the overall limit of two television or eight radio stations. On the other hand, it would not be illegal for one person to control up to two television stations and four radio stations in a regional city such as Newcastle. In this latter case, it is clearly desirable that the Tribunal should be able to limit undesirable concentration.
The Broadcasting Tribunal then stated:
One of the criteria to be considered by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was outlined in the following manner:

''the need to avoid undue concentration in respect of influence, either directly or indirectly, in relation to the ownership or control of radio and television stations in non-metropolitan . . . areas.''

The Tribunal deals with that at length. The only point I am trying to make is that bodies such as the Broadcasting Tribunal and the former Broadcasting Control Board have expressed concern about this question of undue concentration. The consequences of our amendment being carried would be-unlike what the Minister said in the House of Representatives-that the Broadcasting Tribunal would be asked to consider, in relation to a particular area, whether there was undue concentration. The Broadcasting Tribunal would then, presumably, apply or develop the criteria which it was developing in relation to public interest prior to the iniquitous 1981 amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act. It would perhaps find in a particular situation that there was undue concentration. If the Tribunal finds undue concentration it goes to the Minister with a recommendation that he call for an independent licence in that area. It may be said that if he calls for applications for an independent licence there may be no applicant or the applicant may not prove to be viable. That is something which, in the free market, the applicant should decide, that he will succeed or go broke. If he is to succeed, he succeeds against a concentrated media ownership situation. People shudder at the thought of going broke. That is what is wrong with private enterprise in Australia. It never wants to go broke; it never wants to take the risk of going broke, as distinct from the United States of America, where people take calculated risks in business. Supposing the applicant does go broke. Then it might be said that the effect of our amendment is to deprive the people in that town of an additional service. That is not so at all because broadcasting is not limited to commercial services. That town could be provided specifically, for example, with a public broadcasting licence or some other service of that kind which may at least introduce a degree of diversity into the consumer situation in that town. That is what we are concerned about.

While the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) is responding, I wonder whether he would also answer this question, the answer to which I am not sure is revealed by the legislation: What happens when there are two commercial licensees in a town and they both apply for supplementary licences? What happens then to determine the question who should get a supplementary licence? What happens to the independent applicant in that situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I say that the Australian Democrats are sympathetic to the motivation of the Australian Labor Party and Senator Button but cannot support these specific amendments. We will be voting with the Government. The fact that we should be opposed to concentration of ownership in the media is beyond question. My colleague, Senator Siddons, the Democrat's spokesperson on communications has said this repeatedly in public speeches that he has made. That is one of the reasons why the Democrats, together with the Labor Party, are zealously guarding the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. We are fearful of concentration of ownership of the media in Australia. When the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) replies, I would like him to say whether my interpretation of the Labor Party amendments is correct or whether Senator Button's interpretation of his amendments is correct. Frankly, I think this amendment is a contradiction in terms. It is a contradiction against the whole spirit of the Bill, the basic purpose of which is to create supplementary licences. By definition, a supplementary licence is a licence which is supplementary to the one already owned. I will not take as an example a mythical town; I will take one which brings back rather fond memories for me. I refer to Bendigo. I did rather well in a foot race in Bendigo a few years ago. I started short price favourite, actually. I ran five yards inside evens and then did not win. But let us say, for example, that Channel 8, Bendigo, applies for a supplementary licence. Under the system, the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) must refer that application to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I am sure that Channel 8 Bendigo will be one of those stations which will apply for a supplementary licence. Let us take another classic case, Channel 7, Canberra. Channel 7, Canberra will apply for a supplementary licence because it is a progressive station; it has dynamic leadership and management.
—You will be on Channel 7 tonight.

—I cannot win many votes but I will put in a good word for the honourable senator. That immediately triggers a device. The Minister must refer that application for a supplementary licence to the Tribunal. The Tribunal then must conduct a public inquiry and make one of two decisions. At that public inquiry all would-be competitors of Channel 7, Canberra could say 'We do not think a supplementary licence should be given to Channel 7, Canberra. We, the XYZ company, should be granted an independent licence'. The Tribunal at that point must make one of two decisions. Either it must say: 'This city of Bendigo is now ready to take an independent channel', or it must say: 'It is not ready, it would not be viable, and therefore we will give a supplementary licence to Channel 8'. I assume that if the Tribunal made the former decision, to open it up to an outsider--
—It is a new ball game then.

—It is a new ball game. As I understand it, Senator Button's criteria immediately applies-I ask the Minister to correct me if I am wrong-and if the Tribunal said 'There will be another licence in Canberra', it would never in a million years give the new licence to the existing management or ownership of Channel 7. I would be appalled if that proposition were right. The whole thing would be reduced to a farce. Let us come to the second proposition, which I think illustrates that Senator Button's amendment is contradictory. If the Tribunal said: 'There is no room for another licence so a supplementary licence is granted' and Senator Button's amendment were applied literally, would it then be said that we cannot have a concentration of ownership and it cannot be Channel 8 which owns the supplementary licence which is granted to Channel 8? If someone other than Senator Button had moved this amendment I would have said that it bordered on absurdity, but because I have such respect for his capacity- -
—It borders on sloppiness.

—It is not sloppiness. Either I cannot understand what he is getting at or he misinterprets the Bill. Therefore, I ask the Minister to respond because what Senator Button and I are putting are clearly two different interpretations of one set of words.
—Before Senator Button responds, I indicate that the Government agrees with Senator Chipp.
—Oh, God help us!

—That is not such an extraordinary thing to do. The facts as we understand them are as Senator Chipp has set them out-the intended effect of the proposed amendments reintroduces what we might call undue concentration of influence as a criterion for refusal by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to grant a supplementary licence. If the Tribunal will not grant a supplementary licence and a supplementary licence is all that is viable or possible, the only effect which might flow from that is that a region might be denied the extra service for which it might otherwise have a capacity.
