Tasmania might be the perfect example. Senator Button has given as evidence what he says is a high concentration of ownership.
—The Tribunal said that.
—The Tribunal said that; I thank the honourable senator.
—Surely you would concede that.

—I would concede that. It may be that an independent licence is not possible. There are then two choices. Either the people in Tasmania do not get an extra capacity or it is done by way of a supplementary licence. It is for that reason, which Senator Chipp set out, that we will not support the amendment. I have tried to get some information on the question put to me by Senator Button about what would happen if two licensees both applied for a supplementary licence. The Minister would have a capacity to do several things. He could reject both and ask both licensees to talk to each other to try to come up with some accommodation, or the matter could go to the Tribunal and the Tribunal could then reject one or both of the applications. It could do so on the grounds of viability or public interest. I find the question very difficult to answer with precision.
—Surely it could reject one and grant the other.
—It could reject one and grant the other, but there may be an alternative course of saying to the applicants: 'Get together and try to come up with something in the form of a consortium'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate. I begin by saying that listening to Senator Chipp I was reminded of that Peter Sellers record where there is a British Broadcasting Corporation book review session. The book to be reviewed is Blossoms in the Dust. One of the reviewers comes on and says: 'Well, I was asked to review Seven Brave Tractor Drivers'. He then gives his review of Seven Brave Tractor Drivers. Senator Chipp , of course, has done exactly the same. The fact is nowhere better illustrated than by the two examples he has taken of Bendigo and Canberra which would not be affected by this amendment at all. What I am talking about is cross-ownership of media. In Bendigo, BCV8 does not own the newspaper and does not own the radio station. It is a classic example of where this amendment would not apply. If we refer to Canberra, the Macquarie radio station, 2CA, is owned by the Fairfax group; 2CC is owned by local people; Channel 7 is owned by Kerry Stokes effectively; and the Canberra Times is owned by the Fairfax group. There cannot be said to be undue concentration of media in the Canberra market. So this amendment would not apply in the two examples that Senator Chipp has chosen. His speech was addressed to the earlier amendments which I moved, not to the last amendment. It is sad that the Australian Democrats have such a misunderstanding of the amendment as it has been moved.
—Well, the Government and the Department also misunderstand your words. Would you please-
—Tasmania would be an example where Senator Chipp's argument and my argument would apply.
—Might apply.
—Okay-might apply.

—But it would be a matter for determination by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. That is what the amendment is directed at. If one wants to say that in a market where all the media is owned by one proprietor the effects of this amendment might be to stop a supplementary licence going to that proprietor then the answer is yes.
—It would, yes.

—Yes. But there are other means of providing additional broadcasting services in that area than by the commercial sector. What we are talking about is choice and diversity. That is the thrust of the amendment. For reasons best known to itself, the Government has blandly announced that it agrees with Senator Chipp. I would have thought that in general terms for the Government it was a proposition that it would not embark on with alacrity and Senator Chipp recognises that. But in this particular instance I think it is a very poor way of getting out of a basic argument about what should happen in that sort of situation. I do not want to pursue the matter. I hope that in the new year greater minds than those today will be applied to some of these debates .

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982 and Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1982 agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 December, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the Senate debate cognately this Bill and the Special Employment-related Programs Bill on the Notice Paper.
—Order! Is it the wish of the Senate to debate the measures cognately? There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of these Bills is to impose the Government's so-called wages freeze. The Special Employment-related Programs Bill seeks to appropriate a sum of $300m which the Government says will be used in job creation programs. The Opposition is opposed to these Bills. It is sometimes said of the Opposition that we seem to be enjoying the great Australian loneliness in being opposed to these Bills as they have been supported in part by some Premiers for their own particular reasons, and so on. That is not the point. It is the function of the Opposition in the Parliament to point out its concerns about any legislation which comes before the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I say at the outset that, as far as we are concerned, this country is in a period of grave economic crisis. The response of these Bills to that situation is very poor. We are not pursuing dogged negativism in opposing these Bills. We see this wages pause as a stunt. The Government, as one of its junior Ministers said, had to be seen to be doing something. The wages freeze legislation follows from the Government's desire to be seen to be doing something rather than from any particular rational economic argument. People should be clear from the outset that this legislation is economic gimmickry designed to keep this Government alive.

I do not have time to refer in detail to the extent of the economic situation in this country. I make two points at the outset. First, I commend to honourable senators a reading of Professor Keith Hancock's book Incomes Policy in Australia , particularly page 84, where he makes the point, if I may summarise it, that such things as wage freezes are no substitute for sound economic management or for a proper wages policy. A proper wages policy is something which this Government has not had since, in 1981, it abandoned wage indexation which it inherited from the previous Labor Government. Secondly, in the context of the economic situation in this country, I draw the attention of the Senate to the last issue of Australian Bulletin of Labour, published by the National Institute of Labour Studies. On page 4, the following point is made:
. . . Australia is the only country on the list--
That is, of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries-
which experienced an increase in its inflation rate over the past two years.
It goes on to state, relative to Australia's inflation, and referring to the manufacturing sector:
Once again, Australia's inflation performance is seen to deteriorate in the most recent year, both in absolute terms and relative to other countries included in the comparison.
At the foot of the same page the point is made:
In the year to August 1982, industrial production in Australia declined by a staggering 13 per cent . . .

I am making these points just to illustrate the extent of the current problems with which this legislation purports to deal. It is a pathetic response to this country's crisis. The current inflation rate of 12.3 per cent in Australia compares with the latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 7.2 per cent. It compares with the United States inflation rate of 5 per cent-on the last figures-a United Kingdom inflation rate of 7.5 per cent and a Japanese inflation rate of 3 per cent. By February 1983 unemployment in Australia is expected to exceed 700,000 people-a rate of 10 per cent. I again make a point which I have made before in this chamber: Of all the OECD countries other than Italy-in fact, including Italy, where the inflation rate has gone down slightly-Australia is the only country which has achieved the twin success of rising inflation and rising unemployment at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about rising wages?

—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle glibly interjects 'rising wages' . I will come to that. Some of the figures she has quoted in this place are quite extraordinary when we look at the international comparisons. That is a glib assertion by the Minister for Finance. I was making the point that unemployment is expected to exceed 700,000 persons by February-a rate of 10 per cent. That is rising unemployment and rising inflation, according to the Melbourne Institute and indeed the anticipations of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in recent statements. Employment in manufacturing industry in Australia declined by over 38,000 people since last year. That is the largest absolute decline of any industry. Blue collar employees in the manufacturing sector are the main victims of this recession, losing over 79,000 jobs compared to a total unemployment decline of 87,000 jobs in the year to August.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has admitted in the Budget papers that there will be little or no growth next year. It has lost control of the economy. The Budget blow-out has pushed the deficit up to $4,000m. It must be understood that the wages freeze, as it is called, is the Government's response to these problems. According to surveys, it is not a response believed in by most Australian people in terms of its effects on the inflation rate and the level of unemployment. The people are right about that. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, last week said that the wages freeze was 'the single most valuable contribution that can be made at this moment to the cause of improving the employment position'. With respect, that proposition is absurd. It is a contribution, we concede. We said at the beginning and we will say at the end of the debate that there are a number of other things which governments ought to be doing by way of contribution to this enormous problem which this Government has inflicted on the Australian people. The wages freeze is a political and not an economic nostrum. In six months' time it will be known as the Flinders freeze, if it is not already. It is a stunt dreamed up to cover government ineptitude. It is a slogan, again in the scapegoat category, whereby the Government says it has to blame somebody or something else for economic incompetence and this time it is wages. As the Sydney Morning Herald put it on 8 December 'Now it's a farce'. Farce it is, rather than a freeze. Some States are to have a six months' wages freeze. Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Commonwealth are to have a 12 months' pause. There is no certainty about what will happen at the end of those respective pauses in any State or the Commonwealth as a result of Government policy. There is no doubt about the origins of this proposal in terms of the Government's political priorities.

I say at once that this Government has grossly misrepresented the position with regard to wages and employment in Australia. The Government would like everyone to believe that wage rises are the cause of unemployment. That is a dishonest and simplistic argument. As I have said time and time again, no one would argue that wage moderation is a desirable thing and a contributing factor to any recovery which may be possible in the Australian economy. But it is just not true to say that there is a direct and continuing link between wage rises and unemployment to the exclusion of a host of other factors for which this Government is responsible. Clearly, wages are important but they are not the cause of unemployment in the way in which this Government would like them to be. I refer again to the Government's own Budget Papers, which show that unit costs of production in Australia have not increased since 1976. That is to say, the relative cost of labour since 1976 has not increased if we have regard to productivity and output.

The Government is concerned to make transfers from wage and salary earners to profits. Supposedly this is being done because there have been rapid and real wage rises which have forced employers to lay off workers. It is true that there may have been a slight increase in real wages in the last year. But I make the point again that the average weekly earning series upon which the estimate of a large increase in real wages is based is not beyond suspicion. I pointed out a week ago that the Flinders Institute of Labour Studies, publishers of the authoritative Australian Bulletin of Labour, does not believe that there has been a massive increase in real wages this year. It points out that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures measure wage growth on average but they do not take into account the fact that low paid workers are dropping into the unemployment pool under this Government's policies and those lower wages are no longer being taken into account in assessing the average wages in Australia. If lower wages are dropping off at one end of the sample it has an effect on the level of average earnings which seems to rise because poorer workers are constantly being disemployed as a result of government policy. I made this point earlier in relation to blue collar workers.

The Flinders Institute pointed out that there has been only a 13 per cent increase in wages over the past year in contradistinction to the figure cited by the Government, which is based on changes in average weekly earnings. We have had a 13 per cent increase in wages at the same time as we have had a 12.4 per cent increase in inflation. I make the point again that the pattern of wages in Australia has been closely allied to the figures for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Let us not forget that any explosion in wages that occurred in the final quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year was based on the abdication by the Government from a central wage fixing policy in Australia. I have said it before and will say it again-the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peacock, has said it-that this Government has no wages policy. In the absence of a wages policy following the abandonment of indexation there was an increase in wages in the last quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year.

Let us compare the pattern of wages over recent years in Australia with the pattern in the OECD. Australia has had a 13 per cent increase in wages. I do not dispute that that might be too high. But Australia has had a 12.4 per cent increase in inflation. The same pattern is to be seen in OECD countries overall. There has been a 7.2 per cent average rate of inflation, and there has been an 8 per cent wage increase, which is slightly higher than the rate of inflation. That comparison has been totally ignored by this Government in considering how it should respond to the current economic crisis.

Again I make the point that, in dealing with this question, it is most important to look at questions of equity. There is no reason in the world why the salaries of top public servants or why the salaries of politicians should not be frozen. There is no moral argument against that at all. But that is not what the wages freeze does. It freezes those salaries but it also freezes the salaries of lowly paid workers-those workers who are receiving incomes well below average weekly earnings-who are dependent in this time of high interest rates and high prices on a continuing capacity to keep up with the increasing cost of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't go back to a four-day week, will they, Senator?
—Who will not go back to a four-day week?
—The public servants.

—No, of course they will not. I make the final point that if wages were a major cause of unemployment this would have shown up in the productivity figures, but it does not. Again, while we stress that wage moderation is important, it is important as part of an economic strategy to combat the current recession. To single out the issue of wage increases and lay the cause of unemployment at its feet is stupid and wrong. The Government, of course, is clearly confused about what it expects the wages freeze to do and what will happen at the end of it. On the important question of price surveillance mechanisms, what is to happen to the wages policy after the freeze? What is to happen to the control of non-wage incomes? What is to happen in relation to job creation programs? The Government has shown itself inside and outside this Parliament to be beside itself with confusion on these issues. Honourable senators will remember Question Time on Tuesday a fortnight ago. It illustrated a chronic incapacity of Government Ministers to answer questions on these issues. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, to make the same point, a copy of a list of questions that the Australian Council of Trade Unions addressed to the Government at its meeting on 9 December and a copy of the responses, which illustrate total confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
QUESTIONS
1. Is there any written agreement between the parties.
2. Is there any written record of understanding between the parties.
3. Is there any written record of your understanding of the agreement reached.
4. What is the status of the 21 point Commonwealth proposal.
5. What is the starting date for the freeze.
6. What is the exact situation regarding flow on of the ''old'' wages round (a) is this compatible with your point 3 of the Commonwealth proposal.
7. What is the extent of proposed legislative action both State and Federal in relation to the freeze.
8. What is to happen to anomolies/inequities during the freeze.
9. What does the government expect will happen at the end of the freeze; specifically:
(a) What will happen to wages
(b) What will happen to employees covered by Federal Awards working side by side with State Award employees who will be affected by the 6 month freeze
(c) What are the governments fiscal and monetary policies for the post freeze period in the context of the differing freeze periods.
10. What are the governments expectations of productivity and CPI movements in 1984.
11. How does the government assess the effects of the freeze on:
(a) Unemployment
(b) Inflation
(c) Economic growth
(d) Budget Deficit
12. How does the government expect the freeze to increase profits and international competitiveness given the depressed state of markets both domestic and international.
13. What is to happen to over-award payments during the freeze.
14. How are non-wage incomes to be controlled.
15. What is the mechanism for price control during the freeze.
16. How does the government reconcile its wages freeze strategy with the statement on page 53 of Budget Paper No. 2.
17. How does the government see the role of the commission during the pause.
18. What is the commitment by the government to return to a centralised system of wage fixation.
19. On what basis do you see that system operating.
20. Do you think real wages will fall as a result of the freeze and if so by how much.
21. How is the figure of $300 million for Job Creation programs calculated.
22. How many jobs will this generate.
23. How is the $300 million to be allocated.
24. Is the government prepared to consider other Job Creation schemes.
25. What is the governments commitment to Tax Indexation in the next financial year.
26. Is the government prepared to now adopt the repeated call by the ACTU to urgently convene and participate in an exanded economic summit involving State Premiers, ACTU and employers.
RESPONSES
1. No.
2. No.
3. Yes. Related in Statement to Parliament.
4. 21 point proposal-no standing now. Points specifically excluded some assumptions but did not define.
5. On day of proclamation. Expected legislation through the Senate on 21st or 22nd and proclamation a day or so after that.

6. Expect old wages round to be completed. (Waffled on here). Discussion of hours. Detailed special circumstances. Mentioned Williamstown. Only the wage freeze and the national interest to be considered. No roving Commission.
Agreement of the Government on hours is required. They saw hours differently to wage rates so far as catch-up and community round concerned.

7. Extent of proposed legislation was Bill to be introduced in the Parliament for the Commonwealth sector. Will also relate to doctors and pharmacists. States had indicated they would use most effective commissions. All states but Bannon had agreed. Gentle pursuasion to be used for professional fees. Ministers to go to the various groups with which they have associations.

8. Anomalies and Inequities. Asked Commission to take a narrow view. Adamant there would be no interference with the functions of the Commission. Nor would there be interference with Public Service arrangements in relation to higher duties etc.

9. No catch up. A case to be put to the Tribunal-we would go into and out of the freeze through the Tribunal. Their attitude about the end of the freeze appeared confusing. Anthony said a better idea could be gauged over time. The results of their Departmental Inquiry would be known by then. The Tribunal will be used to get out of the pause.

Where Federal/state awards cover side by side . . . Different lengths of pause- no reason to believe there would be any difference in dates for the pause. The Government said the states said the six months could be extended. In NSW this could be done by regulation. It was really having regard to the ACTU's view that they agreed not to go beyond six months. We will see about it when the problem arises.

Monetary and fiscal policy-Shouldn't have any effect on interest rates, there will be a higher level of capital inflow. Certainly no looser monetary policy. No tightening either. Can't imagine a different approach to policy in 12 months time.

10. 1982-83 CPI 10 1/2 to 11 per cent. The CPI for the calendar year will be lower. The Government said they were really stabbing in the dark. Until they know the extent of the pause it is hard to make assumptions.
1983 productivity could be up to minus 2 per cent, farm product down by 20%. If greater, then the 2 per cent is under-estimated.

11. The freeze will help in private sector retention levels. They are not talking about changes to the levels of employment or unemployment they are talking in terms of how many people will or will not be put off than otherwise would have been the case.
Reluctant to put figures on what will happen if there is a 12 months freeze.

12. They assume a link between profits and wage levels. They believe there will be a greater degree of confidence because they are correct in this assumption. But they have no figures at all. They see a gain in terms of confidence. They talk about Average Weekly Earnings being reduced down 12 per cent and 11-11 1/2 per cent. It will have a minor impact here because we have already got 9% up to the September quarter.
During 1983 it could be down as far as 10 1/2 to 11 per cent on a calendar year basis.
12. (Point made here in relation to avoiding all these people being put off).
13. Over-award wages are no great problem.
14. Government Ministers will liaise with various associations and urge them to adopt the same approach.
They believe that they will get a positive situation-through legislation or advocacy.
In many non-wage areas the states have controls and it is up to them to use their own judgment.
As to other areas they argue they are more market oriented.
15. One state offered price power. Queensland and Western Australia rebuffed the idea. Generally they were against centralised pricing power and didn't want it anyway.
16. (NO POINTS HERE).
17. The commission will have very little to do. They see a decision as late as January which will be mirrored in State tribunals. After that nothing to do.
18. We now have a centralised approach with respect to the pause period. Future to depend on the Departmental Inquiry etc.
19. Subject to continuing discussions.
20. Too early to estimate. Particularly in relation to the private sector. There will be a fall. ACTU indicated discussions desirable in relation to tax measures.

21. The $300 million figure-is money otherwise expended on wages and salaries in the public sector. It is 5 per cent of wages and salaries bill in the calendar year across the public sector. Private sector savings will be $2-$3 billion.
22. The situation of jobs-they are guessing. The States have been required to provide ideas. Employment, Australian content mentioned. To be applied in non- discriminatory way.
23. Chaney said the $300 million would be allocated on a population basis to worthy projects.
24. Welfare housing proposal involved $100 million, 2,000 houses to be constructed, 2,300 jobs involved. The Commonwealth asked for ideas.
They explained the Unemployment Benefit pilot thing, unemployment benefit used to supplement casual work rates to create part-time employment.
25. Howard said no commitment to tax indexation. Government withdrew it two years ago. The Government had been generous in the last budget. No proposal to review in the next budget.

26. Economic summit idea. Positive answer gained. Followed up with Anthony running down the corridor saying when? At first he had stated 'not at this stage '-maybe sometime in 1983. Outside he changed and indicated he was prepared to call it as early as January.

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth is that the Government does not know what will happen because the wages freeze was never conceived as anything other than a political stunt. That may be all very well for the Government, but the pause or freeze, as it is presently conceived, represents a massively inequitable burden on wage earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I have referred before to figures which demonstrate the pattern of real wage increases in Australia since 1975. It is quite clear from those figures that the lower paid workers have suffered a real decrease in wages under this Government while higher paid workers have endured a real increase.

I refer to the latest version of the table which was published by the Flinders Institute of Labour Studies. It makes the point that the wages of a worker on average earnings of $154 a week-that is somebody on the lowest wage figure- between 1975 and August 1981, went down by 11.4 per cent a week; On the other hand, the salary of somebody earning $530 a week increased by 8.2 per cent in the same period. So the real wages of the lowest paid worker have gone down by 11 per cent and those of the highest paid worker in the table have gone up by 8 per cent in the last six years. A freeze imposed in that situation rigidifies the inequality which is now built into the system. So the higher paid worker, having received all that benefit in the last six years, has his salary frozen for the 12-month period, whereas the lower paid worker on whom the costs of food , clothing and interest rates continually bear more savagely has suffered a decline of 11.4 per cent in real wages.

This freeze will exacerbate the difference between high and low income earners and create a situation of inequity by the absence of a proper wage policy and a fair taxation policy. When the government gets into trouble it freezes the inequities, rigidifies and solidifies them in the ice cube of its own indifference. That is the very real charge against this Government in respect of wages policy over the years. Low wage earners are being asked to bear the brunt of this recession, if they were not doing it already.

I want to make some other points on this matter. Because of some half-baked idea of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in favour of a decentralised wage system, it appears that over-award payments will not be subject to the freeze. We have asked questions of Ministers in the Government, for days on end, as to whether the Government's wages policy is for a centralised system or a decentralised system. There has been no answer. Mr Macphee, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, wants a centralised wages system in Australia. He is quite right. The Department of the Treasury and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, for bizarre reasons of their own, do not want a centralised wage system in Australia. They are quite wrong in terms of considerations of equity and justice. Because the Government has two wages policies-it cannot agree on one-we have this absurd situation where the freeze will apply to award wages but not to over-award wages . This again will only increase the disparities between high and low income earners. At the end of the pause wage earners will have experienced a real drop in living standards. This should be understood.

Professional incomes will not be subject to any sensible control. Some Minister rushing off to the Law Institute of Victoria to ask it to dissuade its members from putting up their charges or something of that kind, will not work. The pause or freeze will not work either because it will do nothing to create jobs. It is essential to grasp that a wages freeze is contradictory in the sense that it will reduce demand. If it is successful it will ensure that real levels of income fall. We do not know what will happen at the end of the freeze. Will there be demands that real levels of wages and incomes suddenly rise, to catch up? If so it will be economically disastrous. The reduction in real wage levels will reduce consumer demand and reducing consumer demand will not create jobs. People will not spend money if they have less available so why will manufacturers produce more goods for people who cannot buy them? Why will manufacturers take on more labour as a result of this freeze?

The benefits of a freeze will, of course, go to increased profits which will be spent, if not in distribution, on plant and equipment rather than the creation of jobs. Of course, that is what the unemployment issue is all about. It is not about wages being frozen in the naive belief that employers will create employment opportunities as a result of the effects of that process. The Government, under the provisions of the Special Employment-related Programs Bill , plans to spend some $300m on capital works projects. That may have some small effect. But I remind honourable senators of what the Government is saying. It is to spend $300m to remedy a situation in which 700,000 people are projected to be unemployed by February of next year. I remind the Government that every one per cent increase in the unemployment level of this country costs the Australian Government a billion dollars in terms of unemployment benefit and tax revenue lost. This Government says that some $300m will be spent on capital works to deal with an army of 700,000 unemployed. This Bill is a totally inadequate gimmicky response.

Of course, what is needed are policies for reflation and growth. The wages pause is contractionary. Wages pauses are only ever a temporary alleviation of long term problems. They seek an adjournment to allow one time to think. If one does not have the capacity to think it is no good having adjournments because nothing will occur in the meantime. A wages pause is not a substitute for a soundly based incomes policy. I again commend the Senate to a reading of Professor Hancock's book, Incomes Policy in Australia because there the point that a gimmick like this is no substitute for a sound wages policy is clearly made. It is no substitute for a proper prices and incomes policy which would introduce two notes into the system-one of equity and one of sound economic management-as a basis for economic recovery.

Finally, I want to say that it is time for this Government to think seriously about serious policies rather than these gimmicks to deal with a very serious situation. We need national economic leadership rather than slogans. The Government merely reacts. It has no idea where it is going. The inevitability of economic collapse is with us unless the Government is prepared to give far- reaching national leadership on these issues. Because of constraints on our time I confine my remarks to those points except to say that I wish to move an amendment to the second reading of the Bill. I move:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn pending the convening by the Government early in the New Year, of a national summit conference of Federal and State Governments, the trade union movement and employers, at which:
(a) the full dimensions of the economic crisis confronting Australia can be fully exposed and analysed;
(b) the elements of an equitable, consistent and coherent alternative strategy to meet the immediate and short-term problems can be defined and agreed on a basis of consensus including-
(i) moderation of wage and non-wage incomes,
(ii) prices surveillance and the limitation of government charges,
(iii) demand generation and job-creation programs,
(iv) manpower planning, including immigration levels, and
(v) the employment effect of current levels of protection, and
(c) any legislative and administrative measures needed to implement a strategy of this kind can be determined'.

I began by saying that this country faces a very grave economic crisis of which the Government has suddenly become aware and becomes increasingly aware from day to day. In the solution of that crisis a number of people and a number of groups must assume responsibility. It is in that spirit that we commend to the Government the calling of such a conference to try to tackle some of the issues which are set down as an agenda in terms of what I have just read out to the Senate. We do not see the Government's wages freeze as the end of the world for anybody. We just see it as a totally inadequate solution to very serious problems and a totally feeble, limp wristed response to a very difficult situation which this country should try to solve with the utmost rapidity. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, has moved an amendment to the Salaries and Wage Pause Bill. I want to make some general comments with regard to the Government's proposals. The Government's initiative to impose a wages pause is directed to the domestic labour cost problem. It seeks to hasten correction of the wage profit imbalance and seeks to share more fairly the decline in Australia's living standards flowing from circumstances beyond our control. In the private sector a wages pause would operate directly to improve profitabiity and consequently improve employment prospects more quickly than otherwise would be possible. In the public sector a wages pause would ensure that employees with job security would not encourage further wage rises in the private sector where they could not be afforded without further losses of employment. The pause would allow funds already budgeted to be used for more employment and activity-related purposes rather than just to finance higher costs of existing public sector employment. One of the Bills before the Senate this afternoon is for the appropriation of $300m which will result from the public sector wage freeze.

SPEECH.PARA: The initiative of a wages pause has been objected to on the grounds that it is unfair not to have a prices pause at the same time. I want to say quite briefly that a prices pause would be inappropriate because wages have already increased substantially faster than prices. Even if there were a fully effective wages pause without a prices pause for a full 12-month period it would still fall well short of unwinding the cost disadvantages suffered by industry over the last two years or so. One of the main objectives of the wages pause is to improve profits so that the ability of companies to maintain their labour force is improved. Profits have already had to suffer too much of the burden of the decline in national income and this has intensified the downturn and the rise in unemployment. Market forces are already operating to restrain price increases. Mortgage interest rates and interest rates for small overdrafts are already held below market levels. Any further reductions, if they are to be sustained, will require reduced inflationary expectations and restrained public sector financial demands.

Another objection that we have heard to the wages pause is that reducing real wages would reduce effective demand and further slow economic activity. However, it is obviously not true that increased household income would increase demand. Disposable incomes, particularly wages, have been increasing and yet, because consumer confidence has declined, it is savings that have increased, not consumption. Investment demand has also gone down because the increase in income has been at the expense of profits. Maintaining real wage rates would not mean that total disposable income would be maintained. If real wages were maintained at excessive levels, profitability would remain inadequate and employers would have no incentive to retain staff, let alone recruit more staff. Thus, unemployment would continue to increase and total disposable income would decrease.

The wage pause would act to benefit and not to lower the level of activity because the wage increases forgone by the vast majority who still have jobs would be available to increase employment prospects for others. Total real household disposable income would be increased in a sustainable way as private sector employment responded to reduced real labour costs and the existing labour force would be used more intensively, reversing the recent increase in part time employment at the expense of full time jobs. Further, the rate of inflation moderates as profitability improves, thereby cushioning the impact of the wage pause on real wage rates.

There are other aspects such as the reduction in average income tax rates further cushioning the effect of the wage pause on per capita real household disposable income. Reduced costs and, ultimately, inflation pressures would operate to improve Australia's competitive position, increasing the extent to which domestic and overseas demand was directed to Australian production and enhancing prospects for reduced interest rates. Business and consumer confidence would be improved as a result of all of these factors, thus leading to increased consumption and investment spending from incomes and profits.

I want to make a couple of other comments in the fairly limited time that I am able to spend on this matter. Arguments have been advanced in respect of labour costs. I think that Senator Button said in his speech that wage moderation is a desirable thing. I want to put down some of the figures that have been used recently by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and to draw attention to the fact that over the two years to the September quarter of 1982 average weekly earnings for male employees increased by 29.7 per cent whereas in the same period the consumer price index increased by 22.4 per cent and manufacturing output prices increased by 18.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you deal with the argument about what average weekly earnings means?

— I am using the average figure. I think if we are going to use some figures average weekly earnings have to have some relevance to the overall position of the manufacturer or the employer who has a range of employees, many of whom are at different wage levels and so on. Average weekly earnings is a figure that is used very often statistically. It has a meaning and a relevance that I think can be applied in this case.
—I am just querying whether you understand the argument about its appropriateness at the present time.

— I can see that we could take a particular employee. If he were a high level employee or a low level employee we would then be talking about something other than the average. I think that point can be conceded for whatever purpose it might be used. But if we want to look at the overall position of the employer, we should compare average weekly earnings with profitability and the consumer price increases over a period.
—Do you concede that 400,000 lower paid workers have been taken out of the average weekly earnings calculations by unemployment?
—Yes, I could concede that. But not all of the unemployed are in the lowest income group either. People in all sorts of positions have been finding it increasingly difficult to retain-
—I said 400,000. I did not say all the unemployed.

— I realise that. The increase in average award rates, which does not reflect compositional changes in the labour force or changes in overtime working, amounted to 24.8 per cent for males over the same period. Increases in hourly labour costs have been even higher because of reductions in standard weekly working hours, particularly in manufacturing industry. Wage increases already awarded this year would project a rise in average weekly earnings of around 10 per cent. The increase for the full year, in the absence of a wages pause, is forecast at 11.5 per cent. If there were a fairly effective wages pause the rise this year might be held as low as 10.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Primarily as a result of pressures from labour costs, including their effects on government authorities' budgets, inflation in Australia has accelerated from an already unacceptably high level. The gross non-farm profit deflator increased at a rate of 14 per cent in the six months to September following an increase of 11.5 per cent in the preceding six months. In the year to the September quarter the consumer price index accelerated to 12.3 per cent. The increase in final consumption prices, however, has been restrained by export prices and farm prices with the implicit deflator of gross farm product declining by 10.7 per cent and the implicit deflator for exports of goods and services increasing by only 5.1 per cent in the six months to September. In contrast, price and wage increases overseas have continued to moderate. In the year to the September quarter consumer price increases averaged about 6 per cent amongst Australia's major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners.

We find then that the very large increases in labour costs in Australia have played a major part in cutting back business cash flow and profitability. The gross operating surplus of companies fell at a rate of 10 per cent in the six months to March 1982 and still further in the six months to September. There has consequently been a dramatic fall in the share of national product going to profits. In the half year to September the share of gross operating surplus of companies and financial enterprises in non-farm product fell to an historically low level of 12.7 per cent.

Those are some of the facts and figures that I wanted to put down. But my main purpose is to speak briefly on the employment related programs under the Bill which is before the Senate at present. The purpose of this Special Employment- related Programs Bill is to give effect to the announcement following the Premiers Conference on 7 December that the Commonwealth will fund programs designed to generate or maintain employment throughout Australia. It is intended that these programs will be financed from the savings in Commonwealth outlays from an effective national wage pause in 1983. An amount of up to $300m-the estimated saving-is appropriated under this Bill for this purpose.

The Bill provides for the Government to spend an amount consistent with the savings actually achieved. Estimates indicate that savings in Commonwealth outlays for the remainder of 1982-83 and for the first half of 1983-84 from a national 1983 wage pause could be of the order of $300m. That is a gross amount with no deduction having been made for taxation receipts which otherwise would have accrued to the Commonwealth. The estimate is based on the expected balance of the bulk allowances for wage and salary increases provided for in the Commonwealth's 1982-83 Budget; the allowance for notional wage increases forgone in the first half of 1983-84; and Commonwealth savings resulting from a 1983 wage pause in Australia's primary, secondary and tertiary teaching sectors.

The Bill provides for expenditure by the Commonwealth itself throughout Australia and also for grants and advances of grants to be made to the State and Northern Territory governments and, through appropriate mechanisms, to local government authorities for the purpose of funding special programs. In determining the allocation of any funds to States the Commonwealth will take into account factors such as population and the ability of State governments to identify and facilitate work on worthwhile programs. The Government has already announced that it has decided that $100m will be allocated for welfare housing. Full details of this decision were contained in a Press release and a statement by my colleague the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) earlier this week. Other projects which would meet the eligibility criteria include such things as the acceleration of capital works already under construction; repairs to and maintenance of existing plant, machinery, roads and buildings; minor works; and a number of things which we think will come forward from the States as being their priorities for expenditure that they believe would provide employment to the greatest extent possible.

Programs financed under this legislation will have beneficial effects in the Australian community in direct employment generation; the second round effect will be the indirect employment that flows from them, and that will facilitate the completion of worthwhile projects. I think that the expenditure which will be undertaken as a result of this Bill will share the burden between those who have job security in the public sector and those who may have insecurity of employment in the private sector or no employment at all. It is for these reasons that the Commonwealth has decided that this expenditure will be undertaken related to the period of the pause. Expenditure can be undertaken up to 30 June 1984. It is for all of these reasons that I commend the Bills to the Senate. I hope that they have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill and the Special Employment-related Programs Bill with some reluctance and some reservation. We note that the economy presently is in crisis, and this is the Government's response to that crisis after consultation with all Premiers. A rare occurrence took place. As we understand it unanimity prevailed at the meeting of the six State Premiers, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the Federal Government on the concept of a wage pause or, as Senator Sir John Carrick cleverly described it, the cessation of an upward movement in the wage area. Unemployment is expected to pass the 10 per cent mark in a matter of weeks, investment expenditure will fall by approximately 30 per cent and gross domestic product will be down 2 per cent. In other words the economy as a whole will contract.

SPEECH.PARA: Our adverse balance of trade will continue, offset only by a record foreign capital inflow. At present we are borrowing money or selling the farm, factory or store just to avoid bankruptcy, a fate overtaking many an otherwise sound business. That is a brief description of the economic scene in Australia today. Clearly some action had to be taken and this is the elected government's proposed action to the state of crisis. The Democrats say that it is not enough and that it is tackling only a small portion of the problem. We, as a party with five senators out of 64, with five members out of 190-odd federal members of parliament, have been presented with this legislation which, according to the Government, will assist in alleviating the present economic chaos that surrounds this country.

What rights would obtain to us as a small party in being disruptive? We take the view that the Government is elected to govern. We believe that the Government is largely responsible for the chaos which we are in, and it is only fair to give the Government an opportunity to get us out of that chaos. That might be an over-simplistic reaction to the situation; but let me put the alternative to the Senate. The Australian Labor Party is opposing the legislation. That is rather predictable because this is legislation which, by itself, calls for a freeze on Public Service wages. The Labor Party, with its close affiliation with the trade union movement and with the members of the Public Service, is virtually bound to oppose such a unilateral action. I can understand its action and I can understand its dilemma.

What would happen if the Australian Democrats joined with the 27 Labor senators in opposing this legislation? It would mean that the vote of Senator Harradine would be irrelevant. I am not saying Senator Harradine is irrelevant, I am just saying that the Democrat vote, combined with that of the Labor Party, would be enough to destroy this legislation. That would inevitably, as from tonight or this afternoon when the legislation was defeated, create early election speculation the like of which this country has never known. God knows it has known enough speculation on early elections over the last several years. It has almost been promoted to an art form by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and his Office.

The Democrats, on their undertaking that they would not be obstructive to government, find themselves in a situation where the country is in chaos. We are not just talking about some itsy bitsy Bill to cure something in the Health Act or the Social Services Act; we are talking about the whole economy in which hundreds of thousands of people are unemployed and this elected Government has come up with its solution. We say who are we to say at this stage: 'No, you cannot go ahead with your solution'? We say to the Government: 'We wish you luck , Government; we hope that this solution of yours will work. We hope that these measures will alleviate suffering and unemployment and will promote activity'. However, we say to it just as forcefully: 'If this does not work then you will meet your masters at an early opportunity in the New Year', because I would have thought that that will be when the next election is held. If these measures are not working, or seen to be working, by May, then it will have to meet its inevitable fate. In that way, I believe the Democrats are playing their part in the democratic process by not obstructing the will of government on something important and allowing the voters to judge it by its performance or lack of performance, or the lack of results of this particular legislation.

However, the legislation does have some positive features. To a minor extent the costs of our export or import competing industries will be contained or reduced and our international competitiveness will be improved. That argument the Government has been using, and that argument is unassailable. The extent to which our competitiveness will be improved, the extent to which our exports will increase and the number of jobs which will thereby be created will be open to observation as the wage pause unfolds. Theoretically, anyway, that is a positive aspect of the wage pause. The responsibility and initiative of this measure must rest with the Government and it must take responsibility for the success or failure of the legislation.

I must raise an objection-not that it does any good these days-to the handling of this legislation. It is unfortunate, to say the least, that this legislation is being debated on the last day the Senate sits and after the Members of the House of Representatives have gone home. An honourable senator or a party may have believed that it could move amendments to this legislation which could improve it or correct injustices. The Democrats have several ideas, as no doubt do other honourable senators. We are concerned, for example, about the raw deal we believe pharmacists are getting out of this legislation. We cannot see the justice of a situation in which we tell pharmacists throughout the country that their income is to be pegged, as from the passage of this legislation, for the next 12 months. We may grant their shop assistants an increase, thus adding to their costs, but pharmacists' total income is virtually limited. We cannot say that while saying to members of the medical profession that there is no real limit on the extent to which they can increase their fees. I know that the amount that is to be paid out of Commonwealth revenue is pegged, but there is no limitation on what doctors can charge. If doctors in any community can get together and charge X per cent over the prescribed fee, as they do, the patients in that locality, particularly in rural areas, have no choice but to be hit with extra expenses. That is the injustice of pegging wages and salaries and yet allowing one section of the community or some sections of the community an unlimited opportunity of increasing their income.

I now refer to an amendment that might be moved. Let us assume that it is a responsible one. What would members of the Press Gallery say of the Democrats, Senator Harradine or a member of the Australian Labor Party who moved an amendment which resulted in the House of Representatives being recalled? Conduct which brought the House of Representatives back-and, if it came back, it would probably vote on party lines anyway-and which cost the taxpayers thousands of dollars would be labelled irresponsible. And the whole exercise would be fruitless.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might give you a chance on the heritage Bill.

—Yes. The exercise this afternoon is essentially an academic one, and I object to it. Reducing wages and living standards, which this Bill will do , is certainly a way of increasing productivity. We get greater output per dollar per person not only because people are working the same hours for less real money but also because in the circumstances the fear of God is put into everybody who is working and those people work harder for fear of losing their job. That is a method, described in some of the right wing economic textbooks, of improving and increasing productivity. But the Government continues to neglect the other positive way; it opts for the negative way each time. The positive way, surely, is the introduction of high technology accompanied by retraining, compensation, taxation reform, income support schemes and transition measures which turn the potential catastrophe of technological change into a positive growth factor. We believe in the stimulation of the economy. I am most regretful when I think of my friend and colleague Senator Siddons who, in August of this year, put forward an alternative Budget which provided for a deficit of $4 billion. What did the Liberal Party say? It said: 'A deficit of $4 billion is a recipe for--
—Economic collapse.
—'Economic collapse'. That is a smart-Alick political comment dreamt up by that dreadful little man over at Liberal Party headquarters, whatever his name is.
—'Falcon', isn't it, or something like that?

—No, that is not his name. The Siddons Democrat alternative Budget proposed for the deficit to be spent on job creating schemes. While we had the ball at our feet, the Democrats said: 'Let us kick it in the right direction and let us kick a goal with it. Sure, it will cost $4 billion in the short run; but, by generating employment and by creating jobs, we will soon turn the deficit into a surplus by reducing the amount that we have to pay out in unemployment benefits and increasing the amount that goes into the Department of the Treasury through taxes paid by employed persons who presently are unemployed'. We then had the ball at our feet, even as late as last August. But the Government said no, and it went around creating a most dreadful Budget which did nothing. It was an election Budget which set the scenario for the Prime Minister to call an election on, I think, 18 September, from which subsequently he withdrew. But now we have a Budget deficit of $4.7 billion--
—Four.
—It is $3.7 billion, up to four.

—Can I have an even $5 with both the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that by the end of the year the deficit will be nearer $5 billion than $4 billion? I will give the Ministers odds if they feel so inclined. I stick to saying that it will be nearer $5 billion, frittered away not on constructive job -creating activities, such as stimulation of the housing industry, but on paying extra unemployment benefit because of the growing pool of unemployed. The Government has embarked upon a self-defeating Catch-22 exercise because the deficit will inevitably get bigger, paying more people unemployment benefit and having fewer people paying more people who are unemployed. That is the downward spiral in which we find ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: One other positive feature of the present legislation is that the funds saved will be used for job creation programs. This is what the Australian Democrats have been advocating; it is what Senator Siddons advocated back in August, which has not been done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hawke has been advocating it for the same length of time.

—And Mr Hawke and the Labor Party have been advocating it. We have been advocating it for the last three years, both of us. But let us give credit where it is due. This will produce $300m for job creation programs, $100m of which will be earmarked for welfare housing. I am sorry; one should not use the expression 'welfare housing'. I warn the Ministers never to use that term publicly now. The term is 'public housing'. However, if it is the purpose of the exercise to reduce costs, surely the measure does not go far enough and an excessive burden will be placed upon one group-wage and salary earners. For that reason, the Democrats will press for certain measures. I am now speaking to Senator Button's amendment. I give notice, Mr Acting Deputy President, that when that is disposed of, one way or the other, I shall move an amendment which I foreshadow now but I will not speak on at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: In that amendment the Democrats will be pressing for a moratorium on government charges. We shall move that for one year a moratorium be placed on rises in petrol prices. We shall ask the Labor Party to join us-it did not do so last time-in voting against the validating Bill on the increase in excise on petrol. That is a classic example of where we can assist those wage and salary earners who will be affected by a wage freeze by saving them something out of their pockets. We could say to them tonight, with the support of the Labor Party if it supports our amendment, that there will be no increases in petrol prices for the next 12 months. This Senate has the power in its hands tonight to do that. We would want a moratorium on sales taxes, and again, the Senate has that power. We would want a moratorium on increases in telephone and postal charges. Where is the justice of saying to one section of the community: 'Wage and salary earners, we shall peg your wages but we shall jack up costs of postage stamps and telephone charges and raise sales taxes and the price of petrol'?

We shall be asking the Senate to force the Government to take effective measures to freeze professional fees, those of doctors, lawyers, accountants and so on. We contemplated moving an amendment in Committee to peg doctors' fees. It is an amendment that attracted the Democrats strongly. We ask again: Where is the justice of freezing wages and salaries but saying to doctors 'You can charge what you like'? We have found that it is legislatively and constitutionally possible for this Parliament to peg doctors' fees if doctors want to remain within the National Health Scheme. After hours of deliberation the Democrats have reluctantly resiled from that idea because apparently the only way in which we could do that would put the patient at risk. The only way in which we could peg doctors' fees-I remember Sir John Gorton trying to do this in 1971-72-would be by legislation, which could have tacked on to this legislation, saying that if a patient went to a doctor who charged above the schedule fee, as outlined in the National Health Act, no benefit would be paid to the patient.

On the surface that seems fair. One could say that that would be a beaut way to control doctors. But then a mother who has a child with a stomach ache or whatever may want to go to her local doctor. The child is ailing and in pain. The mother would see a sign, if she is lucky, saying that schedule fees are not charged by the practices. What does she do? She has two choices. She can leave the doctor's surgery and shop around the suburb with a sick child looking for a doctor who charges the schedule fee or she can pay the doctor his fee and get no reimbursement from the health fund or the Commonwealth, notwithstanding the fact that she might be a fully paid up member of a health fund. Although that scheme would effectively prevent doctors from charging above the schedule fee it seems to me that in many cases it would, result in an injustice being impacted up on patients and particularly on patients who cannot afford it.

We wish the Government well in its endeavours with its request to doctors and professional groups not to charge higher fees. We will be looking for the revival of the Prices Justification Tribunal to prevent profiteering and to keep down living costs or the cost of the necessities of life. We will be pressing for the passage of the Bank and Financial Corporations (Overdraft and Loan Charges) Bill I introduced yesterday, which refers to bank interest charges. Do honourable senators know that banks, by surreptitious means, by charging overdraft service fees, account charges and all sorts of other charges under different euphemisms, in reality increase the real price of interest they charge on their money-at times by one per cent or 2 per cent-again for people who cannot afford it? If these measures are taken, the limited objective of the exercise-containing costs-will at least be pursued in an efficient and equitable manner.

Presently the order books are empty. Employers will not start employing more people just because wages have stopped rising. They will employ more people only if there is an increased demand for the goods and services they produce. Unfortunately, the Government is taking no action whatsoever in this area. The Democrats will press for increased government expenditure as a pump primer to generate more demand. We will push for selective, temporary import quotas to enable Australian industry to survive and to restructure. We will press for the investment allowance to discriminate in favour of Australian made goods. Above all, we will press for a concerted all-party effort to create a framework for the social, economic and financial charges necessary to use high technology to Australia's advantage. In the short term this pulling together is necessary just to deal effectively with the immediate economic crisis.

In conclusion, I want to put a preposterous and outrageous proposition to the Senate. The magnitude of the crisis in which we find ourselves is not known. I do not know that anybody fully appreciates how bad the present problems are, who created them, what the proper solutions are or how soon we can get out of them. I do not know and I do not pretend to know. Maybe smarter people in the Treasury and government departments know that. I certainly do not know. What I do know is that more people are unemployed today than at any time since the Depression. Interest rates are rising and our overseas market outlook is dismal. I would have thought extraordinary measures were needed to overcome this sort of crisis. I am in sympathy with the Government in the limited action it has taken with this wages pause. It could have done more. In the present political climate, with political parties confronting one another, with the Government being confronted by the trade union movement-a government strangely reluctant to confer and consult with the trade union movement-I cannot see any solution to the present chaotic conditions with this legislation or with anything that any Government Minister has said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, do you think that if the United States economy picked up under a Democrat President there might be a flow-on to other countries , unlike the situation with the Republican concept of finance?

—I do not deny that that would have a beneficial effect on Australia, but I certainly do not believe it is the answer to the basic problems we have. A technological revolution is occurring in this world which is decimating jobs and putting human beings permanently out of work. That technology revolution is not being addressed by anybody in this country of any significance.
—It's not being addressed by this Bill. That's what I was just about to say.

—I acknowledge Senator Harradine's interjection and thoroughly agree with it. The outrageous suggestion I make is that instead of talking about an early election and creating political instability and confrontation early in February, which will occur if these measures do not work, why do we not at least discuss the possibility of having some political stability for 12 or 15 months? God knows, I would not care if the voters of Victoria dispatched me to retirement tomorrow. I am not looking for an extended time in this place. Twenty -two years is long enough. What would honourable senators think of a proposition to extend the lifetime of this Parliament until about March 1984-I understand that is constitutionally possible-and for the next six or nine months call off politics and have a moritorium on political activity in this country? Why do we not consider adopting the War Cabinet concept for nine months? It is not my idea . It was an idea put up by an incredibly distinguished group of Australians-Sir Barton Pope, Sir Mark Oliphant and Sir Macfarlane Burnet. I would have thought that those names would at least command respect. They are people who have no axe to grind. What if we could forget politics for even six months? What if some distinguished members of the Australian Labor Party-one could mention Mr Hayden, Mr Lionel Bowen, Mr Hawke, Mr Keating, Senator Button and Senator Grimes-were asked to join a Cabinet?

SPEECH.PARA: The intellectual giants around me are scoffing at the proposal. They can afford to do so, of course, because they bring innovative and new ideas into this place every day! They can afford to scoff at new ideas! I leave the intellectual giants to themselves. I just ask-I am not hopeful that my request will receive too much thoughtful debate in this place but at least it may receive consideration from the public-that for six months at least we have an Executive made up of members of at least the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party with Parliament acting as a check and balance. I say to Senator Button that then there would be effective opposition. Parliament would then at least have a chance of acting as a parliament and not as a rubber stamp for the Executive. At least we could have some sort of consultation between the trade union movement, the employers and all political parties. If another honourable senator has a better, more constructive idea on how to get Australia out of this crisis-I have yet to hear one in this debate-let him or her put it forward. I do not put forward my idea as a serious proposition, but as something to stimulate thought towards a solution of a problem that may engulf 30 per cent of Australians before the end of next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words on the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill. This Bill has been designed for several reasons. The main reason is to reduce wages. In the last depression, in the early 1930s, a conservative government brought down a wage reduction of 10 per cent. This Bill will do a similar thing but in a much more devious way. It will reduce wages by at least 12 per cent over a 12-month period. The Government thinks that it is being very smart doing this. As I said, the legislation is very devious. It will bring further recession to this country. People do not trust this Government. Personal savings in this country are exceptionally high. We must ask ourselves why that is. It is simply because people do not trust this Government. They feel that they have to save rather than spend. That is one of the reasons we have such a big depression at present. Thousands of people daily are losing their jobs. People are putting off buying the commodities that they would normally buy because they fear that they will lose their jobs. There is no security in the country. That is the main reason for the current situation. It is costing this Government untold millions of dollars in unemployment benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: The wage pause will do nothing to stimulate growth and employment. Unemployment is at an historically high level. Imports are flooding into the country and have been allowed to overwhelm our own industries, which have been discarded by this Government. Local production has not been encouraged. We have only to look at the increased trade deficit. This year our trade deficit will be $9,000m. Exports will rise by only some 2 per cent. That is absolutely ridiculous. What has this Government done? It has changed the guidelines for exporting firms. There is no long term arrangement for the export of goods from this country. Nobody can cope if the guidelines keep changing. Manufacturers find that they must reduce their labour force.

If this country was managed correctly, and if everyone worked together profits could be increased. With higher profits we could certainly increase wages. That is what we should be thinking about. This country is probably in the best position of any country in the world today. We have a very small population of 15 million people and the majority of them are reasonably healthy and well educated. We have resources in this country to manufacture into the goods that we need. There is no need for the present level of unemployment. It is impossible for workers to have any confidence in the Government. The structure of the family is being destroyed. Thousands of people every day are finding themselves out of work. If young people do not have work-it does not matter whether they are my children or anybody else's-and take their place in society they will be destroyed. The Government is destroying the family structure but nobody cares. During the war this country pulled itself up by its bootstraps. We started to manufacture goods that we never thought we could manufacture. Yet today we are allowing imports in untold quantities. We can match any other manufacturing country in the world.

This Government has done nothing to bring about reasonable negotiations between employers and employees. It wants to create trouble and confrontation all the time. It is bring down legislation which causes disruption to the trade union movement and the employers. The Government does not want peace in the work force . It is using disruption and unrest for its own political ends. This is what happens to a nation when the people are deceived. This country has almost ground to a halt. Yet we live in what is most certainly the best country in the world. If a government cannot manage this country, it could not manage a peanut stall. This is a wealthy country. As I said, we have well educated, healthy people. We grow all the food that we need. We are able to manufacture goods. We have marvellous resources and energy reserves, yet we find ourselves in trouble. It is unbelievable that a country such as Australia could be brought to its knees. But it is slowly grinding to a halt and the situation will not improve.

Some industries in this country have managed, with co-operation between management and labour, to achieve great things. I mentioned, for example, Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd which is probably the most competitive company in the rag trade. There is no more competitive company in that field. It continues to grow and to make a marvellous product. All of the workers participate in that company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Best value for money.

—It does provide the best value for money. There is no doubt about that. The quality of its product is equal to any in the world. That example shows that it is possible to be competitive with co-operation between Australian management and labour. When the Australian Labor Party was in government it set up the Trade Union Training Authority and established Clyde Cameron College to train people in unions. That policy has been very successful. This Government should have set up educational centres to train management. Australian management, on the whole, is deplorable. It has created great unrest and trouble in this country. This Government has seen no value in following the example set by the Labor Government. Instead, it has introduced a wages pause which will do nothing to improve the condition of this country. It there were an honest and sincere attempt to get unions, management, financiers, business people and politicians of all sides together, as Senator Chipp has suggested, there would be a sincere attempt to do something about the present situation. All political parties would go out of their way if they believed the Government was making an honest and sincere attempt to do something about the situation. But this Government is not sincere and this plan cannot work.

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago I asked a question relating to averages. The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) said that she believed in averages. I raised the example of a person earning $200 a week, a semi-skilled worker earning $300 and a professional person earning $400 a week. The average in that case is $300. But let us say that the chap on the lower rung of the ladder, the unskilled worker, loses his job, as is happening today. There are then only two people employed, one earning $300 a week and one earning $400 a week. The average immediately rises from $300 to $350. No one is being paid any more money. There is no more money in the community, there is less; and yet we can prove that the average rises. Averaging is honest when there is full employment but it is totally dishonest and we cannot work on it when large numbers of people are unemployed. In those circumstances it is ridiculous to work on averages.

I think it is about time we looked at some innovative ideas. Many years ago President Roosevelt pulled America out of the doldrums. America achieved that recovery by using its own resources. We could do it. I have always been a democratic socialist. If I went out into the country and built myself a home out of the natural products of the land, this country would have to be more valuable because I had produced something from nature. As a national community, can we not build better railways, roads, air facilities, water conservation schemes? We cannot say that that has not been done. The east-west railway line has been constructed. This country is dying on its feet. To say that we do not have enough money to do these things is ridiculous. If a war were to break out tomorrow, in Australia overnight billions of dollars would appear as if by magic . But we cannot find a couple of thousand million dollars-and that is nothing, it is peanuts-to put people back to work.

In consultation with industry we could establish sensible guidelines that people would trust. We could talk to people. If we could get the people to trust the Government they would start spending some of the money they are hoarding up. That would get people back to work. This Government thinks that it can cure the ills of this country by introducing legislation such as this. But conciliation and consultation is the only way in which we can do that. There is no one person in this country or any other country who can overcome these problems. Politicians can only suggest the guidelines but we must get the co-operation of all members of the community. If we do not do that this country will never pull itself up by its bootstraps. Over the years Australian workers have proved themselves to be as good as or better than anyone in the world. We are innovative but we are not using our skills. I believe we should be using our high technology skills. We should be educating people to go into other fields. We are not doing this. Over many years this Government has allowed the ownership of this country to slip away from Australians to overseas. We do not even own this country, and that upsets me. I know that it upsets a lot of other people. If we are to have pride in our country, we must own a part of it. Unless we do we will get nowhere.

The general public really does not have anything to hang on to now. Everyone fears that he will lose his home. This Government has kept interest rates at such a level that foreign money comes into the country not for development but to take advantage of those high rates. That is killing our own people. By keeping interest rates up this Government has made it very difficult for young people in this country to repay the loans on their homes. Whether or not they pay money out of interest rates, people have to get an income. They do not want charity. They do not want to live on the dole or unemployment benefit. That is not our way of life. The average Australian wants to work, wants to participate and wants decent leadership, which he is not getting. I think that is a great tragedy.

The trade union movement has been knocked over many years just for political ends. The trade union movement over many years has managed at least to give the Australian people an equitable distribution of wealth. Let us not forget that. If honorable senators doubt that, let them look at the countries where unions are not allowed. They will find that the wealth belongs to about 10 per cent of the people. In this country the situation is getting worse, and the wealthy are becoming wealthier. This wage pause will do nothing to a person like me on a good salary. It will not hurt many people in the community, including doctors, lawyers, architects and other professional people. But it will hurt the little people. Honourable senators should talk to the car drivers who earn just a little over $200 a week. By the time they pay their tax and their medical fund contributions they have nothing left. The Government is saying that it is fair for them to have a wage pause. I think that is ridiculous. It is fair enough for me to have a wage pause, but it is not fair for people on the lower income rungs to have a wage pause. It is not a wage pause. The Government is simply taking out of their pockets money which they cannot afford. Interest rates will go up. Every time one goes into a supermarket these days one finds that prices have gone up from last week. People with families are almost destitute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most supermarkets stacked their prices in case we had a price freeze.
