—That is true, but there is no such thing as a price freeze. It is impossible to have one. During the referendum on prices and incomes control, Mr Anthony said:

SPEECH.PARA: What incentive is there to work harder, to produce more, if your wages are controlled?
He said that in 1973. Senator Sir John Carrick said:
If you give the government the power to control prices, you certainly give it power to control wages. Wages are obviously a price-the price of your energies and skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Sir John Carrick said that on 28 November 1973. It is all gimmickry, and it is just impossible for people to live. Nobody can say that the world economic situation does not affect Australia. We would agree with that . No one can say the drought has not had its effects. We agree with that. The main problem with this country is this Government-its obstinacy in making political points, in trying to run things by legislation and in always blaming the unions and the little people. It has let the tax dodgers get away with it for years. It is the little people who have had to pay the extra money in tax. They will never get it back. It will not benefit them. Any money that the Government gets will never go back into the pockets of the little people. It is the big people in this country, the scoundrels, who do not pay tax. The small people are carrying this country. It is about time this Government considered the small people, the people who take off their coats and do the work of this nation. It is about time we started to think of them.

SPEECH.PARA: This wage pause is plain gimmickry. It is nothing more nor less. It is not a pause; it as a wage reduction. It will be a wage reduction of at least 12 per cent because of inflation; it may be more. The people affected are not expected to get a catch-up wage increase after 12 months. It is just not on. More divisions within the community will be created. In the past this Government has created divisions. That is one of the main reasons for the difficulties which we face. Australians are more divided today than they were after the Kerr incident of 1975 which honourable senators opposite created. Unless somebody unites this nation of Australia we will not get anywhere. We cannot become united if part of Australia pulls one way and the rest pulls the other way. That is no way to bring about conciliation and consultation. If there were a genuine desire to overcome the difficulties there would be co-operation on all sides of Parliament . We would be making approaches to the trade union movement, management and everyone else involved. This could be done collectively, but this Government is not prepared to do so. The Opposition opposes these Bills. The amendment should be considered most certainly by the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. I hope it is considered by them. I hope there is some conciliation and further talks are held. I would not mind bringing the House of Representatives back. These Bills should be tossed out entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate seems to be in an atmosphere of unrealism due to the fact that we all know that these two Bills, the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill 1982 and the Special Employment-related Programs Bill 1982, will be passed by the Senate because the Australian Democrats have indicated that they will not block the Bills. They have indicated that although some amendments were desirable to the Bills, on reflection they should not be moved because the House of Representatives has risen.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to enter this debate to talk about the problem of unemployment. The measures before us may result in temporary job creation but, in my view, they will result in long term job destruction. The measures do not address themselves to the issue of structural unemployment within Australia. One thing is certain: The proposals will not work because they are not based on a recognition of the fundamental problems of unemployment within Australia nor are they based on a recognition of the economic realities and challenges with which Australia is faced. We are in a totally different situation today than we were in 1972, 1973 and 1974. The application of economic measures alone to the problems today will not have the same effect as it may well have had in 1972, 1973 or 1974. I very much doubt that the prescription which has been developed by the Government is in fact economically vindicated.

It is true that for far too long Australia has allowed costs and prices to escalate with consequent rapid erosion of the value of money. Even the automatic adjustments in pensions have been insufficient to offset the effects of inflation on a large number of pensioners, let alone on other sections of the community. I wonder whether the Government has given any consideration to its foreign exchange policies, because the flexible peg exchange rate system implies nothing about the particular balance of payments objectives of the Government and their application to the problems of unemployment in this country. The Government contents itself with pointing out that whilst prices as measured by the consumer price index have increased by something like 12.3 per cent in the past 12 months, average weekly earnings have risen by, according to the Government, 16.9 per cent to $335. But as I have pointed out before, that figure includes earnings of highly paid executives and politicians. Most workers on award wages are receiving something like $100 below that average weekly earnings figure; so they are receiving about $229 a week. It has been said in this debate -quite justifiably-that the higher salary earners have received a comparative increase in real terms in the last six years but at the lower end of the scale there has been an 11.4 per cent reduction.

I have stated in this chamber before that there is a need for an examination of the wage structure. One good thing that may emerge from the discussions now taking place is that this examination may well take place and that we might find ourselves back in a central wage fixing arena. One of the reasons that the higher salaried people have received such an increase over the last six years has been that there is in place within Australia, and has been since 1967, a total wage concept. In 1967 the basic wage and margins concept was abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should return to it.

—I agree with it. It was abandoned. I vigorously opposed the abandonment of the basic wage and margins concept at that time. Since then, increases on economic grounds generally applied as a percentage of total wages have tended to favour those on higher salaries. I have always considered it most odd that a salaried employee on, for example, $600 a week receives a $30 a week rise, while another worker on $200 a week, receives a $10 a week rise to compensate for the same five per cent increase in prices. The abolition of the total wage and the reintroduction of the two-tiered system would provide a structure wherein the blow-out of wages could more readily be contained, lower wage earners protected and margins for skills and responsibilities more visibly delineated. One of the beneficial results that may well come out of our concentration on the wages area is that we may well return to that two-tiered system and to central wage fixation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned, wages are only a very small part of the problem. What is the problem of unemployment with Australia? The problem is that more people are seeking paid work than there are jobs available and this is at the same time as new jobs continue to be slashed by technological changes. That is the simple problem. That is the problem that the Federal Government is not addressing itself to. The Government has concentrated solely on economic solutions. Unless we realise that the unemployment problem in Australia has social as well as economic aspects, Australia will continue to have soaring unemployment and we will unfortunately see by the end of next year over one million permanently unemployed. When I forecast some time ago that, during the 1980s, we would pass the half a million unemployed level, I suspect that there were a large number of people who raised their eyebrows and who thought at that stage that I was being negative. What I am saying today about the essential problem of unemployment, I have been saying for six years.

The preoccupation with economic solutions alone over that period has not addressed the real problem. What is the position now? In Australia, we will have 700,000 unemployed by the end of this month and an inflation rate of 12.3 per cent. Of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, we are the worst. What is the Government's answer? It is a wage pause, further economic medicine which was previously found not to be satisfactory. The Government visits the results of its absence of ideas on public servants and pharmacists, amongst others. It does not attack the real problem. Faced with the gloomy aspect that I have just mentioned, would honourable senators allow jobs to be destroyed by the wholesale application of automation and technological changes? Would honourable senators force people to stay in the paid work force- those people who have better reasons to be out of those jobs which could be taken by the unemployed? That is what is happening. That is the effect of the Government's policy. That is just plain crazy.

I turn now to the matter of automation and technological change. The Government 's proposals exacerbate the problem in that area. That is why I said at the beginning of my speech that the Government, under its present policy, might create some temporary jobs but its policy will result in long term job destruction. Mr President, may I deal with the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill and the Special Employment-related Programs Bill within the context of the whole of the Government's policy, including the submissions it made today to the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator.

—Thank you, Mr President. I think this is relevant. The Government's policy will increase profits. Workers will have their wages pegged. They will be producing the same amount of goods and services; therefore, the profits will go up. There is nothing wrong with profits. Anyone who discusses these matters around the traps will know that businessmen, manufacturers and entrepreneurs now are not investing in high technology or equipment because of the current cost of money, the high interest rates. But what will happen when interest rates fall and money becomes cheaper? They will rush to buy new technology. They will be assisted in their efforts by the Government's indiscriminate investment allowance policy. I use the word 'indiscriminate' because the policy applies equally to a retailer, a banker or a manufacturer competing with overseas manufacturers. One can see, of course, that there is room for the policy to apply in those areas in which we are in direct or indirect competition with overseas manufacturers. But one must question the wholesale application of automation and technological changes, for example, in the banking industry where we are not in direct competition with people overseas .

SPEECH.PARA: The money that will be poured into these areas by investment allowances and so on will result in job destruction. The profits gained from the wages freeze will be used along with the investment allowance, to employ more technology. Let us take the retail industry as another example. The Government's policy is quite unintelligible as far as this industry is concerned. It urges two things: An extension of trading hours which it has stated results in the destruction of full time jobs and encourages two-income familes and in fact, people to have two jobs. The other aspect around the corner is product code numbering. The Government's own investment allowance policy will be the cause of job destruction in that area. Should we allow jobs to be destroyed by the wholesale application of automation and technological change under these circumstances? Of course not. But that is what the Government is doing.

Let us look at the other social aspect of the problem. The Government is forcing people to stay in the paid work force. These people could have a reason to be out of the work force and the jobs they hold could be taken by the unemployed. The Government is not even prepared-I have not heard it say so, and I would like the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who represents the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, to tell me I am wrong-to have an in-depth study of the work force in Australia to find out who in the paid work force has a reason to be out of it. Many people in the paid work force at present wish to retire but are unable to do so because of the substantial reduction it would cause in their living standards. We should consider reducing the retiring age and providing for a voluntary phased-in retirement plan from, say, 55 years of age. By refusing to provide practical recognition of the economic worth of the homemaker, by exercising tax discrimination against the one-income family and by providing insufficient help for home buyers, the Government is forcing thousands of young married women and thousands more mothers to stay in the paid work force. Though there have been increases in family allowances, their value is eroding rapily by reason of inflation. On reflection, because family allowances are a high profile social security expenditure, I wonder whether it would not have been better to retain a low profile income tax deduction for children. Today's Daily Telegraph editorial, under the heading 'Two job families', states:
One of the factors contributing to unemployemnt in Australia remains the working women who is forced to take a job simply to make ends meet.

Families which need to have both adults working are possibly depriving another family of having even one member working. Of course, it is no solution to the problem to suggest that married women be made to stay at home. That would be sexist and totally unreasonable.

But research shows that around 60 per cent of working women do not wish to work and do so only because they need the money. They find it very difficult to be both breadwinner and mother and would gladly give up the job if they could afford to do so.
And the fact remains that half a million Australians are out of work-nearly 10 per cent-and that many of the jobs they could get are being filled by women earning an additional income.

The Federal Government must soon devise and consider some sort of scheme to allow the reluctant women workers to give up their jobs. For instance, it should not be difficult to introduce tax incentives and family allowances that would allow them to remain at home without great loss of family income.
If they could afford to stay at home it would open up areas for the jobless and ease the social problem of the latch-key children.
Such a scheme could be more effective and far more permanent than the expensive job creation schemes at present being considered by the Government.

I had not read all of that editorial before I quoted it. I have been discussing a number of these matters for a long time. Let us consider the number of full time school children in the paid work force. It may surprise honourable senators to know that the participation rate of full time school students between 15 and 19 years of age in the paid work force is 22.5 per cent. They are working an average of over nine hours a week. Obviously we cannot say that school kids should not have jobs such as paper runs, but quite a large number are working long hours in various areas such as the retail industry thereby taking jobs that others require. I give that as an example; there are many others. There are the greedy people, the two-jobbers. The Government is not prepared, apparently, to examine the structure of the paid work force to see who is in it and who has a good reason to be out of it.

I do not have much more time in which to speak. Actually, I had almost intended not to speak at all on this legislation because I was somewhat disgusted with the approach. Perhaps the legislation has some merit somewhere along the line, but it will have merit only if we combine it with other measures. I agree that there needs to be wage moderation. In fact, the trade union movement should have , central to its wages policy, the preservation of jobs. Nothing that I have said is meant to underestimate the obvious responsibilities of governments to create a legislative, economic, trading and taxation framework conducive to employment and to ensure infrastructure, notably power and transport. In addition, businesses, employers, trade unions, educational institutions, community groups and families each have a role to play in facing the social, as well as the economic, aspects of the employment problem. I agree that we ought to lay off politics for a while, but I do not quite agree with the way Senator Chipp put it. If I were Prime Minister I would declare that the Parliament would run its full term and call on everyone in the community to concentrate on solving our economic and social ills. Not only should we concentrate on solving our ills but also we must not forget that if we have economic and social ills certainly our near neighbours have those problems as well.

I turn very briefly to the amendments to the second reading of the Bill. I do not have much to say about these. I support them in the absence of anything tighter, but I believe that local government ought to be involved in the conference that has been suggested in the Australian Labor Party's amendment. I believe there is room for a community-led recovery. Many local government officials, who include businessmen, are experiencing unemployment in their own families. They are the ones who know the area. They know where the jobs are. I would have included reference to such persons in the amendment but no doubt that can be added at some stage. I will support the Opposition's amendment only on the clear understanding that I have been given that the word 'immigration', as used in paragraph (iv), is not meant in a racist sense. As I understand it, it simply deals with the question of skills. For example, companies should not advertise for rock drillers in the United Kingdom when Australia has rock drillers.

The Australian Democrat's amendment calls, among other things, for a freezing of sales taxes. Senator Chipp said that the Senate has the power to do that. If so, I wish that, when sales tax increases were introduced in the Budget, he had joined me in voting against them; but I suppose it is better late than never. As I understand it, this amendment really will not affect anything. I must say that I would not tie family allowance increases to oil parity price increases. That has been my stand over a long period. I hope that something will come out of this proposal but I suspect that unless the Government, by using a number of other measures, applies itself to the real nature of the problem there will be no long term effect; it will merely have an adverse long term effect on jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- The Senate is debating the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill and the accompanying Bill which provides for the appropriation of the moneys which the Government anticipates will be saved by the wages pause. That will be used to provide public works of a high employment content. There does appear to be agreement around the chamber that the Bill should be passed, though the reasons for agreement differ as between honourable senators. There is also agreement in the Senate about the need for wage moderation. It was interesting that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) put that view down as being the Opposition's official view and Senator Harradine put it down as being his view also.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the difficulties is that there has not been wage moderation in Australia . There has been some debate in the course of the second reading stage about the extent to which wages have risen. The Opposition challenged the use of the average weekly earnings rise over 12 months because of the unemployment which has occurred in that time and the number of lower paid workers who therefore have ceased to be counted as part of the average. Even if one accepted the heavily discounted figures cited by Senator Button one gets a situation of rising real wages during a year of falling profits-there is no dispute about that-and growing unemployment. I do not believe, even on the basis of the facts as put before the Senate by Senator Button, that one can say that there has been wage moderation to a point which is desirable.

This Bill is just one part of the Government's approach to Australia's current economic difficulties. Part of the approach is being played out in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission today when, for the first time, the Commonwealth, all the States and the Northern Territory are joined together in, we understand, a surprisingly common view that there does need to be a wage pause. Certainly, there are differences of view as to the period for which the pause should apply. Three States are arguing for six months; three States and a Territory for a year and the Commonwealth for a year. That is another part of the line which the Government is pursuing to meet Australia's current economic difficulties.

It is not, of course, a matter of saying that what is contained in these Bills is the sole answer. I would point to the changed attitude which was evidenced by the Commonwealth at the Premiers Conference held in the middle of the year; to the changed attitude which was evidenced by the Budget with increases in capital expenditure; and to the changed attitude which is evidenced in our increased capital expenditure under the companion legislation which is being dealt with today. All of this is part of the response of the Government to Australia's changing economic fortunes. I point to the industry package as being yet another part of the Government's approach.

We do not have time this afternoon to canvass every element of the Government's approach. But the fact is that the Government has responded across a wide range of policy areas and has changed the setting of its policies to meet what is admitted from all parts of the chamber to be a difficult situation. We had a speech from Senator Elstob, which I am sure was straight from the heart. I would share his concern about the effects of unemployment upon many families and individuals in Australia. We would all share that concern. But even he admitted in his quite compassionate speech that Australia faces external difficulties; that Australia faces difficulties brought about by the drought; that Australia faces some internal difficulties of its own making; and that the cost of wages, which have outstripped the capacity of our industry to pay, is one element of the problems which Australia faces. This Bill is one element of the Government's approach or attempt to come to grips with those problems.

I do not want to canvass every point that was made but this is an important issue for Australia; it is an important element of our overall approach to policy. I will, therefore, touch on at least some points which have been made by honourable senators in this debate, notwithstanding that they are proposing to support the passage of this Bill. Senator Button quoted a rather critical leading article in the Sydney Morning Herald which said that the sort of action the Government is taking was unlikely to be of assistance. In response, I would like to quote something from the Melbourne Age of 25 November which to me made much more sense. I do not wish to quote at very great length. However, I thought that the comment by Mr Terry McCrann, the business editor of the Age, encapsulates a lot of the thinking which is behind the Government's move in this legislation; I believe it encapsulates why what we are doing has such broad public support. Mr McCrann firstly drew attention to the situation in these words:

At a time when the average Australian is coming to realise, often through unhappy personal experience, that direct links do exist between excess wage rises, falling corporate profits and disappearing jobs, it is distressing that the nation's current alternative Prime Minister appears unable to accept this reality . . .

I think that that really is the nub of the debate which has taken place in this chamber this afternoon. There is a failure on the part of the Opposition to accept the relationship between those things. I would like to quote from the concluding part of that article because I think it again encapsulats from an independent viewpoint what needs to be said. Mr McCrann commented:

In very simple terms, the higher wages and salaries might well have created increased spending-subject to the tax leakage-but the overall effect across the nation was not as good because before many people could spend their higher incomes they were losing their jobs.
He went on to say:

. . . if Mr Hayden and his party, which lays claim to possessing the high ground of compassion in politics, wish to stem the rising tide of unemployment and put people back into jobs they will need to face two realities, one immediate, the other somewhat longer term.
The immediate one is the need for those still with jobs to give back part of the excess wage rises of the past two years through the mechanism of a wages freeze.

The longer-term reality is the need to remove the basic irritant in the wages- prices game: the intrusion of government and its appetite for 40 cents in each dollar of extra income across the economy.

I would agree very broadly with what Mr McCrann has said. I would say that it is entirely appropriate that people who are in employment in a difficult time ought to be prepared to forego the rises that they anticipate knowing, in the case of public servants, with their security of tenure, that that money would be used to create work for other Australians and, in the case of private industry employees , that wage increases foregone would go to provide profits which would guarantee continuity of employment and a fresh and new investment.

The point was made by Senator Button that this was a measure which imposed a massively inequitable burden on wage earners. I suggest to the Senate that that is no so. The massive inequity is between those Australians who do have work and those who do not. I believe that those of us who are fortunate enough to have work must be prepared to accept some sacrifice for those who do not.

I welcome the early part of Senator Chipp's speech in particular in which, I think, he fairly and squarely placed the responsibility for what action ought to be taken in these difficult circumstances upon the Government. I respectfully endorse the views which he put before the Senate, that it is proper for the Government to determine a course and to have the opportunity to follow that course. He drew attention to the fact that in the end we will be judged by the electorate on the success, on the appropriateness of that course. I believe that is a proper assessment of the situation. I thank the Australian Democrats on this occasion for adopting what I think is a proper course. They are entitled to be critical but they allow the Government to get on with the job in the way in which the Government thinks it needs to be done. I acknowledge and welcome that approach from them.

I say, however, that I have some doubts about the practicality of the somewhat idealistic appeal at the end of the speech for a political moratorium. I say that not because I think there is an absence of good will in the different parts of the political system in Australia. I do not pretend that the Government has a mortgage on good will. I believe that the Opposition and the Democrats, and the others of course, have a great deal of good will in this matter. The fact of the matter is that there are differences of opinion, which are genuine, about how things ought to be tackled. I do not believe that simply putting the people mentioned into the same room will produce agreement.

I must say that at times it is a little difficult to say precisely where the Opposition stands with respect to policy. Honourable senators might recall, for example, that there was a demand from the Opposition before the Budget for tax cuts from the Government. There was a demand for a deficit of some $1,600m. When the Government came down with figures which appeared to show that, the Opposition promptly shifted its ground. It may well be that there is a degree of opposition for the sake of opposition. But I believe that rather than the Opposition looking for a political moratorium there might be some value for Australia if the Opposition were more properly and clearly to define what it sees as the alternatives for Australia so that the Australian people can consider a genuine alternative. Quite frankly, I have seen very little evidence of any serious attempt by the Opposition to come to grips with the alternative economic policies which might be followed. The standard of debate is generally at about the level at which Opposition members tell us that we should be prepared to change our economic policy, without giving a definition of how that change ought to be made.

Senator Harradine's contribution to the debate covered a very wide range of issues. Again, he made a number of points which I think are extremely serious for Australia, but they were points with which I would not altogether agree. I do not believe, for example, that it is possible to slow or to stop the flow of technological change. I realise the problems that technological change can give rise to but I think there is nothing in human history which would suggest that that is likely to occur. I do not believe that reducing the retiring age is likely to be either successful or appropriate in modern Australia. As Australians are living longer and as many Australians do not wish to retire at an early age that would also go against the success of that policy. There are, indeed, many people who believe that with the changing pattern of Australia's population we will look to people working longer rather than shorter periods in their lives. I do not make any personal final judgment on that but I do not believe that the general reduction of retirement ages is likely to help. The Government believes that this measure is one of the things which can be done by the Government and by the people of Australia to improve Australia's position in difficult economic times. I commend the legislation to the Senate. I hope that it will have a speedy passage. The Government will, of course, not support the amendments which have been moved by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Button's amendment) be left out .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) proposed:
At end of motion, add:

', but the Senate declares that to restrict wages only is an inadequate response to the present economic emergency, that the Government should take action to achieve reductions in prices and government charges for a similar period across a broad range of goods and services, by-
(a) freezing Commonwealth Government charges and taxes, including sales tax, stamp duties, telephone and postal charges;
(b) re-establishing the Prices Justification Tribunal and charging it with the specific task of preventing profiteering and containing costs of the necessities of life;
(c) requesting all professional and trade bodies to freeze the fees their members charge, and enforcing this course by administrative or legislative action where this is feasible; and

(d) not implementing any increase in the world parity prices for Australian produced petroleum products unless the additional revenue so gained is returned to the community in the form of increased family allowances, pensions and benefits,

and that the Government should take urgent and comprehensive measures to stimulate the economy, restrict imports, and call a national conference to begin a process of long term co-operative indicative planning'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition is opposing this amendment. I do not think I need to say why, except that it is inconsistent with the stance we take on the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to support the amendment moved by Senator Chipp and point out that if the Senate could find a majority to declare itself in favour of this amendment there would be an effective price freeze for 12 months.
—There would not be an effective price freeze.

—There would be an effective price freeze for 12 months because there would be a majority in the Senate to stop any Bill which raised any prices in the area under the control of this Government. If the Australian Labor Party and Senator Harradine voted for this amendment it would be useless for the Government to introduce any Bill because it would not get through this House. I respond also to two points raised by Senator Harradine, one of which was in relation to paragraph (a) of the amendment, which refers to Government prices. We are looking forward in the same way that the Government has done with the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill, in seeking to bring in what we believe is a price freeze which is compatible with the Bill-that is, one which covers all new price rises that are under the control of this Government. It has preached long and hard about the State governments freezing their prices, but it has many prices under its charge. Indeed, that was the area in which the greatest rises took place last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The last part of the amendment, paragraph (d), seeks to prevent any further petrol price rises. The Australian Democrats voted against the last increase and we will vote against the next one. The actual item is couched in the terms of a promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in Launceston during the last election campaign that if there were any new increases he would ensure that additional revenue would go into areas such as pensions and benefits or family allowances. It is not to put them together, as Senator Harradine suggested, but rather to say that if there were to be any additional rises in that area the Prime Minister's promise ought to be carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak about this matter because, as I said, we seem to be in an atmosphere of unreality. We are getting further and further into fantasy now. This is a meaningless amendment.
—Not if you vote for it.
—If the Australian Democrats had voted against the increases in sales taxes-
—We are talking about future ones, not past.
—I am talking about when those come before the chamber, and Senator Macklin did not vote against the sales increases, as I did.
—You are talking about past ones.
—Even if the Senate passes this piece of legislation how will it affect the sales tax increases that will come in from 1 January? It will not.
—Any future ones.
—It is crazy freezing Commonwealth Government charges and taxes, including sales tax. The Democrats' action should have been taken then. This amendment is meaningless. It will not take effect.
—What about the next one?

—The next one, presumably, will be in the Budget. Senator Macklin will have the opportunity of voting against it then. I will not have family allowances, by implication, tied to increases in import parity prices. They stand on their own. In fact they ought to stand on their own and they ought to be adjusted in line with increases in the consumer price index. Apart from all that, as I said, we are in fairy land when the Democrats exercise their vote , as they should have done just a moment ago and voted against the legislation. If they had the gumption, they would have protected those people upon whom the burden will fall-for example, the low income public servants and pharmacists in this country-and voted against this measure. They should have done so and not put up this fairy tale business now.
—I shall answer Senator Harradine's remarks. If he votes against the Australian Democrats amendment he will vote against the proposition that we put which is simply this-
—Senator, you should really obtain leave to speak. According to the Notice Paper you moved this amendment. That is correct, is it not?
—Yes, Mr President. I thought I had the right of reply.
—As such you do not have the right of reply but you may seek leave .
—I seek leave.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—This matter is based on a proposition that government charges which represent a significant part of the cost of living-such as sales taxes, telephone charges and postage charges- should not go up while a wages and salaries freeze is introduced by this Parliament. In the past when there was no wages freeze we agreed to the increases in taxes. Of course we did. I quite often find Senator Harradine to be totally incomprehensible. The Government said that there will be no increases in wages. The Democrats said: 'Okay, we will agree with that, but there will be no increase in wages or in government charges which represent a significant part of the cost of living'. Let the people judge our action by that statement not by what Senator Harradine might describe as the rationale behind our actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by the comment made by leave by Senator Chipp. I seek leave to make a comment.
—Senator, you do not need leave in regard to misrepresentation. Having spoken on this aspect you are entitled to rise in your place.
—I mentioned the fact that this would have absolutely--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is one of the--
—Sit down, you fraud; you got leave.
—Order, Senator Tate!
—Just watch who you call a fraud, you idiot.
—Order, Senator Chipp! Address the Chair.

—This is one of Senator Harradine's favourite tactics. Is not the proper procedure for him first to state where he has been misrepresented by me and then to state how? Is it not improper to allow him to go on with a speech before he has illustrated where he has been misrepresented?
—Yes. I would ask you, Senator Harradine, to state clearly where you have been misrepresented and to build your case following that.
—I seek leave, Mr President, to respond to Senator Chipp's comments.
—You still have the call on the point of misrepresentation, Senator; you do not need leave.

—Senator Chipp indicated that I had in some way misled the chamber in indicating that this document of his, the second reading amendment, was a fairy tale amendment. The fact of the matter is that the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . freezing Commonwealth Government charges and taxes, including sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President.
—You don't want to hear the truth.
—Senator Harradine is clearly just wanting a second go at the debate. I ask you, Mr President-I repeat--

—It is strange that we have champions of Senator Harradine here. Mr President, you gave a ruling that he must first state where he has been misrepresented. He has not done that. I ask you to ask him to do that.
—Senator Harradine, I would ask you to point out exactly where you claim to have been misrepresented, and then build your case in relation to that misrepresentation.

—Senator Chipp indicated that, in respect of the sales tax matter, I had stated that his proposition would be ineffective. I maintained that situation. That is where I have been misrepresented. In fact, I said that it would be ineffective. It will be ineffective because the sales tax comes into operation from 1 January, and the Democrats should have opposed it--
—Order, Senator!
—When it was before us in October.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator! You have made your point.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be added (Senator Chipp's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.40 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 9 deals with the suspension of powers of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. I want simply to place on the record the view that there can be no doubt that this legislation places an undue burden on pharmacists which they should not be asked to bear. It is quite apparent that clause 9 will have a most detrimental impact on the income which pharmacists might have been expected to obtain following not even future, but, indeed, current inquiries of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. That Tribunal is currently conducting an inquiry to determine the manner in which the Commonwealth price of any pharmaceutical benefit or all such benefit, is to be ascertained for the purpose of payments to approved pharmacists for the supply by them of those benefits. It is an unfair burden that those pharmacists will now have to share in common with all those dependent on the Commonwealth Government, whether by way of fees or wages, for their income.

SPEECH.PARA: It is precisely because pharmacists are asked to bear this burden in common, as I have said, with other fee or wage and salary earners dependent on the Commonwealth, that the Australian Labor Party took the view that the Bill as a whole ought to be defeated. Indeed, the Labor Party, in conjunction with Senator Harradine, voted that way. The Liberal Party and the Australian Democrats chose in the end to support the Bill as a whole and, therefore, this provision within it. In other words, had the ALP and Senator Harradine been joined by even one of the Australian Democrats, not to mention one of the dissident Liberal Party or National Party senators, this clause, suspending the powers of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal, would have been defeated. In other words I believe that the Labor Party and Senator Harradine took the principled view that one ought to oppose the Bill as a whole because of the impact that it will have on those persons who are dependent on the Commonwealth for their income.

I believe now that the two Houses of Parliament, having approved the Bill in principle at the second reading stage, against the vote of the ALP and Senator Harradine, are entitled to have the Bill carried into law. It would be sheer grandstanding, would show lack of inequity and, indeed would be beyond the ability of this chamber to carry out a piecemeal review of all those matters which chemists would wish to put before the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. One could well ask: Why should pharmacists be singled out for specially beneficial exemption when railway workers, Telecom Australia employees and all other Commonwealth wage and salary earners have to bear the burden of this Bill, which has now been approved in principle by both chambers to the second reading stage. For that reason the Opposition is not moving a Committee stage amendment in relation to this clause, having, as I said, attempted unsuccessfully to defeat it at the second reading stage.

We can provide some sort of mechanism whereby the Governor-General can make regulations to direct the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to deal with a particular of specified matter and to make that exercise of power effective; that is, to lift the suspension of powers of the Tribunal in relation to some specified matter. Indeed, one finds such a provision in clause 10. Clause 10 (2) provides:

. . . the Governor-General may make regulations conferring, during the prescribed period, powers on a specified tribunal or authority, being a tribunal or authority referred to in section 7, 8 or 9, in relation to a specified matter or in relation to matters included in a specified class of matters, being powers that would, but for that section, be exercisable by that tribunal or authority.

This, in short, enables the Governor-General to revive the powers of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. I do not doubt for a moment that the pharmacists of Australia, principally through the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, will make a submission to the Government that the Governor-General should exercise that power to make regulations to revive or empower the Tribunal to make the necessary findings or determinations in relation to the tasks which pharmacists perform, on behalf of the Government and the community, in particular, in relation, obviously, to the dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits .

I especially remind honourable senators that only a matter of weeks ago, on 16 November, I brought to the attention of the Senate the fact that the Government, without putting the form in the Commonwealth Gazette, had circulated to doctors declaration forms which are superimposed on the back of prescription forms, requiring the filling in of details by pensioners and those holding health care cards. When one looks at what must be filled in by somebody who, by definition, is probably elderly, somewhat frail, perhaps disadvantaged and who therefore finds forms daunting, when one looks at what faces a pensioner or health care card holder in filling out that form from 1 January onwards, one can appreciate the extent of bureaucratic harassment of that person who, after all, is only seeking a medicine on the pharmaceutical benefits list in order to deal with some illness arising from a traumatic injury, or some minor illness, chronic complaint or ailment.

In addition to having the assistance of a chemist being sought to obtain that necessary medicine, the cost of which to that person is being subsidised by the Government, it is quite evident that chemists will have to spend some time away from their primary professional task of assembling and dispensing medicines. They will have to engage in some clerical work on behalf of the Government and the community in order to assist those pensioners and health care card holders in the filling in of those declarations. Honourable senators should not forget that on the form it is stated that there shall be a penalty of $1,000 and/or imprisonment for six months for making any mistake in the filling out of that form. Quite clearly, the chemist will be involved for some minutes on each prescription with the person seeking the pharmaceutical benefit. That adds up to many hours per week.

The Government is now saying that, in addition to the loss of professional time involved in helping with that task, there will be no remuneration during the coming 12-month period of the freeze for carrying out that extra duty as from 1 January. I imagine that a very strong case could be made by chemists under clause 10 for the Governor-General empowering the Tribunal to make a special finding or determination in relation to that matter. I give that as an instance but it is only one instance. Clearly, it is beyond the competence of this chamber to look at all those matters in relation to which it ought to be specified that the Tribunal could make an effective finding or determination. I have had many representations from the President of the Pharmacy Guild of Tasmania, Mr Tremaine, from Geoff Noar of Lindisfarne and from Peter Miller of Sorrell, all of whom are reputable chemists and pharmacists in Tasmania and all of whom find the Government's harassment of pensioners and health care card holders bad enough to contemplate. But in the absence of some remuneration for assisting those persons, one only has the Government compounding the felony.

The Labor Party and Senator Harradine attempted to frustrate the Government in its imposition of this salaries and wages pause on various sectors of the community, including pharmacists. Had we been supported by any of the Democrats or Liberal Party or National Party senators we would have succeeded in our endeavour. That has not been possible. But I can assure pharmacists in Tasmania- other honourable senators from other States will no doubt be making it well known to pharmacists within their own jurisdictions-that we have by no means given up the battle on their behalf and that we will be seeking, as soon as possible, to encourage the Government to make the necessary exemption under clause 10 of the Bill to allow the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to make the necessary findings or determinations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the same clause. The Australian Democrats yesterday sent a letter to Mr Macphee who had charge of the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill in the other place. I quote a paragraph from that letter which relates to pharmacists. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We have considered their case in detail and quite frankly believe that they have put forward an unanswerable set of reasons for special consideration. This would include the fact that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has been in session for some time and is close to bringing down a determination, as well as the fact that pharmacists have had their work load increased considerably by the obligation to administer the declarations to be provided by people receiving pharmaceutical benefits.

I want to refer to two items in that letter. First, the fact is that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal has been hearing the particular case for quite some time. It would seem that there is no reason for the Tribunal not to have brought down a judgment. Indeed, the pharmaceutical representatives yesterday, I understand, put that fact to the Tribunal. But it became obvious in those discussions before the Tribunal that they would make no headway before this Bill was passed, which I think is unfortunate.

Looking at the Bill, I think it would be inappropriate to alter clause 9 (1). The reason for that is that the pharmacists realise that if all professional people were to come under control, as indeed is the intention of the Government, though that intention is not being executed in this legislation, then the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal would have to be included. It is, therefore, appropriate to turn to clause 10 (2) in the Bill under which regulations can be made in relation to special circumstances and specific matters or in relation to matters included in a specific class of matters. This certainly would be one of those areas.
I refer now to the statement by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) in relation to this wage pause. He stated:

. . . it is to address the deteriorating employment situation . . . the central thrust . . . was to put in place the widest and most effective possible pause in wages for the next 12 months throughout the Australian economy, as a means of saving jobs.

I emphasise that last point. In announcing this legislation the Acting Prime Minister made the point that it was to save jobs. I read now from a telegram which I received from a constituent in Bundaberg, Queensland, in relation to this particular matter. The telegram states:
. . . totally unjust . . . will result immediate retrenchment three of my 28 staff . . .

He was referring to pharmacists. That is an extraordinary way to start to save jobs. The reason for that retrenchment is to be found in the intention of the Government to allow a continuation of the community wage round. The reason that that comes into this context is that in some States shope assistants have not had a catch-up from the metal trades flow-on. The intention of the Government presumably is that those shop assistants will be allowed that catch-up.

TALK.START.PARA: —With which we do not disagree.

—We do not disagree with that. I think it is a perfectly reasonable proposition that such members of the community should be allowed that catch-up, but it means that many pharmacists will be in the unenviable situation of having their remuneration frozen while that of their employees is still to rise. We should take into account that fact and also the fact that the increases that pharmacists have had in the last 12 months have been minimal. Mr Macphee, in response to the letter sent to him by Senator Chipp, alluded to two rises which have occurred in recent times; that is, an increase in the mark-up from 1 December 1982, and the 10 per cent increase on contemporaneously prepared items and 4 per cent on readily prepared items. The actual situation is that the increase in the wholesale price of the first item alluded to was about 1.6 per cent, which is absolutely minimal, and the increase in dispensing fees per prescription was about 2.9 per cent, whereas the Tribunal seems to accept that dispensing expenses in the same period went up by 8 per cent. Part of the submission that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia put before the Tribunal was that part of those increases in dispensing costs flows directly from actions of the Government. In these circumstances, when dealing with a unique situation such as this, fairly obviously the Government in a sense has to say: 'This is it'. But it cannot cut off wages quite that easily for those people who have increases already in the pipeline and who have not received a flow-on of anywhere near the amount others in the community have received.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, I would like to allude to the point that Senator Tate raised, and has raised previously, concerning the new forms that pharmacists will be asked to deal with from pensioner patients. Without doubt the conscientious professionals will find themselves involved in a lot more work. Without doubt the conscientious professional pharmacist already spends a considerable time giving assistance to such people over and above that called for according to the remuneration paid to him. I am not talking of the person who sees his pharmacy as a little like a supermarket; I am talking about the vast bulk of professional pharmacists who see themselves as paramedics involved in counselling people who come into their shops, many of whom are pensioners. This item has already caused an enormous amount of concern among pharmacists and will increase their work load enormously, particularly those pharmacists who have a large number of pensioners amongst their clientele or who get a proportion of their business from nursing homes. Many pharmacists earn their bread and butter from one or two nursing homes.

The problems involved with the new forms are immense. I understand that the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) probably does not have all that much support from his Department in relation to this absurd proposition. Unless the Minister changes his mind on those forms, pharmacists will be disadvantaged even further. That particular item has not even been raised in discussions currently before the Remuneration Tribunal. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) might be able to give some indication of the Government's intention in this area in relation to pharmacists. I raise this particular item not because pharmacists comprise the only group involved but because it is a representative group of a number of people who will get caught up in this move of the Government. I believe that sympathetic and reasonable judgment will be required to make sure that these types of anomalies are handled with care. I seek from the Minister some response in relation to the powers that clause 10 (2) of this Bill gives the Government. I would like to know what is on the Government's mind particularly in relation to the judgment-it would be almost immediate if it had been allowed to proceed-from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter in respect of clause 7 of the Bill and its reference to section 8 (1) (a) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973. By that indirect reference the Bill in question in fact does exempt from the effect of the wages freeze or pause a member of either House of Parliament who is appointed as a parliamentary secretary to a Minister of State. Of course, reference to section 8 (1) (b) shows that such a person has not as yet had his or her allowances and salaries determined. My query is: Why has the Government found it necessary to include under the ambit of the exemption part of this freeze persons appointed as parliamentary secretaries? So far as I know we do not have any such persons appointed at the moment. I wonder what is the purpose and the intention of the Government with respect to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The speech we have just heard from the representative of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin, is really, might I say, typical of the grandstanding that the Australian Democrats are engaging in on this issue. I would have thought that the speech that has just been made by Senator Macklin would presage an intention by the Australian Democrats to vote against clause 9 of the Bill.
—It does not need to. I explained that, if you were listening.

—I was listening very carefully. What the Australian Democrats are doing is giving over the pharmacists' matter to a decision by the Government as to whether or not it will act under the provisions of the Bill in respect of any determination that is made by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.
—Clause 10 (2).

—Yes. Frankly, for my part, I do not want to buy a pig in a poke. Maybe it will act; maybe it will not act. I think that the issue was very well stated by Senator Tate. The obvious means to achieve what we want is to vote against clause 9 of the Bill. It is as simple as that. The odd part about all this is that the Tribunal's Chairman, a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, may be engaged in considering applications for variations of Federal awards which may indeed move as a result of catching-up on increases in community wages. I must say that I congratulate the Government for its policy of not opposing-it cannot prevent it; it is contrary to the Constitution-those registered industrial organisations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which may wish to make an application for variation of an award so that they can have the last round of community wage movements applied. I congratulate the Government on that. I can see very clearly, as can a lot of other people, that this measure is to ensure that a new round of wage claims is not started prematurely. As I said at the second reading stage, if that achieves a return to the centralisation of wage fixing it is probably not a bad idea. But as I also said at the second reading stage, unless the Government addresses a wide range of other issues which are pertinent to this problem of unemployment this whole thrust will be doomed to failure.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems is that experienced by the pharmacists. I do not propose to hold the Senate any further other than to refer to what Senator Tate said and the amplification that he made of their case to the Senate. I say only that the opportunity is here for the Australian Democrats to vote against this measure. In so doing, they will put into practice what indeed they have been saying to the chamber today. I will be interested also in what the Minister has to say about clause 10 (2) but, as I say, I am not prepared to buy a pig in a poke. I would be prepared to vote against this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a query of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) relating to the provisions of clause 4 of the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill 1982 which states that the Act extends to every external Territory. I notice in the Press reports, yesterday, I think that the Government would be exempting from the provisions of the legislation a number of categories of employees who have, as it were, part heard matters before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which would complete the current round of wage increases. My concern relates to the Christmas Island workers who, I understand, have a part heard matter before the Arbitrator which was to come on today in Melbourne. I would be pleased if the Minister could inform us of the position relating to those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to the matters raised by Senator Button regarding the Christmas Island workers. As he has correctly pointed out to the Committee, arbitration has already commenced. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has asked that it be completed expeditiously. The Arbitrator has said that he would finish the hearing even if he continued into the Saturday and Sunday. In the circumstances of that case it is thought by the Government that there will be a decision before the Bill is proclaimed in which case no problem arises. In any event, if that is not the case, the Government would be sympathetic to an application to exempt that particular case under the regulations. I do not want to go into great detail, but I think that more clearly than in other case there would be a case for exemption if the matter were caught by the legislation. It is not the Government's intention to so catch it.
—Does it involve essentially ratification of an agreement with employers?

—I understand so. The rest of the contributions in Committee so far, apart from the quite interesting contribution from Senator Bolkus-not one word of which did I understand, so he might have to repeat it-related to the question of pharmacists. They have in light of their relatively small numbers attracted a very great deal of attention during this debate. What we are talking about here is the application of the same rule to the pharmacists as is being applied to approximately half a million other people. In other words, it is not a case of their being singled out. The pharmacists of course should be treated in the same way as other people who are caught by this legislation. It is perhaps worth noting that we are talking about a particular aspect of the pharmacists' remuneration. On my advice prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the Repatriation Benefits Scheme make up approximately 35 per cent to 40 per cent of the total pharmacy turnover if we include all items dealt with. In other words, we are dealing with a segment of the turnover of pharmacy businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter has been canvassed and has been raised, of course, with the Government in the lead-up to the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill, as was indicated by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The matter was raised by Senator Chipp in a letter to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Senator Jessop on our side of the chamber was one who also raised with the Government the position of the pharmacists. Some reference has been made by Senator Macklin to the response which the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations sent to Senator Chipp yesterday. As was mentioned in the Committee debate the pharmacists have received a couple of adjustments to that part of their income which is influenced by the legislation-that is, to their dispensing income-since the bulk of blue collar workers who will also be affected by this legislation have last received an adjustment. It is worth noting, as pointed out by Mr Macphee, that the pharmacists have received two increases in their remuneration in the past year. In comparison with the more lowly paid blue collar workers in, say, the metal industry where the tradesman fitter received a $25 a week increase in December 1981 and a mid-term adjustment of $14 in June 1982, the pharmacists have had the adjustments which have been referred to, namely, an increase in mark-up as from 1 December 1982 and an increase in dispensing fees on 1 July 1982.

I do not make those comments wishing to be destructive of the case which has been put forward by the pharmacists but merely to illustrate that it is very important that the Government should try to apply this quite difficult concept of a wage pause in as fair a manner as possible. I simply wish to assure the Committee that the Government will examine the situation of the pharmacists in the same light as it will look at other people who are caught in what might be argued as an anomalous or difficult situation.

There has been talk about the completion of the community round. I note that there is general Senate suport for that element of the Government's approach, namely, trying to ensure that those relatively small proportions of the work force that have not yet had the advantage of the 1981 community round should do so notwithstanding the passage of this legislation. As far as the pharmacists are concerned I think I should merely say that the Government has approached the Bill with the policy that the pause in remuneration should be total, covering all those on the Commonwealth payroll and those in receipt of remuneration funded by the Budget except, of course, those on welfare payments who have been exempted from any pause.

Our policy towards the pharmacists is consistent with that policy. They have had the two movements to which I have referred since the blue collar workers gained their last adjustment in June. This Bill means that the lowly paid workers and the pharmacists should not receive additional rates of remuneration funded from the Budget after the date of commencement. The pharmacists are, of course, free to take advantage of clause 10 which has been referred to in the Committee debate. They are entitled to bring forward a case for consideration that, for the reasons that they would wish to mount, there is some reason why they should be exempted. I would not wish to say anything which would pre-judge or pre-empt the consideration of that matter. It is a matter which would have to be considered on its merits bearing in mind that the pharmacists should be treated in the same way as other members of the community. I invite Senator Bolkus to repeat his point because I do not find any reference to parliamentary secretaries in the clause to which he refers. I am not clear how the point that he raised does arise. I would appreciate it if he would clarify it. I will endeavour to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the invitation from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I refer the Minister to clause 7 (1) of the Bill which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Except for the purposes of sub-section 8 (1A) . . . the Remuneration Tribunal is not empowered, during the prescribed period, to hold, or to continue to hold, any inquiries or to make any determinations. . . .

Sub-section 8 (1A) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act was a sub-section which was inserted in 1980 by the Parliamentary Secretaries Act. It refers to the position of parliamentary secretary to a Minister of State. What I am saying is that, under the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill, the position of the parliamentary secretary to a Minister of State is excluded from the freeze. I ask the Minister : Why has the Government seen fit to exclude parliamentary secretaries? I understand that we do have one or two parliamentary secretaries-the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) is one. My point, therefore, is: Why does the honourable member for Macarthur get this privileged exempt status under the proposed legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an authoritative answer to that question. The only answer which occurs to me is that parliamentary secretaries do not receive remuneration as such. Because of a constitutional problem, they do not receive a salary. I think they are entitled to receive no more than reimbursement. I stress to the Committee, because I have no wish to mislead it, that I speak now from my general recollection of the provisions relating to parliamentary secretaries. It may be that the allowances which can be dealt with are allowances which relate solely to out of pockets and things of that nature because of the constitutional prohibition.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to avoid the issue. I will try to get my advisers to find a copy of the Remuneration Tribunal Act in order to give the honourable senator a more authoritative reply. I will undertake to follow the matter up further and will give the honourable senator a reply. Unfortunately he will not be able to use it until the Senate resumes in February. There is no intention or wish to exempt parliamentarians generally from the provisions of this legislation. We, including Ministers, stand caught by it, as do others.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't be increased? That is the point.

—Quite frankly, I do not know the reason for the inclusion of that provision. I will try to find out before the Committee debate ends. But I will certainly undertake to give the honourable senator a written response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to section 11 of the Bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-section 4 (6) of the Health Insurance Act 1973 does not apply in relation to-

And it goes on. Sub-section 4 (6) of the Health Insurance Act is one of those sections that manage to get into most Acts which are unreadable the first time around and also unreadable about the fourth time around. But, essentially, the meaning seems to be that the Schedule relates to the set fees that are paid to doctors for their services to people who come under the Act. An example might be a pensioner who receives all his or her medical and doctors fees free as they are paid by the Commonwealth.

Clause 11 of the Bill suspends the automatic cut-off at the end of 12 months of the end of that schedule. In other words, as I read it-the Minster for Social Security (Senator Chaney) can correct me if I am wrong-that Schedule will continue at the level that is set unless the Government takes some other action to increase it. That would be the only obvious reason to tamper with that Schedule. If that is the case, I assume that the Government has said to the doctors: 'While your fees may be varied, the remuneration from the Commonwealth will be frozen as a percentage of what the doctor may actually charge over and above that'. Of course, he is entitled to do that. There is no Commonwealth power to stop the person doing that.

I assume also that it is the intention of the Government that that schedule be frozen for 12 months. I would like the Minister to comment on that aspect. Certainly, if the Government attempted to change that schedule it would have to gazette a regulation to do so. I am fairly confident that that regulation would not pass the Senate, or certainly the Senate would disallow such an increase at that time. It may very well be that the Government has chosen this method, if I interpret this clause corecctly, in an attempt to put as much pressure as it can on doctors to hold their charges, although of course constitutionally they are able to charge what they will over and above that amount which is funded by the Commonwealth. I would like a response from the Minister as to whether that is the situation as the Government understands it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer to that question is contained in the second reading speech, which points out that the remuneration of members of the medical profession is affected-of course, it is not controlled-by the level of approved fees under the Health Insurance Act 1973. In this Salaries and Wages Pause Bill the Government seeks to continue the present regulations during the period of the pause so that the level of fees approved for payment of benefits from registered health insurance funds will be maintained at current levels. Senator Macklin is quite correct-indeed, it is confirmed in the second reading speech-that this action does not stop medical fees from rising. But the Commonwealth will be approaching the professional organisations of the medical profession to seek the co- operation of all members in the application of a pause in medical charges for that year. This is one of the areas in which government actions will effectively influence the behaviour of doctors in these matters. A very substantial number of doctors do charge the schedule fee. On recent figures, on average 79 per cent of doctors charge the schedule fee, so it is quite a significant determinant of the cost of medical services in Australia. That fee is to be held. Doctors will, in turn, be asked--
—What percentage charge is the fee?
—Seventy nine per cent, so there is a fair degree of Commonwealth influence. There is not Commonwealth control, as Senator McLaren acknowledged in his comments on the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 15 December, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Proposed Reporting on Operation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in respect of each week during which the Senate meets, on the first day on which the Senate meets during that week, the Leader of the Government make a statement informing the Senate on the operation of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982 and the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982, and in particular on savings effected in the expenditure of the Commonwealth and amounts paid to the States, respectively, under those Acts.

I believe this proposition is only fair given the importance which the Government attaches to the measures under the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill and the Special Employment-related Programs Bill. I believe it would be most interesting for the Senate to hear next year what savings the Government has effected as a result of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982 and what disbursements have been made to the States and for what purposes under the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982. In effect my motion is a measure to ensure that the Government remains honest about these matters. It will give an opportunity not only to the Senate but also, I believe, to the whole of Australia to see, week by week, just precisely what these measures mean. I hope that the Senate will see its way clear to accept this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the interest of Senator Harradine in the success of the wage pause and the effect of the savings which are made. I would see some difficulty in making a statement on a weekly basis about the operation of the pause. The undertaking that has been given to the States is that we will release funds to them on a monthly basis for their approved expenditure under the employment related programs. The Government is perfectly happy to provide any information as soon as it is readily available. Perhaps Senator Harradine would be happy with an initial report, say, on the first day that we return. That would give us a period in which to put the whole program into effect. Then on a monthly basis we could give the expenditure under the appropriation legislation which was before the Senate tonight. I think in that way the honourable senator would be able to get the information he is seeking. The honourable senator would like the information provided on a weekly basis. However, from time to time there may be no change in the information from one week to another simply because no payment has been made to the States.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be far more indefinite for an assumption of savings to be made on a weekly basis because savings will result from increases that would have been received had determinations continued to be made throughout the year. So the savings themselves are not readily ascertainable on a weekly basis. In fact, the figure of $300m has been calculated on the basis of expected increases in salaries and wages during the latter part of the year. Therefore, we are happy at any time to make any available information on expenditure readily known to the Senate as we did, for instance, in respect of the welfare housing proposal. It was decided that $100m would be directed towards that program and the Minister concerned would make statements as the information became available.

The States have been asked to give us ideas on programs which they would like to see included in this proposal. I think some sort of announcement will be made when the programs have been determined. We have agreed with the States that payments be made to them on a monthly basis. I ask Senator Harradine whether he would be prepared to accept that whatever information is available be provided on a monthly basis or at other times when special information is available. I see no problem in giving the Senate as much information as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Leader of the Opposition, I ask Senator Harradine whether he is willing, in view of the Minister's statement, to seek leave to amend his motion. This could have some bearing on the responses of other honourable senators in this place. I take it that Senator Harradine will not agree to the Minister's suggestion. I call Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I can help. I indicated to Senator Harradine that we would support his motion. However, I quite see the point made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). The Opposition would support a Government amendment to Senator Harradine's motion so that once a month or in each three-week period of sitting there would be such a report.
—And the Democrats would join you.

—I am just offering this as a suggestion because I agree with the spirit of Senator Harradine's proposal. I think it is important that Parliament have a regular report on the implications of the savings which possibly will be made. I appreciate that even after a three-week or a monthly period it might not be possible to give a figure. However, it could be said at the time that a figure could not be given.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that a figure could be given on a monthly basis in respect of the operation of the special employment-related programs scheme. I do not want to say any more except to point out that if the Minister moves an amendment to that effect we will support it. I understand that Senator Harradine is agreeable . If the Government does not move an amendment we will support Senator Harradine 's original proposition. Senator Harradine's motion is exemplary in that he has adopted for the night the slogan of the Australian Democrats and is concerned to keep honesty in relation to this matter. There is one group, however, in respect of which there is no mechanism at all for keeping honest, and that is members of the Senate.
