I suggest in the context and spirit of the wage freeze legislation that each honourable senator agree that he or she is quite prepared to declare his or her income as at 31 December 1982 and again as at 31 December 1983 to make sure there has been no cheating-if I can use that expression-by honourable senators in relation to the wages freeze legislation which has been adopted and which applies to us. I have always advocated the principle of full disclosure of incomes of parliamentarians. I think this is an excellent opportunity for legislators who are imposing freezes on blue collar wage earners-

TALK.START.PARA: —People on less than $300 a week.

—It is less than $300 a week in the Commonwealth railways, Senator Sibraa; it is $240 a week. We should take the opportunity to change, as it were, what is the traditional pattern of this place where by we legislate for everybody except ourselves. It might be a very good idea if we did all declare our incomes as at 31 December and undertook to do so as at 31 December 1983 also to make sure that the same principles apply to us as apply to lowly paid workers in this country. I invite the Minister to respond on behalf of the Government in relation to that suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I seek leave to move an amendment to Senator Harradine's motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think what would meet the spirit of the Senate would be an amendment along these lines. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the motion be amended to read as follows: That, in respect of each 3 week period during which the Senate meets on the first day on which the Senate meets during that period, the Leader of the Government make a statement informing the Senate on the operation of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982 and the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982, and the expenditure of the Commonwealth and amounts paid to the States, respectively, under those Acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is supported.

—The Australian Democrats are pleased to support that amendment. We believe that is a reasonable amendment for the Government to offer. I just note in passing that the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) has deleted the words 'in particular on savings', but the Government is prepared to lay down the expenditure. I think this is fair enough. If anyone wants to do certain sums it is up to that person to do his or her figuring from that statement. The Democrats support the proposition.
—I just want to ask a question of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle); I do not want to close the debate.
—The honourable senator is speaking to the amendment now.
—Do I understand that the Minister's amendment really is my motion, with the words 'three-weekly period' inserted in the first line?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Yes, with the omission of the words 'with relation to savings'.

—Come on. You are getting away from it now. You don't want to put down what the savings are because you know that they are going to be infinitesimal having regard to the problem of unemployment in Australia.
— But the reference is to savings that arise from not increasing Public Service salaries, details of which will not have been determined.
—You know the parameters of those. You know the date on which the application would have been made.

— We would not have known the dates on a weekly basis, as was asked by the honourable senator, or even on a three-weekly basis. I point out that under this legislation an appropriation of $300m is sought. The Government is appropriating those funds so that they may be drawn upon by the States and the Commonwealth itself for programs that will be related to the wages pause. The Government has already specified an amount of $300m in the Special Employment-related Programs Bill. It is not a case of talking about an indefinite amount. It is a case of having a Bill that allows us expenditure of up to $300m. Savings that are identified on some hypothetical basis would be very difficult for us to determine at any particular time. We have made a fair estimate of what we think the increases in Public Service salaries will be for the period of the pause and appropriated that amount. On that basis I feel that that is a more protected situation than the one that Senator Harradine expects had we only been talking about savings that we could identify by a particular date or in a particular week. The period of the pause will achieve $300m for appropriation, the expenditure of which will be announced on the basis that I have indicated in the amendment.
—Is that from the Public Service alone or from statutory authorities as well?

— This $300m is appropriated to the Commonwealth Budget for our Public Service salaries. That is the amount that we have just appropriated in this Bill. We will give advice of expenditure under the Bill. But as to the savings made, it would be very difficult for us to assume that a tribunal would make a particular determination on a particular date.

—I will be very brief. I support my leader, Senator Button, in regard to the final point that he made. People in the community, given their cynicism of politicians, will have great difficulty about this matter. They will say the politicians are on a fairly good wage while theirs will be pegged. There is no doubt that politicians' wages will be pegged but they will say: 'How many politicians have other outside income? How do we know that they are not profiting by the situation and how do we know that their income will not increase over that 12-month period?' I support Senator Button's suggestion that every one of us on 31 December-or probably a couple of months after; we will need time to calculate the figure-state what his or her income was for 1982 and state it against in 19 months time. Thus the public as a whole can regain some confidence in politicians. They will see that people-especially those who are making the law-are not ripping off the system.

—I support Senator Robert Ray in his request that all honourable senators state their incomes as from the beginning of the wage pause and again at the end of the wage pause. I think that that is a very reasonable request and it should place no hardship on any honourable senator.
—As signed by the Commissioner of Taxation.
—Yes, as signed by the Commissioner of Taxation.

—I also join Senator Button, Senator Robert Ray and Senator Siddons in supporting this proposition. As my colleague Senator Robert Ray has said, politicians are not underpaid. If any honourable senator has a double income, if he is in a profession-particularly government senators who have introduced this legislation to freeze public servants' wages- he ought to be the first to agree to the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Button. If honourable senators are not prepared to do that I think that they could well be classed by people outside as absolute frauds in putting this legislation before the Parliament.
—I think that it is essential for all politicians to declare their income. After all, we have have frozen wages for public servants. I most certainly am only too willing to declare my income.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! For the clarification of all honourable senators I will read the amendment that the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, has proposed. The amended motion is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: That in respect of each three week period during which the Senate meets, that on the first day on which the Senate meets during the period, the Leader of the Government make a statement informing the Senate on the operation of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982 and the Special Employment-Related Programs Act 1982, and the expenditure of the Commonwealth and amounts paid to the States , respectively, under those Acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, as amended, add ', and that all senators declare their gross incomes for the year ending at the commencement of the Acts and at a date 12 months after the commencement of the Acts'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make an appeal to the good sense of the Senate. This is one of the most absurd procedures that I have seen in my years in Parliament. I am not saying the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) is absurd; I support the thrust of that. But on the run, at ten past nine on the last day of sitting, we have a bright young senator getting a sudden burst of inspiration and trying to tack on to another motion, the relevance of which is a little obscure to me, the amendment, as I remember it, that each senator should declare his or her gross income for the year. As a person who has some training in this area, I have found that even the definition of gross income leads one to difficulty unless it is spelt out extremely carefully.
—Get the Commissioner of Taxation to tell you.

—I would accept that sort of qualification but that is not in the motion. I strongly appeal to the good sense of the Senate, having said that a reasonable proposition thought out carefully along these lines would have my total support and I am sure the support of my party. But I will not be so irresponsible as to catch something on the run. What about a member of parliament who receives only his or her parliamentary income and has a spouse who is earning hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of assessable income a year? Under this proposition that income would not need to be declared. Alternatively, a person could enter into a family trust and obscure or hide their income. I should have thought that when a good idea, like the one proposed by Senator Button, is put forward, the Senate should not deteriorate to a stage at which we take something on the run and cause all sorts of complications and, perhaps, injustices at a later point. I do not know what machinery is available. If the Australian Labor Party wants to suspend the Standing Orders later in the evening to move a separate motion after it has thought out this matter and conferred with other parties and, perchance, obtained the agreement of the Government, surely that is the sensible course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is always helpful to a young apprentice in this chamber to receive the advice of honourable senators such as Senator Chipp who has had long parliamentary experience. I thank him for his endorsement of the principle put forward by Senator Button and me and supported by Senator Siddons, Senator Robert Ray, Senator Elstob and, I believe, by Senator Harradine .
—And Senator McLaren.

—And Senator McLaren. In other words, there was an endorsement of the principle at the second reading stage. I take on board the fact that perhaps the amendment is not drafted as elegantly as it might be or as comprehensively as it ought to be. Therefore, I seek leave to withdraw the amendment which I forwarded to the table. I foreshadow that on our resumption next year I will introduce the more precise wording to carry that principle into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will now return to dealing with the original amended motion. I call Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the Government gives its estimate of savings in those three-weekly periods if at all possible. I would be very interested to know what those estimated savings would be during a three-week period, particularly in regard not only to the Public Service proper but also to statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION BILL 1982BROADCASTING CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Button.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Lewis-Have you any more bright ideas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the relief of Government senators, particularly Senator Lewis who went white at the suggestion about disclosing his income-he is very keen on inflicting wage freezes on other people but not himself- I will talk about the Australian Broadcasting Commission for a few minutes.
—With emphasis on the 'few'.

—Senator Walters should not tempt me; I might go on. I want to make a few comments about the ABC. First, at the start of 1981 the Government appointed the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That Committee made very extensive inquiries, which took a long time, and it is now 19 months since it reported. In that time the Government has been very slow in responding to that report. It has now responded in the form of legislation passed through the House of Representatives six weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a source of great regret to the Opposition that the Government is not prepared to complete this legislation tonight. It is not prepared to do so because the legislation included an absurd provision regarding a complaints procedure for the ABC, and a number of other provisions which were unsatisfactorily drafted and conceptually unsound. We find the Government in an extraordinary mess. In October the Government distributed a list of Bills which had to be passed before the end of this session. In the last couple of hours of the sitting-if Senator Walters provokes me again, I may make it three hours-the Government indicates that it is not prepared to complete this legislation tonight. That just shows the method by which this Government works in relation to matters of great importance. The ABC is an institution of great importance to this country. I think it would have been the hope of many people in the community and many menbers of this parliament that the ABC could have commenced a new year, and a new era, in 1983 on the basis of legislation passed by this Parliament. It is the Government's fault that that has not happened. It is a very sad thing for the Senate and the Parliament generally, and it is to the discredit of the Parliament generally that that has not happened.

This Bill gives effect to many of the recommendations of the Dix Committee. It contains a few others of less reputable lineage picked up along the way. An outstanding example of that is the proposal for a commissioner for complaints. As anyone with any sort of length of memory will recall, a commissioner for complaints in respect of the ABC becomes a very sensitive issue, because in 1975 Mr Nixon, the present National Party Minister for Primary Industry-subsequently of Asia Dairy Industries and Murray-Goulburn fame-called for the appointment of a moderator, as he called it, or a monitor, for the ABC to vet its political partiality. He referred to the ABC as an organisation which needed unprecedented watchfulness by the National Country Party and the Liberal Party. He said that that had been brought about by the ABC's well-established bias towards the Labor and socialist sides of politics. It was an extraordinary statement for an Opposition spokesman, as he then was, to make. It makes the whole question of a complaints procedure for the ABC a very sensitive issue.

There are other changes which the Government has made in response to the Dix Committee recommendations which are largely irrelevant. For example, the change of name from Australian Broadcasting Commission to Australian Broadcasting Corporation seems to illustrate nothing more than a philosophical penchant for the second word rather than the first. But perhaps the most important change on which the Opposition congratulates the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) and the Government is the change envisaged in spelling out a so-called charter for the ABC, which is done in clause 6. In particular, clause 6 (2) (iii ) spells out, for the first time, the responsibility of the ABC to provide a balance between programs of wide appeal and specialised radio and television programs, that is, programs catering for particular minority audiences. For a long time the ABC has been bedevilled by uncertainty, both within the Commission itself and outside, as to its proper role as a national broadcaster. The argument has been pitched in terms of whether it is to be a so-called quality broadcaster setting a standard and catering for minority audiences and largely disregarding any audience consequences in terms of ratings, or whatever, or whether it competes with commercial television and radio. The result has been something of a superior, sometimes unworldly and detached attitude, by some broadcasters within the ABC and frustration on the part of others.

There has never been an abiding consensus of what the ABC's role is. We as a party have long maintained that the dichotomy between the ABC's specialist role as a broadcaster and its role in broadcasting to mass audiences has been a false dichotomy. The true role of the national broadcasting organisation must be to be truly comprehensive. It is about serving specialised interests at a high standard and it is about competing for audiences in mass entertainment of quality. The real question for the Australian Broadcasting Commission is how to present quality programs with good production values in a contemporary, attractive and entertaining way. Furthermore, the generally low audience acceptance, with important exceptions, has been a chronic cause of low morale, a lack of confidence within the ABC, a lack of a sense of mission and a lack of a sense of identity. If, as a result of following the precept now laid out in the Act, the ABC gains large audiences it will have a resounding effect on its morale with good repercussions throughout the organisation.

I think it is also worth noting that healthy competition from a public broadcasting organisation such as the ABC frankly aiming at mass appeal broadcasting is probably the best form of regulation for the commercial sector that we could devise. A recent history of broadcasting shows a number of instances in which the ABC has pioneered successful programs which have had a very beneficial effect on the development of commercial broadcasting. I refer to areas such as current affairs and Australian drama programs which would never have appeared on, for example, commercial television, if it had not been for the pioneering efforts of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Therefore, we commend this part of the Act wholeheartedly and congratulate the Government on grapsing that nettle.

The Opposition is also pleased to see that the proposal for corporate underwriting now appears to have died as a notion which is in any sense acceptable to a national broadcasting organisation such as the ABC. This is a good thing for all sorts of reasons to do with its possible effects on ABC programs. However, there is a point at which the Bill seems to leave a loophole. We will be trying to redress that loophole in an amendment to the legislation in the Committee stage. However, I would also like to raise one suggestion which has emanated from the Australian Labor Party on a number of occasions. We have made it before and, in a sense, it has a commercial element about it. I refer to the proposal that the Australian Broadcasting Commission or, more likely, a subsidiary of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, set up for the purpose should be given a radiated subscription television channel if that service is to be introduced in Australia.

More than once I have heard Ministers of this Government reflect on the difficulty of funding national broadcasting adequately. Certainly the budgetary history of the ABC under this Government bears that out. On the other hand, commercial television over recent years has been fairly prosperous and does not need assistance other than the assistance it gets through the principle of channels being limited by government action to what the market can stand. We support that policy. In other words, commercial channels are given a structural situation in which they can make a good profit. I believe that this is proper and wise. On the other hand, the Australian Broadcasting Commission is always short of money. It has been shorter of money since the last Labor Government in a sense abolished licence fees-a decision which I personally regret. The ABC has been short of money as a result of funding cuts by the present Government, which since 1976 represent a 22 per cent decline in funding to the ABC.

There are, of course, some problems with radiated subscription television services. For example, I am not happy with the effect that system could have in syphoning off good programs such as major sporting events from other channels. But this criticism applies with most strength to a commercial RSTV system, where there would not necessarily be any countervailing good effects, such as money going into other forms of new programing.

Syphoning off could create a discriminatory situation in which those who could afford it would get the good programs-films, et cetera-but those out of reach for economic reasons would not be able to afford RSTV services. However, with the ABC, it would be quite possible to set up a situation where the Corporation makes money from a subscription service on a second channel, and ploughs the profits back into the Australian productions to be shown on either channel of the ABC. The ABC also has the added advantage of its network throughout Australia, something which no commercial channel has to the same extent. That is a cost-saving and economic factor in considering the desirability of a subscription service for the ABC.

I would urge the Government to consider this proposal strongly during the period in which the Parliament will be in recess. Perhaps it could also give rein to its free enterprise predelictions, and create an ABC subsidiary, possibly with access to the loan market, and charged with making a profit to run an RSTV service. I frankly have some doubts about the entrepreneurial capacity of the present ABC bureaucracy to deal with this question, but a subsidiary may be able to do it, if there is some incentive built in for those who would run the subsidiary.

I am supported in my view about the need for a second channel for the ABC by some recent remarks of the chairperson of the ABC, Professor Leonie Kramer. She has pointed out, quite rightly in my view, that a second channel would give the ABC far more flexibility with programming and provide an alternative outlet for quality programs. With a second channel the ABC would be able to do programs about regions and programs made in the regions. We could have a situation somewhat like that in Britain with British Broadcasting Corporation 1 and 2, where one offers light popular entertainment, and the other offers more serious programs.

The subsidiary idea, perhaps depending on loan capital and the subscription service, could go a long way towards meeting the costs. I commend that idea to the Government as something which is worth exploring. In that situation advertising would of course, as usual, be reserved for the commercials, but this would give a new source of money, free of the dangers of sponsorship, to the ABC and that is something which I again commend to the Government.

I turn briefly to the proposal for a commissioner for complaints, contained in the legislation. Under the Government's Bill this is to be a high profile, fully blown organisation riding over the ABC, with special terms of reference. ' Draconian' and 'outrageous' are some of the terms that have been rightly applied to this proposal in the Government's legislation. The proposal did not come from the Dix Committee of inquiry, which proposed a community affairs officer of the ABC to be in touch with the public over complaints. It is curious to reflect upon the fact that the Dix Committee, after months of public hearings and mountains of evidence, did not see fit to recommend anything like the complaints procedure laid down in the Government's legislation, which passed the House of Representatives. It is far wider than anything which applies under the Broadcasting and Television Act to the commercial or public sectors of broadcasting.

It would compromise investigative journalism and hamper the ABC in the proper performance of its duties. It usurps the rightful functions of the Commission, in having power to investigate complaints as to unfairness, bias or offensiveness. These judgmental matters on programing are matters for which the Commission itself is properly responsible, and should remain so. It is responsible under the legislation.
I can do no better than quote the Chairman of the BBC, Mr George Howard, who said:
The whole package of legislation is so bad, and so discriminatory that if I were a member of the ABC I would say 'Let's down tools and walk off in protest'.

These are strong words from the Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation about a piece of Australian legislation. He went on to say that if such legislation were to be introduced in Britain: 'I could not speak for the consequences'. The Opposition has very strong objections to the proposed complaints procedure and will be moving amendments to see that those procedures are deleted. If they are not deleted or amended in a satisfactory way they will be removed by the Senate.

We will also be moving amendments to give the Parliament an advise and consent role in the selection of ABC commissioners. We believe that it is absolutely crucial that the ABC be taken out of politics, especially when one looks at its history in the mid-1970s. We see much merit in a system whereby appointments continue to be made formally by the Governor-in-Council-that is, by the government of the day-but only after nominations have been referred to a joint all-party committee for recommendation. It is important that the ABC be like Caesar's wife and above suspicion in terms of the appointments that are made to it. The Australian Broadcasting Commission has a long and sad history of being seen as some sort of latter day antipodean House of Lords on the board of which retired party hacks and supporters are rewarded by being appointed-a disastrous approach to a national broadcasting organisation. Those matters, of course, can be dealt with in the Committee stage of the legislation.

I reiterate that the Opposition has a number of amendments to move. We very much regret that this legislation will not pass through the Senate tonight so that the ABC can start a new year in 1983 with a new approach to its role as laid down in the proposed charter and so that the Government will have the capacity to appoint very early, under procedures which I have suggested, a new board for the proposed Corporation. The ABC would then have been able to begin 1983 in an entirely new spirit of endeavour which the organisation has lacked for some period. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a point raised by Senator Button, since the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill came from the House of Representatives a number of things have happened. For example, there has been an amendment to the Public Service Act since the Bill left the House of Representatives. As a result, some amendments are necessary. Amendments are proposed by the Government to clause 42 on the promotion appeals procedures. That, for example, has become necessary. I know that the Government and the Opposition-Senator Button has said so-the Australian Democrats and, I believe, the independent senator will all be moving amendments to this legislation. It seems inevitable that it will be amended. The only point I make is that once it is amended in this place it cannot become law this year; it has to go back to the House of Representatives. It cannot become law until next year. There is no detriment to the ABC in following the procedure which is proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to support the comments made by Senator Button that it is a disgrace that this vitally important piece of legislation was not granted full debate during this session. Considerable discussion has taken place between the Government, the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the independent senator. I am sure that there is a great measure of agreement on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. As far as I can ascertain all parties are in agreement with the general thrust of the legislation. Certainly, some amendments are proposed. Some of the amendments that the Government proposes, as I understand it, have been viewed by the Democrats. We will support at least the proposed amendments that have come to our attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the Bills that pass through this place are relatively trivial or have importance only to a very small group of people. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill is a notable exception. It will have an impact on many, if not all, Australians. It sets the course for the ABC for perhaps the next 50 years. The ABC recently celebrated its fiftieth birthday. In those 50 years it has become a national institution. Many see it as the only guarantee of media freedom that is left; one of the remarkably few bulwarks against private monopoly of media ownership in this country. I say that advisedly. The ABC has an affectionate place in the hearts of most Australians. It is looked on as an objective medium through which people can see and hear the truth behind the news . It is, to me, a great pity-I do not want to pursue my comments in this area- that this vitally important piece of legislation, the most important piece of legislation which this chamber could have debated in many years and which, without any doubt, could have passed through this chamber during this session, has been delayed by the Government's actions. It seems that we will have to wait now until the new year, which is a great pity. Nobody knows what the new year has in store for us. Nobody knows whether we will have an election early or late in the year. A great opportunity has been lost, for which I criticise the Government.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion for Disallowance
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Regulations ( Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1982, No. 302 and made under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, be disallowed.

This motion seeks to disallow a regulation made under the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act. The regulation sets out prescribed reasons why employees in the Public Service may be subject to the redeployment and retirement provisions of that Act. It would perhaps be helpful if I recounted some of the background to this regulation so that the issues are better understood. Firstly, the so-called CE(RR) Act was debated and passed into law during May-June 1979. It occasioned a good deal of debate. Basically the Act established procedures for voluntary early retirement from age 55, maximum age retirement at 65, compulsory redeployment and, if necessary, retirement of sick and surplus staff. Some of the provisions in the CE(RR) legislation were welcomed by the Opposition, in particular the early retirement provisions. However, some other provisions were not so uncontroversial. In particular, the issue of management initiated early retirement remained a point of opposition for the Australian Labor Party. The CE(RR) Act provides for redeployment and, in some cases, ultimate retirement from the Public Service at any age for any employee who comes within the provisions of the Act. Section 7 (1) (b) sets out three reasons why this process may take place; firstly, excess staff situations; secondly, invalidity of staff; and, thirdly, any other reason. There is no dispute with the first two grounds. They are sensible enough and adequate and satisfactory procedures have been developed in consultation with the relevant unions to ensure their practical efficacy. The third ground, however, that of any other reason, is very wide. The Opposition expressed doubts in 1979 as to the appropriateness of giving the Executive such wide powers over the dismissal of public servants, over how they would be sacked or redeployed and why.

The wide language of section 7 (1) (b) (iii) of the CE(RR) Act allowed little parliamentary scrutiny of actions that could be taken under that provision. It is true that section 7 (2) of the Act provides that regulations prescribing reasons for the purposes of paragraph 7 (1) (b) shall not be made except after consideration by the Government of a report from the Public Service Board, made in consultation with the appropriate employee groups. That report has, of course , been made and despite opposition from the employee groups to the making of a regulation for the purpose of section 7 (1) (b) (iii) the regulation has been tabled. I understand that progress was made on the wording of the regulation. However, the Public Service groups involved remained opposed to the making of the regulation. The Opposition also feels that the regulation is inappropriate and seeks by this motion to have it disallowed.

The regulation sets out two matters as prescribed reasons for the purposes of section 7 (1) (b) (iii) of the Act: First, that the employee is inefficient, and , secondly, that the employee is not qualified to perform his or her duties. I wish to concentrate on the first matter as it is there that the opposition to the regulation lies. The regulation purports to set up a standard of efficiency that has not previously been operative in the context of the Public Service. The Opposition is not against efficiency but the regulation introduces a concept of unrestricted relative inefficiency. The existing practices can be understood to proceed on the following basis. Employees are required to maintain a reasonable level of efficiency in the performance of their duties. Such a test involves a comparison of relative efficiency between employees but the normal expectations that exist between employers and employees mean that, provided that the least efficient employees maintain a standard of work that is judged by their employers as reasonable, they will be protected. This is not a case of perpetuating inefficiencies. It simply means that normal work practices are maintained and that employees, if they continue to satisfy their employers as to their work performance, can keep their jobs.

This regulation will change this practice. The effect of the regulation will be to remove the safety net of normal work practices. The least efficient employees would be removed from the Service until the best persons offering from the outside labour market were found to be only equal to the least efficient employees, regardless of their age. This appears to the Opposition to be a strict and impersonal view of the way that the employer-employee relationship should be handled. It also appears that the regulation would add to the degree of job insecurity faced by particular classes of employees in the Service. Those classes could perhaps be summarised into two areas: First, those with restricted degrees of skill and experience, and, secondly, those who require average or above average degrees of physical strength. This result will flow because these classes of employees are more readily identifiable and available in the outside labour market than are other classes. Assessments as to relative inefficiencies would inevitably be made more readily in these two classes of employees.

It could also be questioned whether this regulation is really needed. The Public Service Act already contains provisions to deal with excess staff situations and wilful inefficiency. I refer to sections 20 and 67 of the Public Service Act. Also, as I have already mentioned, sections 7 (1) (b) (i) and (ii) provide for the CE(RR) Act to operate in excess staff and invalidity situations. In the view of the Opposition, it is not appropriate, in times of high unemployment, to be threatening the jobs of people who could find it difficult to secure alternative employment. Accordingly, I have moved for the disallowance of this regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the disallowance of this regulation, promulgated under the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Act. The Democrats have the gravest reservations about management-initiated redevelopment and retirement in the Australian Public Service. Given that we cannot amend a regulation into a form which we would approve, we have no choice but to disallow the regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier today, politicians must be aware not only of the means and the ends but also the consequences, of their actions. They must be prepared to take responsibility for the consequences of their actions even if these cannot be reasonably foreseen. This regulation is superficially attractive but it could be used to redeploy compulsorily and, in practice, retrench or retire, individuals essentially through no fault of their own. In other words, it can be very discriminatory. Individuals whom the management of a department did not like could be got at on a highly selective and undesirable basis. I note that my colleague Senator Mason spoke against the relevant section of this Act when it came before this place in 1979. We maintain our opposition to it. I will not delay the Senate any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose the disallowance. First of all, I want to make perfectly clear the consequences of disallowance. It is very important that this be understood. The disallowance of these regulations will have the effect of leaving no legislative basis on which the Public Service Board can act in relation to inefficient and incompetent officers. Those honourable senators who tonight vote for disallowance will take away from the Public Sevice Board any power to act in relation to inefficient or incompetent officers. That power and responsibility exists in all other places of employment. What Senator Button has said shows a misunderstanding or, at the very least, a very serious exaggeration, of this situation. The protections within these regulations for officers of the Public Service are very stringent. Safeguards for the protection of officers and the preservation of standards are all there. Grounds for appeal are there.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing for me to do is to state the fundamental facts. They are that the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act provides, first of all, for the identification by a permanent head of officers who are excess to requirements, who are physically or mentally incapacitated or for other prescribed reasons. Does anyone suggest that it is not proper for a permanent head to identify officers in those categories? That is done in every business in the land. Secondly, it provides for the redeployment of officers so identified to positions which they are competent to perform-that happens in ordinary enterprise-and for the issue of a certificate by the Public Service Board in cases where it is not practicable to redeploy the officers. If that certificate is issued, there is an appeal, and the appeal is not upheld, retirement follows. The procedures are such, I stress, that at every point the officer is protected. Officers involved in these processes have the right to appeal against each of these decisions at each of these steps. That is a vastly different thing from what was said by the Leader of the Opposition. Appeals are considered by the Commonwealth Employees Redeployment and Retirement Appeals Tribunal which can, in effect, halt the action at any of the three steps I have mentioned.

The purpose of the regulations which are the subject of the motion is to prescribe the reasons for identifying an officer as being inefficient or as being not qualified for the position which he occupies. The regulations also elaborate on the meaning of 'inefficient' and 'not qualified'. In every industry in the land and in every employment circumstance in the land, provision is made for identifying officers who are incompetent or inefficient. Of course, that includes a person who is physically, mentally or medically incompetent. Why would anyone stand up in this place and seek to disallow regulations which are available elsewhere in these situations? If that identification has been made and if the officer feels aggrieved, at that point he can challenge it on any of the grounds-physical or mental incapacity, excess of requirement or for other prescribed reasons.

If no appeal is lodged or if an appeal is not upheld then redeployment can take place. Redeployment takes place everywhere else in the land. Inside the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which we discussed earlier, redeployment can take place. If, indeed, the officer feels that the identification of that position is adverse, an appeal can be made again. The third situation relates to the issue of a certificate by the Public Service Board in cases where it is not possible to redeploy. Under no circumstances can these regulations or the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act be considered to be draconian, to be different from the ordinary procedures of the community at large. On the contrary, clearly, every employer, public or private, must have the right to identify persons excess to requirements; must have the right to determine whether people are incompetent or inefficient on physical, mental or other grounds; and must have the right to redeploy staff. If there is no way in which redeployment, perhaps for medical, mental or physical conditions, cannot be done then ultimately there must be the right to retire.

I repeat that at every level there is a right of appeal. There is far more protection than that offered in private enterprise. All stages are publicly known. The rights of individuals are known. I repeat: An act of disallowance tonight would be deliberately and knowingly-every honourable senator who votes for the disallowance will do this-remove from the Public Service Board and the Commonwealth any power at all. That is the advice I have received from the Public Service Board and from its objective and expert officers. The Public Service Board would have no ability to act with regard to incompetent or inefficient officers. That in itself would be a remarkably bad situation.

I cannot understand how anybody could proceed that way. If the Opposition parties believe that there is something wrong with the regulations then they can put to the Government arguments to have them amended. Instead of seeking to amend some particular aspect, in one sweep the Opposition tonight is trying to destroy the regulations totally. What an extraordinary situation it is that the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats do not come forward with any particularity of argument about any particular part of the regulations. They have not made any plea to the Government. They have not asked it to consider a particular problem and to consider amending a particular aspect of the regulations. The Government has the power to amend the regulation, to withdraw it, or to issue a new regulation if it so desires.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't amend it.

—Of course Senator Harradine cannot amend it. Honourable senators opposite should keep in mind that the proper thing for them to do is to make suggestions to the Government and let the Government consider them. I indicate to honourable senators before this vote is taken that if they are willing to put, either in writing or verbally to me or to any other Minister , suggestions as to what the defects are, in other words, particularities, rather than wipe out the whole regulation so that there are no powers at all, I will undertake to have the Government consider them in depth and I will undertake to report back to the Senate so we can have a debate. I appeal to the Senate not to throw the baby out with the bath water. That would be very unreasonable. Let honourable senators express individually what they want. The Government will take their suggestions seriously. I will take them to the Government and have them discussed. I ask honourable senators to reassess the situation and to give us a reasonable chance over the recess to consider their suggestions. They will be given very detailed consideration, I promise that.

—by leave-I heard the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) with interest. He was persuasive. I ask him whether, if we adjourn this debate this evening and avail ourselves of his offer in the interim, it will keep the regulation alive but not kill it. Can honourable senators have an understanding in that case that on the first or second day of the sitting in February this matter can be resumed and debated? Would there be no harm done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There would be no harm done at all. I understand that there are something like 13 more sitting days to run. If that is right, clearly we have the time. I say with full amity that I will undertake to bring on this debate when the Senate resumes at the earliest date that is suitable to the leaders and to the Independent in this place. In the meantime, I invite all honourable senators to submit, through me, suggestions as to the appropriate nature of the regulations. I will have them considered. If I get them early enough I will be able to make a report at the intervention of the debate. I undertake to do this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This seems to me to be a fairly acceptable arrangement. I pointed out during my remarks that the Australian Democrats did not have the opportunity to amend this regulation. We are concerned about the concept of accountability in the Public Service. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) stressed that point in the remarks he just made. It seems to me that having some time to consider this matter and to arrive at a solution which would take into account some of the comments of the Minister would be a good solution.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Chipp) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During the Committee stages of the Salaries and Wages Pause Bill 1982 I asked for some information in respect of clause 7 of that Bill. Senator Chaney has provided that information. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate this information in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

To: Senator the Hon. F. M. Chaney
Minister for Social Security
Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations
Re: The matter raised by Senator Bolkus during Committee stage of the Salary and Wages Pause Bill 1982

I have discussed this matter with the Acting First Parliamentary Counsel, Mr G. Harders, who indicated to me that the exclusion of 8 (1A) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act from the provisions of Clause 7 of the bill was because it is a new office for which a determination has not been made.
