DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Annual Reports of Special Broadcasting Service: Government Response- Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations presented its report on the first and second annual reports of the Special Broadcasting Service-SBS-on 27 May 1982. This statement responds on behalf of the Government to that report. The Committee criticised the performance of the SBS in the following matters:

SPEECH.PARA: the incorporation of two periods in the first report of the SBS, that is, 1 January to 30 June 1978 and 1 July 1978 to 30 June 1979;
the delay of some nine months in presenting the report incorporating these two periods; and
the delay of some 10 months in tabling the 1979-80-the second-annual report of the SBS.

The SBS responded to the Committee that these delays were occasioned largely by administrative difficulties resulting from the newness of the SBS and the lack of experienced staff in financial and other areas. The second annual report was further delayed by problems which arose when the material was sent for printing. Honourable senators are referred to the Standing Committee report for details of the SBS response.

Honourable senators will agree that the SBS has been very successful in the first years of its operations, notably in the establishment at very short notice of multicultural television in Sydney and Melbourne. It is inevitable that, in these circumstances, organisations will be subjected to considerable stress and pressure.

Nevertheless, the Government agrees with the Standing Committee's view that the SBS was remiss in not having due regard to its statutory obligations to report to the Parliament as soon as possible after the end of the financial year. The Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) has taken steps to ensure that delays in the tabling of SBS annual reports do not recur and that the SBS is fully aware of its statutory obligations. The Minister wrote to the Chairman of the SBS asking that the 1981-82 report be available as soon as possible and instructed his Department to follow through with this request. As honourable senators will be aware, I tabled the SBS annual report for 1981-82 earlier today .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am sure, speaking as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations but without having had an opportunity to consider the statement, that the Committee will be glad that the Government agrees that the Special Broadcasting Service was remiss in not having regard to its statutory obligations. I am glad that steps are being taken to rectify the matter. But there was a broader matter which was not referred to and to which I would ask for some future Government response. On page 63 of the sixth report of the Committee, in dealing with this matter, a broader question was raised. The Committee said in paragraph 7.5.2:

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee has previously noted that authorities are too often conceived and born in haste by government and given obligations that often cause varying degrees of difficulty in settling a form of accounts and preparing a first annual report for timely presentation. We have noted in detail in our Third Report on statutory authorities that little care or foresight is taken to consider accounting and administrative problems which may arise in the case of a significant number of new statutory authorities. The problems incurred by the SBS with relation to its accounts were an example of this situation. There is a need for guidelines and briefing to authorities on their procedures, duties and obligations.
I repeat the last two lines of the paragraph, which state:
There is a need for guidelines and briefing to authorities on their procedures, duties and obligations.

I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) whether he will ask the Government to respond to that particular part as well as the general part. I am sure the response will be welcomed by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I thank the Government for the response.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick)-by leave-proposed:

That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate at its rising adjourn till Tuesday, 22 February 1983 at 1.45 p.m., or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed by the President or, in the event of the President being unavailable due to illness or other cause, by the Deputy President, and that the day and/or hour of the meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator.
Amendment (by Senator Button) agreed to:

At the end of motion add ', provided that the President, upon a request or requests by an absolute majority of the whole number of Senators that the Senate meet at a certain time, shall fix a day and hour of meeting in accordance with such request or requests, and such time of meeting shall be notified to each Senator.

For these purposes a request by the Leader or Deputy Leader of the Opposition shall be deemed to be a request by every Senator of the Opposition and a request by the Leader or Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats shall be deemed to be a request by every Australian Democrat Senator.
Provided further, that the request or request a may be made to the President by leaving the same with, or delivering the same to, the Clerk of the Senate, who shall immediately notify the President.

In the event of the President being unavailable, the Clerk shall without delay notify the Deputy President, or, should he be unavailable, any one of the Temporary Chairman of Committees, who shall be deemed to be required by the Senate to summon the Senate on behalf of the President, in accordance with the terms of this Resolution'.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick)-by leave-agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this point each year immediately prior to Christmas it is one of our pleasant duties to pay some tributes and to express with full sincerity to those around us our thanks for the year that has passed and our good wishes for the Christmas season and for health and happiness for all the year ahead, and I so do. In doing so I would like first to start with you, Mr President.
—Don't forget the chef this year. You forgot the chef last year.

—I will be grateful if honourable senators will help me in this matter. Senator Button and I will be speaking, as will other honourable senators, in a unanimous way. Mr President, you have brought to your very high office a dignity, impartiality and an equable temperament which has given character to this Senate. You have been a very distinguished President in your still relatively short term of office. We congratulate you not only upon attaining that office but also in the way you have executed your duties. May we, through you to your charming wife, say how much we enjoy her company and her gracious hospitality as a hostess.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the people who make this Parliament work. I thank the Clerks and the Senate officers. I mention too the particular Clerk who is very subjectively looking after me, Tom Wharton. I thank Mr Cumming Thom--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is favouritism.

—Yes, it is utter favouritism indeed. I say to all the Senate staff: 'You do a wonderful job'. The fact is that we impose enormous strains in the kind of battlefield this is with the unexpected skirmishes and the raids that all of us undertake. You are the people who have to adapt yourselves to this situation. You do it with skill and dedication and, again, with a temperament which takes into account this strange, this unique place. It was Churchill who said that the democratic system was the worst of all systems in the world except for all others. There is no doubt in this world that this is so. This is a unique place with unique stresses. In its way it is a battlefield. So we ask Mr Clerk to convey our thanks to all of his officers. I thank all of the attendants for the excellent job they do for us throughout the year. I do not forget those who look after the cars and the very special things for us.
—You are forgetting the chef again.

—No, I have not come to him yet. These people have become not just our helpmates but our real friends. They know our families and help us. I thank them for that. I thank each of the parliamentary departments. I thank Hansard, on whom we have put very great strains in the past and particularly in recent weeks. I thank the Parliamentary Library, the Joint House Department and the chefs, brown dogs or no brown dogs. I thank the delightful girls who serve us and who serve us so well in the parliamentary rooms.

SPEECH.PARA: Having got those in their right order I now turn to the members of this chamber , not in any order of precedence. I thank my ministerial colleagues who have the intolerable job of putting up with me and pretending that it is not too hard. I thank the Whips of all parties. I acknowledge the great job that they do under great strain every day. Although it may seem that they are able to take confusion and confound it, somehow or other it works out. I thank also their staff. I acknowledge the Press who have the job somehow or other of interpreting what we do. I thank particularly my colleague the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, for his good humour and also for his courtesy and his friendship . I acknowledge that he is a doughty opponent and a doughty leader and that he has led his people very well indeed. I pay tribute to his leadership and to the support given to him by his deputies and his Whips. I acknowledge the Australian Democrats who let us know that they are here. I acknowledge Senator Brian Harradine who plays a unique role being something like the Pooh-Bah in The Mikado, not an individual but a consortium or a condominium.

I do not wish to speak at length except to say one or two things in great friendship. The Senate has been setting something of a record, I do not think intentionally. I am told that this is the latest sitting for over 40 years. This , like most things that happen in democracies, may be accidental. I am told that 21 December 1912 was the latest that the Senate has sat. It is only by lack of charity that honourable senators did not get into the Guinness Book of Records. Whilst I do not think there is any merit in claiming lengths of sessions because sitting days vary, it is interesting to know that we have sat for 43 sitting days. That is the most sitting days for the last eight years. This session has been very strenuous and vigorous. On all sides issues have been held passionately and strongly, and, I think, sincerely. All sides have fought these issues well and vigorously. Yet we have managed to remain friends. That is the business of this place.

Some 1,000 or more years ago, a similar chamber decided to fight with words instead of swords. Equally the fight with words should be as sharp and as effective as the fight with swords. I believe that both sides know something about that. It is a fact that we do have the lines drawn apart three rapiers' lengths. In that spirit, may I wish all in this place a very happy Christmas and New Year. I wish particularly for a healthy year ahead. If we have fought and glared at each other occasionally, nevertheless, I thank honourable senators for the friendships which prevail across the chamber despite all those factors because, while we can fight with ideas and still respect each other, this Parliament is worth while.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week, I thought that there could be no place, in spirit and in everything else, more remote from the stable at Bethlehem than the Senate. But we have reached the end of the year . On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to reciprocate the remarks and tributes which the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, has made to various people. I do not, and I have never done, attempt to emulate the lengthy way in which he sometimes expresses matters, but I do reciprocate in terms of the tributes which he has made. On behalf of the Opposition, I wish everybody a happy Christmas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to endorse the sentiments that have been expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). It is pleasant to have a word to say in this chamber in which there is unanimity in the views of all of us. Indeed, it is pleasant that, as the dust of the conflict of recent days and weeks drifts aside , we can emerge from that conflict as Australians. We are aware that, as we go out in this Christmas period, great challenges confront all Australians. I am sure not only that we are aware of that fact but also that we are capable of meeting those challenges. We have a proud history in peace and war. As the rhetoric and sometimes even insults of the past weeks and months disappear, I trust we will find that the period of good will that normally exists at Christmas is as it has always been. Mr President, I wish you a very happy Christmas. I thank you for your efforts to maintain a measure of decorum in this chamber. I thank all the officers of this chamber including the people who work with Hansard, the attendants and other staff, wherever they are employed. They have all contributed to the ultimate survival, shall I say, of this chamber and indeed this institution. I wish one and all on both sides of this chamber a happy Christmas and a healthy and prosperous 1983.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, thanked everybody so comprehensively and with such an attractiveness and eloquence that there seems nothing left for me to say except to endorse everything that he said and perhaps send a cheerio to Senator Janine Haines who is recovering from very painful surgery after hospitalisation and to the Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack- just to name two-who, I am sure, are glued to the radio this evening. There is something magic about this place. There are two people-Liberal senators-who shall remain nameless, who were absolutely anathema to me a couple of weeks ago during the Franklin River debate.
—And a happy Christmas to you, too!

—My friend Senator Siddons and I played tennis today against those two honourable senators. I did not intend to name them because the result was decidedly in our favour; but, if Senator Martyr wants to identify himself by way of interjection, he can do so. I endorse everything Senator Sir John Carrick said. Next year is going to be a brutal year, not for us necessarily but for the country. It will take all our wit and all the sort of co-operation that, frankly , we have seen today. It is rather strange that on the last day the Senate has seen more co-operation between parties than it has in all of the last six weeks. I would hope that that spirit of co-operation and consensus might continue. Mr President, I wish you, your wife and your family well.

—Very briefly, in the spirit of the occasion, I join with other honourable senators and support some of the wishes that have been expressed. I refer in particular to Senate committee staff and advisers, that most essential and vital part of our total operations. Quite often when we are talking in the chamber we tend to refer to that which is immediately associated with the chamber and forget that which is the other half of the total work of the Senate. I simply pay tribute to the particularly valuable work that has been done this year and the fairly massive input from the staff and advisers of the Senate committee system, to the benefit of Australia. I adopt the general sentiments of other honourable senators.
—I join my leader, Senator Sir John Carrick, and others who have spoken. I congratulate honourable senators for the restraint they have exemplified during this very arduous six years of sittings.
—It only seems that long.

—I have probably been here longer than most honourable senators. I suggest, Mr President, without innuendo, that a golden feather award ought to be presented-I make no suggestion as to who should receive it-to the senator who has shown the most restraint with respect to the impulse to speak in this last week of session. That award ought to be presented in perpetuity. I think that such an effort by an honourable senator would be an example to us all. As I have said, I have been here for a long time. On that basis I can say that the last two or three weeks of sittings have been very tough. I pay tribute to all parties and to all members of the Senate for the exemplary way in which they have behaved over the last week. Incidentally, I think the golden feather award ought to be named after a person who may retire in due course. I wish everyone in the Senate a happy Christmas and a merry New Year.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with the sentiments expressed by all honourable senators this evening. In doing so I wish to thank quite a few people . First of all I thank the Deputy President, Senator Douglas McClelland, and the Temporary chairmen who assisted me from the Chair. I thank them very sincerely for the way in which they have so loyally carried out their duties which at times, I can assure honourable senators, have been rather onerous when there has been so much activity in the chamber and everything focuses on the Chair. I look forward to working with them again next year.

INTERJECT.PARA: I refer also to the leaders of the parties. The pressures on senators from each side of the chamber and on the Chair can be extreme at times. I sincerely thank all leaders of parties for the way in which they have co-operated with the Chair . I also thank the Whips and Deputy Whips for their co-operation. I thank all honourable senators. There were times during the session when I wondered whether I would get to the stage of even being here now to thank you for your co- operation. I say that in jest: I thank honourable senators most sincerely for the way in which they have co-operated. The cut and thrust of politics has been demonstrated very clearly during this rather long and strenuous session, particularly during the last six weeks. Senator Jessop spoke about the session lasting for six years; I am sure he meant six weeks. No doubt the sitting at times felt like six years. Nevertheless, over and above all the cut and thrust of politics, it clearly came out that honourable senators accept their responsibilities and have respect for this chamber. I thank all honourable senators for the way in which they have conducted themselves.

I thank the Clerks, the other table officers and all officers associated with the Senate for what they have done. Of course, I cannot forget the Committee staff mentioned by Senator Peter Rae and those other very delightful people who help us so much in this place-the attendants. I thank also the transport officers, the men of patience and wisdom in this place. I could find out when we were likely to rise only by going to the transport officer. He was never far off the mark. I mention one group of people in this place who work behind the scenes and are rarely seen. They are the staff of the reproduction area. I do not think honourable senators appreciate just how dedicated these people are, the many hours they put in and how they work to help this place operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the girls from the Records Office?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I must not be seen to be sexist. I thank the girls from the Records Office. I was going to mention all the people in the Records Office. I thank the Joint House Department staff from the dining room to the kitchen right through to the garden, they do such a wonderful job. I thank the Hansard staff who make every honourable senator's speech read very well. We thank them for what they have done through the year. I thank the Library staff for the way in which they have assisted in the Parliament. I thank the Government Printer and his staff, and the Australian Broadcasting Commission staff who broadcast the proceedings of the Parliament and rebroadcast Question Time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Whilst this has been a long session-nearly a record breaker, as Senator Sir John Carrick said-I nevertheless take this opportunity of again thanking all honourable senators very much. I wish you a merry Christmas and all the best in both health and prosperity in 1983. I hope that you will bring a little bit of the Christmas spirit back into this chamber in 1983, if only for the sake of the Chair.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory: Microwave Telephone Links-North West Shelf Project: Australian Steel Industry-Australian Broadcasting Commission: Use of Music for Program on South West Tasmania- South West Tasmania

PROCTEXT.PARA: Northern Territory: Microwave Telephone Links-North West Shelf Project: Australian Steel Industry-Australian Broadcasting Commission: Use of Music for Program on South West Tasmania- South West Tasmania
Motion (By Senator Sir John Carrick) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that at this late hour of the last day of the 1982 Budget sittings I have to take up the time of the Senate but I shall be brief. I speak now because it is very difficult these days for a Whip, or even other honourable senators, to get an opportunity to speak. The conduct of business in the Senate has been rather intense, as has Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly this evening I take up a matter which I have been endeavouring to raise for the last week or two. I refer to the microwave telephonic links in the Northern Territory. Telecom Australia, as honourable senators realise, is responsible for communications links throughout Australia, but its role is particularly important in the outback. Telecom provides microwave links to various new, very isolated projects. But these days it seems unable to raise money to finance these rather expensive links to the outback. I particularly refer to the spur links, as they are described, to Yulara at Ayers Rock and to Groote Eylandt. It is a policy of Telecom not to finance spur links. The cost of the spur link to Ayers Rock from the North-South facility could be a million-odd dollars. The user has to pay for the service but what he pays goes into the coffers of Telecom. I think it is a very big strain on the Northern Territory Government and the promoters in the area who have to find a huge amount of finance to carry out these projects. On top of that there is the demand for the construction of a microwave link by Telecom. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press statement relating to this project.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Chief Minister Darwin 1-238-82
2 December 1982
PRESS RELEASE BY THE CHIEF MINISTERMR PAUL EVERINGHAM
The Northern Territory Government has reluctantly committed $2.7 million for the construction of a micro-wave link to deliver communications to the Yulara tourist resort near Ayers Rock.

The $2.7 million commitment was approved at the first meeting of the new Everingham cabinet meeting in Darwin yesterday. Telecom has committed $1 million towards the program for the exchange and cable reticulation at Yulara.

The chief minister, Paul Everingham, said it was a sad state of affairs when the Northern Territory had to spend $2.7 million to provide its own communications system to Australia's major international tourist village, which is already costing $110 million to construct and service.
'The new micro-wave link will also service Willowra, Curtain Springs, Mt Ebenezer, Angus Downs, Mulga Park and the Uluru National Park,' Mr Everingham said.
'Yulara is currently served by two radio telephone links and two radio telex links.

'The commitment by the Northern Territory Government will allow the micro-wave link to Alice Springs to be extended to bring full telephone and radio communications to Yulara by the time the international resort opens towards the end of 1984.
'Unless the Territory Government had picked up the lion's share of the financing of the communications system, the economic viability of the project could not be fully exploited.
'You don't expect Australian and overseas tourists to lock themselves away from the world-wide communications links for days at a time in this modern world.'
Mr Everingham said both the Commonwealth Government and Telecom should have shouldered the financial responsibility for the communications network in Central Australia.
''It points to the intransigence of the Commonwealth in not allowing Telecom to raise the level of its capital works funds for essential projects such as this,' Mr Everingham said.
'It also appears that Telecom is unable to adjust its priorities to accommodate projects of national importance such as Yulara.

'I will support the recommendations made in the Davidson Committee of inquiry for greater freedom and flexibility for Telecom as a public compnay so that many of the bureaucratic strangleholds exercised on that organisation are removed.'
Ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Press statement is self-explanatory so I will not take the Yulara matter any further. However, I will refer to Groote Eylandt. A microwave link has been installed at Groote Eylandt by a mining company. It has limited service to the people in the area, the Aboriginal people of Ngukurr and Umbakumba, the people at the trawling base and the fishermen in the Gulf of Carpentaria. These people have a very limited line of communication. It is the policy of Telecom that these isolated places should pay for the microwave link. It was stated in the report of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia', which recently looked into Telecom, that its structure should be changed to form a totally Australian Government owned company through which finance could be raised to finance such projects. I believe this would be extremely good for projects in isolated areas. I was going to ask a question this morning but because of the intense interest in Question Time I could not get the call. This is the reason I felt that I had to raise the matter tonight. I conclude by putting my question on the Notice Paper. I hope that the Government will see fit to pursue the recommendations of the Davidson report on telecommunications.

SPEECH.PARA: In the more remote areas of the Northern Territory such as Yulara, the new Ayers Rock village, and Groote Eylandt in the Gulf of Carpentaria, where the population is made up of mining employees, a large number of Aborigines and public servants and which acts as a victualling port for trawlers et cetera, communications through microwave links are provided under the Telecom spur line policy. This requires the user to finance the link with the revenue, in the case of Yulara, going to Telecom. I understand that Telecom says that it cannot borrow enough to finance such isolated projects despite a need for them. Perhaps many more are on the drawing board. With this in mind and considering the recommendations of the Davidson report on telecommunications that a wholly government owned company should be established to finance and achieve better communications, particularly in outback areas, the question I leave for the Government to answer eventually is: What action is the Government taking to remedy the established spur line policy to finance such projects in a more equitable manner?

Mr President, I take this opportunity of wishing you all the best for Christmas and the New Year. You have had a most difficult job. I also take the opportunity , as Government Whip, to thank the Opposition and Democrat Whips who have worked with me. I also have much pleasure in thanking my fellow government senators who have been of such tremendous assistance to me in these difficult months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on a matter which was raised during the grievance debate in the House of Representatives last Thursday. In that debate the honourable member for Adelaide , Mr Hurford, said that only 1.5 per cent of the steel used on the North West Shelf gas project in Western Australia was coming from Australian suppliers. This, he contended, was occurring at a time when the Australian steel industry was facing difficulties and having to resort to retrenchments to survive. Unfortunately the honourable member for Adelaide did not reflect on these two matters as he might have done. If he had he would have understood that the retrenchments and, to some extent, the placement of orders for steel outside Australia are, in fact, symptoms of the same disease-the lack of competitiveness of the Australian steel industry.

SPEECH.PARA: These factors are not an indication that the partners developing the North West Shelf gas have not a policy of supporting local suppliers whenever possible, as the honourable member for Adelaide implied. In fact, to the beginning of December 1982 contracts and purchase orders worth $1,102m had been let by the North West Shelf joint ventures. Of that amount, 58 per cent or $634m has been spent in the State of Western Australia. A further 10 per cent, or $112m, has been spent elsewhere in Australia. The remaining 32 per cent, or $356m, has been spent overseas. But the matter does not end there. More than half of the money which the joint venturers spent overseas, including work in fabricating the North Rankin A jacket and the steel pipe for the submarine pipeline, was so allocated because it was work that, the joint venturers say, could not have been performed in Australia. That is crucial. It was money spent overseas because the necessary capacity did not exist in Australia.

However, the honourable member for Adelaide has put forward another red herring which cannot pass without comment. Recognising the lack of industrial capacity in certain areas, he asked why new fabricating capacity to supply the project was not set up. The honourable member for Adelaide obviously has never been a businessman because if he had he would have understood that the cost of setting up this new capacity would have to be defrayed against the North West Shelf project for it to be viable. Unlike, say, the Japanese who at the moment have spare capacity in suitable areas for use on North West Shelf work, we would have to meet the cost of setting up new capacity without any guarantee that it would be used after the gas project had been completed. To meet those establishment costs the local venture would have to build them into the price offered the North West Shelf venturers which would, of course, make its price uncompetitive against that of overseas fabricators.

There is no doubt that this is the case because if it were not, if it had been viable to set up new capacity and there were prospects that it would not become redundant when the project had been completed, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd itself certainly would have provided that capacity. After all, through its wholly owned subsidiary, Hematite Petroleum Proprietary Ltd, BHP has an 8 1/3 per cent interest in the project. That it did not set up new capacity surely demonstrates the shallowness of the proposition put by the honouable member for Adelaide. But, as I said earlier, the underlying problem is the lack of competitiveness of Australian industry, especially the steel industry, which estimates that it will need to invest about $2,800m in the next 10 years to remain viable. That demonstrates just how uncompetitive our industry is at present.

If the North West Shelf project were forced into a position in which it could not choose its suppliers, if it were not allowed to pursue its policy of giving preference to Australian suppliers where price, quality, delivery and service are competitive, its future would be of course very grim. The huge investment already made and the larger amounts forthcoming would be jeopardised if normal commercial criteria for allocating work could not be continued. That would jeopardise the jobs of 3,000 employees directly engaged in the project and up to 10,000 more indirectly supported by it. It would also jeopardise the potentially enormous contribution to Australia's export earnings and to the degree of energy self-sufficiency of the State of Western Australia. If it is the policy of the Australian Labor Party to stifle development through its ill-advised intentions in industry, it should say so. It will certainly be roundly condemned by the people of Australia, by the people of Western Australia and, particularly, by the people of the north-west of Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Australian Broadcasting Commission in Tasmania has announced that it will use the March of the Pathfinders as the background music for a program on the blockade of the Franklin dam. I could not imagine anything in worse taste than linking the historic action of that group of heroic airmen, the Dambusters, who were prepared to give their lives for their country, with that of a group of people who are prepared to break the law of our State and lie in front of men going about their lawful duties in the course of lawful work. Those young demonstrators are perhaps forgiven for not being aware that but for the valour of men such as the Dambusters they would not have the freedom to demonstrate about anything, far less have the right to voice a view opposing that of the ruling Government. They have never had their freedom challenged so how could they possibly understand?

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is no excuse whatever for the ABC to forget these facts and to denigrate the memory of what was considered to be one of the main actions leading to the turning point in the war against Germany. The Dambusters captured the imagination of the free world. It is a great disappointment to me that a responsible body such as the ABC acted so distastefully. Returned servicemen have expressed their views to me about the ABC. I apologise to them on behalf of the ABC for its lack of respect to them. Whilst I understand the autonomous nature of the ABC, I urge the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) to do all he can to point out to the Commissioners of the ABC the error that has been made and to ask that that error be corrected immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak for only a moment. Senator Walters tonight denigrated the views and opinions of a group of sincere people who believe that there should not be a dam in South West Tasmania. Senator Walters used as her excuse for this speech the fact that they used the theme of the film The Dambusters in their protest. I wish to point out to the Senate that Senator Walters at all times has supported the views of the Right to Life Association of Victoria. She blockaded a legal organisation in Victoria and, in that protest, condemned women who went into that legal organisation. She considered this to be a reasonable protest which people in this community can accept. But tonight she chose to denigrate not only young people but also older people-for example, business people-who sincerely believe that what is happening in South West Tasmania is wrong on economic grounds. I think that her attitude is contemptible.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude she took tonight in the speech that she read in this place is a cheap debating trick which is typical of the approach of people of her type who choose to denigrate ordinary working class people in this community who believe that what they are doing is right and that they have the right to protest. If she persists in this attitude she is saying that no one in this community should be allowed to express a view contrary to that of the Government. That means that democracy means nothing in this community. Therefore, I am very sad that I have to stand tonight and suggest that Senator Walters is expressing the views of fascists in our community who believe that no one has the right to protest against a decision of the Federal Government. I think it is a very sad thing that someone in this Federal Parliament takes that view. I think it would be unfortunate if she wished to persist with that view. As long as there are some of us left who can point out that that is the view she takes there is some hope for our democracy. I remind her that people who are very close to her objected to the building of the Snowy Mountains scheme. She did not object at that time, and she does not object to their right to make that protest; but she rises tonight and condemns, like Mr Robin Gray, the Premier of Tasmania, anyone who protests about what is happening in Tasmania. It is a sad thing when someone who claims to be a democrat rises in this place to try to condemn the views of people who make an innocent and democratic protest in this community. But that is the view of Senator Walters, and I think that we should expose it as that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—The speech that we have just heard from Senator Grimes has misrepresented what I said in this place completely. No one here who listened to him would not agree with me. He said that I had denigrated people demonstrating in South West Tasmania. As a matter of fact, the only time I mentioned them was to say that they could be forgiven by us for not understanding-because they are young; they were not alive during the war years-that their rights to demonstrate have been preserved only by these valiant men. The people I was criticising were those of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, not the people demonstrating in South West Tasmania. I was criticising the ABC. If Senator Grimes reads Hansard when it appears tomorrow, or when he gets it next week, he will see that this is so. This is the second time this week I have had occasion to ask him to apologise. He has been wrong on two occasions.
—Mr Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I have been misrepresented.
—The honourable senator may proceed.
—Senator Walters claims that all she is doing is complaining about the Australian Broadcasting Commission reporting the facts. If she is concerned about the ABC reporting the facts-
—I have not; God save us!
—She is in even greater error than she was before. The ABC reported the facts that these people used that march-
—Senator Grimes, you will have to relate your remarks to a personal explanation.
—I am doing that, Mr Deputy President.
—With respect, you are not; I suggest that you relate your remarks to your personal explanation.
—Senator Walters claimed that the people who were protesting in South West Tasmania were using the theme of the film The Dambusters in their campaign. She then complained that the ABC reported that.
—I did not.
—The ABC should report that, at every stage. If Senator Walters wants to gag the ABC, she is the greatest censor that this country has ever seen .
—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—At no stage did I criticise the Australian Broadcasting Commission for reporting on occurrences in South West Tasmania. At no stage did I claim that the demonstrators were using the music of the Dambusters. I think that Senator Grimes ought to wait until he gets Hansard, because he obviously did not listen. Very clearly, I was criticising the ABC for announcing that it will use next week the music of the film The Dambusters, the March of the Pathfinders, as part of its program dealing with the demonstration in South West Tasmania.
—So it should.
—So I hope that Senator Grimes will apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This discussion has got a little out of hand. I think that Senator Walters has misread the Australian Broadcasting Commission's use of the particular theme. As I see it, the use of that theme in relation to the protesters concerned with South West Tasmania is an ironic use of that music . It is meant to show by paradox and contrast that the theme of the film The Dambusters is being used for the play on words that the title implies. The fact is that the people who are protesting against the construction of the dam, even though they are breaking the law of trespass, and I acknowledge that, are nevertheless trained in non-violence and are extremely self-disciplined. They always have been conscious of the need amongst themselves to act in a non- violent manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrast that with the glorifying of war, even though it was defensive, that was involved in the film The Dambusters, even though there were great heroic events and persons recorded in that film. The fact is that in the film the destruction of property and human life was portrayed on a massive scale. That is certainly not the case in South West Tasmania. As I have said, those involved are dedicated to non-violent protest. I would simply see the producer or director of this program as being highly literate. By paradox, he has chosen this theme for the play on words and yet for the contrast in the activity portrayed. I think that if the position is seen on that basis-I honestly see it on that basis-Senator Walters has really got her protest somewhat out of proportion.

As for her condescending remarks about the young people in the South West, the fact is that most of them are young. But one should also recall-I think it is pertinent to her remark that the young would not remember the war-that one of those arrested yesterday was Mr Claude Alcorso. He is in his seventieth year and he is a well regarded industrialist. He was chairman of the Australian Opera at some stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sort of socialist I would like to be.

—He is the sort of socialist who fled with his brother from fascist Italy. He was forced out by Mussolini's policies before the war. He arrived in Australia and the thanks he got from the Australian community was internment in a mainland internment camp. Nevertheless, he came out without a chip on his shoulder and contributed to the growth and creation of Australian prosperity in the 1950s and the 1960s, as Senator Walters would well know. There is that type of person also in the South West protesting against this construction of the dam . I think that ought to be recorded. I simply wish to throw what I think is the correct perspective on the journalistic integrity and literacy of those responsible for the choice of this theme. I see it merely as a very clever subtle, ironic use of this musical theme to show, by paradox, the contrast between the destruction of life and property in war and yet the non-violent protest in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak in the adjournment debate but I will because of some remarks Senator Grimes has made. He made certain accusations against Senator Walters. He made similar types of accusations against me the other day, which were found to be totally incorrect.
—Rubbish! You had your name down hours ago.
—That statement also is incorrect.
—It is true.
—I did not have my name down.
—Of course you did.
—That is a total untruth.
—You are having everyone on, aren't you?
—That is a total untruth similar to the type of rubbish Senator Grimes is used to spewing around this chamber.
—Order! Senator Harradine, I ask you to ignore interjections.

—When Senator Grimes has had the experience in the Australian Labor Party that I have had he can talk. The damage he has done to the Labor Party over the years and the damage he is doing now will be seen only at the election box. I want to nail what Senator Grimes has said about innocent protesters. Whether or not the protester is innocent is not for this chamber to judge. It will be for the appropriate magistrates in Tasmania to judge whether they are innocent of breaking the law. It is not for anybody in this chamber to judge whether or not they are innocent. It appears by inference that Senator Grimes, and indeed one other honourable senator who addressed the people outside , were condoning the breaking of a law--
—Rubbish!

—Well, if that is rubbish I would like Senator Grimes to recommend that the blockade cease, because the blockade is a breach of the law of Tasmania. Let us understand that a democratic decision was taken on the dams issue, and that democratic decision was taken by the State Parliament. Some 51 out of 54 members, including the Australian Labor Party members, voted for the dam. Whether one agrees with that decision or not, it is a decision which has been properly taken, and it has been taken by those who had the responsibility to take it, who had the information upon which to base that decision, who had undertaken investigation and who had the ability to carry the decision through.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said previously, I do not deny that there is a basis for an individual to engage in civil disobedience, even in a democratic society. In my view the concept of civil disobedience can be sustained in a democratic society only if all other legal or reasonable avenues have been explored, and then only if one's formed conscience influences one to take action if one is confronted with a situation in which one must act or not act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the judge of that? You?
—If Senator Grimes would only listen to what I am saying-
—I am listening.
—It is about time you did because you obviously have not listened-
—Order! Senator Harradine, I suggest you address your remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, I used the impersonal pronoun 'one', and I used the definition of a formed conscience. If Senator Grimes does not know what those terms mean, he is unable to address himself to this very important question of protestors.
—It is important, but who is the judge of it? You?
—The judge in these matters is one who is confronted with doing an act or not.
—I agree with you.

—Well, the honourable senator should tell me whether the people in Tasmania who are engaging in the blockade are confronted with a situation which is similar to a person who has a conscientious objection to being conscripted into military service.
—Yes. I agree with you.

—He says yes. There is absolutely no comparison between the conscientious objection of one who is forced either to accept or reject conscription for national service and the situation in South West Tasmania. There is no comparison whatsoever because in the first case one is confronted with a situation in which one has to act or does not have to act in the personal sense with one's formed conscience. The other aspect of course, is a deliberate confrontation of the law. I wonder whether Senator Grimes, with his interjections, is now supporting the illegal activity that is taking place in South West Tasmania, contrary to the democratic decision that has been taken by the Tasmanian State Parliament. I was quite disturbed to see one honourable senator-I will not name him because he is not here-reported as saying that there are some totalitarian laws that need to be confronted, or words to that effect. Those sorts of statements should not fall from the lips of legislators in this chamber nor from the lips of legislators in any other chamber in the Commonwealth. I now turn to the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
—Please note that I am present and therefore you are not referring to me; is that so?

—No, I am not referring to the honourable senator. Since the ABC has been mentioned, I must refer to the fact that in the adjournment debate on 18 November 1982 the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, gave a response from the ABC to a question that I had raised previously in the chamber. In that statement Senator Chaney indicated that the ABC would be asked to comment on the 'very oddly worded Press release' from which a disc jockey on 2JJ had allegedly quoted. I complained about this on 11 November. On that occasion Senator Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a regular listener to the ABC, I am aware that the ABC appears to give some publicity to what might be termed community organisations. Clearly, in this case , the ABC has given publicity to a community organisation which arouses very strong feelings both for and against the community. I will be asking the Minister for Communications to ask the ABC to provide the Senate with that additional information which I think is relevant to any judgment on whether the disc jockey concerned was behaving in a reasonable manner or not.
I have not had any final response from the Minister in respect of that matter but I note that the ABC has been writing to persons who have made a similar complaint. I quote from their statement:

As the ABC has complete independence in matters of programming, the Minister for Communications has passed on to me for direct reply your letter of 17 November, in which you complained about remarks allegedly made by an announcer on station 2 Triple Jay.
The final paragraph, inter alia, states:

The announcer on duty at 2 Triple Jay simply read a community announcement, without comment and gave a telephone number. There is nothing unusual in this. Community announcements are aired many times each week by 2 Triple Jay.
It went on to state:
The ABC's program guidelines were upheld and no action is proposed to be taken about the alleged incident.

That statement sent by the ABC's Assistant General Manager to complainants pre- empts, I believe, the promised response from a Minister in this chamber. I simply make that point. I hope that very shortly I will receive some explanation of this extraordinary activity on behalf of the ABC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the spirit of the occasion and regretting that we have finished with perhaps less than the equanimity and good will which might be regarded as desirable for a finish to these sittings, might I help Senator Harradine and Senator Grimes in relation to the matter that has been raised by pointing out that it was the lawfully elected Government of the State of Tasmania which requested the Commonwealth Government to act. Some subsequent vote of that State Parliament may or may not have some legal consequence upon the legal situation which was created as a result of the lawfully elected Government of the State requesting the Commonwealth to apply for World Heritage listing for South West Tasmania. Whether the Tasmanian Government did cede its powers or not is something to which I am sure everybody with the spirit of Christmas will give some thought in trying to decide how we should approach this whole problem of a resolution of a matter which, if we are not careful, will divide not only the State but also our country in a way which a lot of us will regret and in a way which could even lead to bloodshed if we have demonstrators, violence, vituperation and abuse taking place in relation to the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: In wishing again that the Senate tonight may approach all of its problems with a spirit and a degree of co-operation and a wish to seek solutions, I say that, whilst it may be convenient to say that a democratic decision was taken whereby 51 out of 54 members of the new State Parliament said something, the lawful Government of the State at the appropriate stage said something else and asked the Commonwealth to act. The Commonwealth did act in consequence of that request . I do not think it has been given sufficient credit for the fact that it acted in good faith upon what was asked of it by the lawful Government of the State of Tasmania acting on behalf of the people of Tasmania.

Mr Deputy President, I wish the Senate well. I wish Senator Grimes and Senator Harradine well in being able to overcome any of the differences which might have existed. I hope that we find a solution to this problem with the spirit which has been exhibited at other times during the evening. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to say those few words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —When earlier tonight I mentioned that the Senate was about to create something of a record for the lateness of its sitting towards Christmas, I did not mean it to be taken as encouragement to improve on what I said. On the contrary, I remind everybody of Voltaire when he said words to the effect: 'We sometimes, in our country, execute an admiral to encourage the others'. Having tonight broken a record of seven speakers on the adjournment, we perhaps should seek to execute an admiral or two on the adjournment to encourage the others. I say that against the background of the few remarks that I wish to make.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilgariff, being a Whip, has been restrained in his opportunities to talk on his local matters. We all acknowledge his tremendous interest in the Northern Territory. He was born and bred a territorian and understands the Territory. His mention of the problems in terms of microwave communication is one that we fully understand. I will make sure that the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) is acquainted with that matter. Senator Crichton -Browne drew attention to the North West Shelf and whether a sufficiency of Australian material and workmanship was being put into it. He gave some very compelling figures. I do not think that I need to add to that. In fact, I think the North West Shelf partners have put out very effective statements on this matter.

I turn to the question that started to erupt when Senator Walters made her statement. First of all, Senator Grimes will not mind my saying that, as I understand what she said, she was not seeking to denigrate the protestors. I will say something about that subject in a moment. As I understood it, she was seeking to say that, in her judgment, it was unfortunate that the Australian Broadcasting Commission had chosen a particular theme. It is a matter for judgment-and everyone will so judge-whether the ABC's choice of themes was in good or bad taste and whether, as Senator Tate suggested, the theme was chosen in a satirical or ironical way or whether it was otherwise. We should all look to our dignity in that regard.

As to the question of protest, the Government and certainly all honourable senators both on our side and opposite will assert vigorously the right of individuals to protest. But that right must be understood. I make no reflection at all upon those in Tasmania or elsewhere who are protesting and doing so articulately. Indeed, it would be a sad day and would register the destruction of this parliamentary system if they were not allowed so to do. It is not good enough merely to say that the protest is non-violent. What that protest must also be is lawful and not obstructionist. It must not obstruct ordinary lawful processes. Within that framework, of course, a lawful protest must be protected. Lawful protest is just as entitled to the protection of the law as is the carrying out of lawful processes. I make that very clear. I make no reflection at all. I am delighted that in this rather materialistic world of ours that has looked towards affluence as a measure we are looking towards this limited sphere , we are looking towards the protection of the natural resources and beauty of this world.

TALK.START.PARA: —With acid rain, will we still have a world?

—Indeed, in my portfolio, acid rain is seen as the greatest threat to the world, as is of course the greenhouse threat of overheating. There are enormous threats to the world. I ask, in all amity, that we might all respect lawful protest and all respect the right of the other person to have a judgment different from others.
—If they break the laws they should pay the consequences.
—If they break the laws, of course they should accept the consequence of the law.
—As they do in Poland, for instance?
—Poland is a different situation. Let me resist the impish interjections of Senator Grimes. I am talking about the rule of law in a democracy, not the rule of law as abused in Poland.
—Or the rule of law in any other country.
—No. The rule of law has a special meaning inside our own country.
—As we did in Vietnam.
—Do not let us provoke each other. I do not ever object to interjections because they are the spirit of the rapier thrust, they are the spirit of the very duelling of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate, whose views I respect and acknowledge in this place, suggested that the film The Dambusters had an unfortunate characteristic, glorifying law. As one who has a vested interest in peace, let me simply say this: I did not see the film. I read the book. My instinct was that the story was a tribute to the eternal spirit of man in that ugly, uncivilised thing called war. I know of no person who has participated in the brutalising aspects of war who is not the most practical peacemaker on earth and the last person to glorify war. If indeed in such a spirit an adventure is attractive as such, that is an unfortunate by- product. But let me say this: While man exists, one should pay tribute to the eternal spirit of man-his courage, his audacity in these things but, of course, fighting all the time to have peace with dignity. Senator Harradine added to the debate on the dam but made a comment on a disc jockey issue on station 2JJJ. I know nothing of the incident, but I will refer it to the Minister for Communications.

Senator Rae added, I thought, some useful words to the debate. Let me make it clear, without any provocation at all, we depart from here for Christmas having faced some very big issues, one of them being the listing of the South West Tasmanian wilderness on the World Heritage List. It is a great tribute to all Australians, to honourable senators on both sides of the chamber, that we managed to list the South West Tasmanian wilderness on the World Heritage List, along with the Kakadu National Park and other areas. It is a great tribute that Australia is able to do that, that it has not laid the wildernesses to waste. The challenge to us all now is to find a way to carry out the steps that are necessary for the preservation of the environment. On that note, I commend to the Senate a happy Christmas and I commend to you, Mr Deputy President, the adjournment of the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Senate adjourned at 11.15 p.m. until Tuesday, 22 February 1983, at 1.45 p.m. or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed by the President, or in the event of the President being unavailable by the Deputy President, in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Industry and Commerce state what steps the Government has taken 'to review its decision in relation to wheelchairs with a view to replacing the tariff arrangements provided in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill with a bounty scheme for local producers'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: During the Government's deliberations on this issue, careful consideration was given to the need to strike a balance between reduction of costs for wheelchair users and the need to provide a level and form of assistance appropriate to the existence of a viable local industry.

It is widely accepted that there is a need to have an Australian wheelchair industry to supply both standard wheelchairs and wheelchairs tailored to meet specific disabilities as well as to provide an efficient maintenance and parts supply service.

The option of providing bounty assistance (instead of tariff assistance) to the local industry was closely examined. During the Government's deliberations on this matter it became apparent that this small industry did not have the necessary resources to meet the administrative requirements for obtaining bounty payments.

In its report on wheelchairs the Industries Assistance Commission described the industry as comprising about 15 local producers being largely jobbing shops concentrating on sales in their own States and whose employees often work only part of their time on wheelchairs.

After taking account of all factors, the Government reached the conclusion that the Australian wheelchair industry needed assistance to compete with imports and that bounty assistance was inappropriate as it could lead to the demise of this industry which provides such a valuable and needed service for the disabled in the community.

Accordingly, it was decided that assistance for this industry would continue to be provided by a tariff on imported wheelchairs. The general rate of duty is being reduced to a long term rate of 20 per cent.

In the circumstances the Government does not accept the necessity for a review of its decision and I note that an amendment to the Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1981 proposed by the Opposition on 2 June 1982 in the terms quoted by Senator Chipp was defeated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Primary Industry's attention been drawn to a report on page 176 of the Sun-Herald of 14 November 1982, that Japanese and Taiwanese fishermen are accused of using long-lines within the Australian territorial waters; if so, has this report been investigated and what has been the result of any investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry is aware of the article in question.

Under the bilateral fishing agreement with Japan, Japanese hand-line and long- line vessels are allowed access to the Australian fishing zone (AFZ) under strictly controlled conditions in order to catch tuna and other highly migratory species. Long-liners operate mainly in Australia's southern waters and target primarily for southern bluefin tuna. A number do, however, operate off the coast of Queensland on a seasonal basis to catch yellowfin, albacore and other tuna. Their catch also includes a component of about 10 per cent black marlin.

For most of the waters adjacent to Queensland access is restricted to areas further than 50 nautical miles from the coast, specifically in order to protect the interests of Australian fishermen operating in those waters. In particular, the area of restriction for Japanese long-liners extends seaward for about 110 nautical miles beyond the outer edge of the Great Barrier Reef between Townsville and the top of Cape York Peninsulal, an area of some 80,000 square miles. Japanese fishing activity as far as it exists in the area from 50 to 100 nautical miles off the coast of Cairns is restricted to hand-lining only.

No Taiwanese long-liners have been licensed to operate in the Australian fishing zone. Under the agreement with Taiwanese commercial interests, gillnetters and pair trawlers are granted access to the north west section of the zone primarily off the north coast of Western Australia, the Northern Territory and a small area of north western Queesnland. In the Taiwanese case access is only available outside the 12 nautical mile limit off the Australian coast.

All foreign fishing vessels (FFV) licensed to fish in the zone are required to report their positions and details of their catch by radio to Australian authorities at specified times. Such information is checked against reports sent to the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre (ACSC) on FFV activity from both primary and secondary aerial surface surveillance resources. All reports of possible illegal activity are followed up. However there have been no reports of breaches by licensed vessels in waters off Queensland since the introduction of the AFZ.
In the case of fishermen taking black marlin in the Cairns area, I understand that the 1982 season to date has proved to be more successful than the preceding two seasons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 16 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: On what basis did the Theatre Board of the Australia Council reach its decision to reduce the grant to the New Moon Theatre Company of Townsville, Queensland from $87,000 to $65,000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council has advised me as follows:

Theatre Board assistance to the New Moon Theatre Company is made available under the Board's Professional Regional Theatre grant scheme. Board assistance under this scheme is matched on a ratio basis with funds available from State government and local sources. The New Moon Theatre Company, which in 1983 will be in its second year of operation, was eligible for assistance from the Theatre Board of up to 40 per cent of all other subsidy.

In its initial submission to the Theatre Board, the company indicated that prospective support for its activities in 1983 would be available from a number of local government authorities as guarantees against box office and rental subsidy. The Theatre Board does not regard guarantees against box office rental subsidy as assistance available on a matching basis from local sources as required by its guidelines. These amounts were not taken into account when the Board approved the initial grant of $64,600 at its meeting on 20-24 September 1982.

The grant was announced in the Theatre Board's Press release of 30 September, which contained details of grants approved at the September meeting. On 7 October 1982, the secretary of the company wrote to the Board seeking a reconsideration of the company's application for a general grant of $98,000. That letter advised the Board of progress made towards the conversion of all guarantees against box office to direct grants from the local government authorities concerned. The total amount of direct grants which became available in this way was $58,440. In the light of this additional assistance, the Board reconsidered its grant to the new Moon Theatre and, on 23 November 1982, an offer of a grant of up to $98,000 was made to the Company.
Grants approved by the Theatre Board towards the activities of the New Moon Theatre Company during 1983 are as follows:
$ Towards regional theatre activities 1983 98,000 Towards interstate movement of artists (3 grants) 5,061

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 December 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Acting Attorney-General seen the annual report of the Director of Consumer Affairs in Victoria, Mr John Miller, calling for a 'crack-down on companies with a paid-up capital of only $2.00'.
(2) Did Mr Miller state that the present system, which allows people to 'enjoy the luxury of limited liability behind a $2 corporate veil is open to abuse'.

(3) Did Mr Miller also state that linking a $2 company with a discretionary trust is 'a further complication . . . such that the consumer, in effect, has no idea with whom one is dealing, nor is it feasible to so discover easily'.
(4) Have the above problems been brought to the Federal Government's attention.
(5) What action has the Federal Government taken to rectify these problems.
(6) Does legislation in the United Kingdom provide for a compulsory minimum paid up capital for companies which trade with the public, and what is the amount.
(7) Do any similar provisions exist in other countries.
(8) What action will the Government take to rectify this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen Press reports about the annual report of the Director of Consumer Affairs in Victoria and am aware of his comments about a minimum paid up capital requirement for companies. The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, at a meeting held in Sydney on 12 February 1982, considered a proposal that the Companies Act 1981 should require all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid-up capital. At that meeting the Ministerial Council agreed that this proposal should be considered in the context of the proposed Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1984. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September 1982 (Hansard, page 863) Senator Hamer asked me , as the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, concerns the automatic declassification of obsolete national security material, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the state of progress in this matter, bearing in mind previous assurance by the Attorney-General that the matter was being looked at? Will he also report whether national security classifications have been restricted to national security documents? Can he assure the Senate that there has been a diminution in the overclassification of government material and that national security classifications on Cabinet documents, for instance, are applied only in strict accordance with the security handbook?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following further information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The question of what procedures should govern declassification of national security documents has caused some difficulty both in the United States and Australia. A Presidential Order issued by President Carter provided for automatic declassification after certain fixed periods and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in its report on the Freedom of Information Bill, referred to this Order in recommending the institution in Australia of a system for automatic declassification of national security documents.

However, presumably because of administrative difficulties in the United States under the original Order, this was superseded by a new order in May 1982 which does not provide for automatic declassification.

The question of what procedures should apply in Australia to govern declassification of national security information is under active consideration and I am awaiting a report from an interdepartmental committee dealing with this subject.

The Government is concerned to ensure that national security classifications are applied only when necessary and appropriate. Thus, in September 1980 the Prime Minister wrote to all Ministers in connexion with the issue of instructions that emphasized:
the dangers of over classification;
the need to have classifications confirmed by a suitably senior officer and for that fact to be recorded on the file copy of the original document;
that parts of a document may be classified separately;
that where information in a document can be reclassified after a certain date or event that should be indicated in the text or in a sideline, and;
the need for a departmental review programme to reassess holdings of classified material.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1609) Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether the Government would give immediate attention to expanding the terms of reference of the inquiry by Mr J. W. von Doussa, Q. C., into the affairs of Mr Denis Horgan so as to require Mr von Doussa to determine whether, as a result of the transactions inquired into by him, money which otherwise would have been paid in tax was not paid and whether the vendor shareholders would be affected by the recoupment legislation promised by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Arrangements for the inquiry by Mr von Doussa including the matters to be inquired into were agreed by the Government and Mr Horgan. The inquiry was arranged having regard to questions which had been raised as to whether it was appropriate that Mr Horgan continue to hold certain public offices. The announced terms of reference of the inquiry are sufficient for that purpose and it is considered that extension of them as proposed by the honourable senator would not be appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2709) Senator Walsh asked the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General the following question without notice relating to the appointment of Mr J. W. von Doussa on 11 October to inquire into the financial affairs of Mr Denis Horgan:

ANSWER.PARA: What power to subpoena documents does Mr von Doussa have for the purpose of this inquiry? What protection from defamation action does Mr von Doussa, his inquiry and, ultimately, his report have? Will the Acting Attorney-General table the letter written to Mr von Doussa setting out his terms of appointment? Will he give an undertaking to table the report as soon as it is completed?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the third and fourth parts of this question (answers to the first and second parts having been provided on 30 November):

Arrangements for an inquiry to be conducted were agreed by the Treasurer and Mr Horgan on 23 September 1982. A Press release about the matter was issued by the Treasurer on that day. The press release mentioned, inter alia, that-
(a) the inquiry would be undertaken by a leading counsel nominated independently by the President of the Law Council of Australia;
(b) the inquiry would proceed as soon as possible and a report would be made to the Treasurer who would report to the Government.
The President of the Law Council of Australia nominated Mr J. W. von Doussa, Q .C., to conduct the inquiry.

The terms of reference were made public by a press statement of the Acting Attorney-General issued on 11 October 1982. The press statement also stated that the solicitor for the inquiry would be Mr David Wicks.

The Acting Attorney-General did not himself forward a letter to Mr von Doussa setting out the terms of his appointment. However, on 12 October 1982 a Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, Mr H. T. Bennett, forwarded to Mr Wicks copies of the Acting Attorney-General's press statement. A letter which accompanied those copies included the following paragraph:

'Ministers have agreed that the Attorney-General will assume general responsibility for this inquiry but this will be on the basis as originally agreed with Mr Horgan that the report will be submitted to the Treasurer.'
Mr von Doussa's report will be tabled when completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2715) Senator Jessop asked me, as the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, a question without notice relating to financial support for community legal services, particularly services in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
The Acting Attorney-General has had a reported statement on 23 November 1982 concerning support for Adelaide's community legal services drawn to his attention.

The Acting Attorney-General does recognise the valuable and efficient work that is carried out by such services throughout Australia. The Commonwealth Government has established a continuing program of grants to these centres which has grown from $175,000 in 1979-80 to $500,000 for the calendar year 1983 . Calendar year funding has been arranged to meet the request of centres regarding the provision of funds. There are four community legal aid centres in South Australia that have received a grant from the Commonwealth. Their share has risen from $21,500 in 1979-80 to $47,000 in 1983.

The Commonwealth has made arrangements with state legal aid and legal services commissions, whereby the commissions make recommendations to the Commonwealth as to which services should receive a grant and the extent of that grant. The Commonwealth has not yet received recommendations from the Legal Services Commission of South Australia about grants for services in South Australia for 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Repatriation Commission advised the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that repatriation benefits payable as a result of the High Court decision in the Nancy Law case will rise to an annual cost of approximately $1 billion within the next few years; if so, is the Minister able to provide further details of estimated cost, the years for which those estimates have been made, and the reasons for those estimates; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I have not been provided with the advice mentioned in the question. It is unlikely that expenditure on disability and war widows' pensions and on related benefits will reach $1 billion in total annually for a considerable time.

It has not been possible to identify accurately the decisions of repatriation determining authorities which would not have been favourable but for the High Court decision in the Nancy Law case. The identifiable effects of that decision on the numbers of claims, applications for increase in pension and appeals lodged and approved remain unclear since other factors, including economic circumstances, the ageing of the veteran population and other decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court are also having an impact on the repatriation system. Consequently, an accurate estimate of the kind sought is not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is meant by 'representative quotations' (see answer to Question on Notice No. 1922).
(2) What are the relevant provisions of Finance Regulation 51 mentioned in the answer to Question on Notice No. 1922.
(3) What reasons were given to the lowest tenderer for not accepting that tender.
(4) Who evaluates the work of the security firm.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.
