(2) The relevant Finance Regulation 51 provisions in respect of the contracts mentioned in the answer are:
51 (1)-At least three representative quotations for the supplies shall be obtained unless tenders are publicly invited, where-
the estimated cost of any supplies exceeds $200;
there is no existing contract between the Commonwealth and a supplier; and
the supplies are not obtained under a contract between a State Government and a supplier.

Expenditure Prices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is any customs duty payable on machine readable books containing computer programs, or on programs 'imported' electronically over data or telephone links.
(2) Are cassette tapes containing computer programs dutiable at a rate of 2 per cent.
(3) Are 'floppy' discs containing computer programs dutiable at a rate of 35 per cent.
(4) Is software imported as a part of a total computer package dutiable at the rate of the total package, that is, 6 per cent.
(5) Does the Department have any plans to alter this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Customs duty is payable on recorded information at the rate applicable to the storage medium. If computer programs are recorded in books in machine readable form, that is, using character fonts that allow recognition by an optical scanner the duty will be calculated on the value of the document at the rate for the book-currently free. If the program is recorded on a floppy disc the duty would be calculated on the value of the document at the rate for floppy discs-currently 35 per cent. There is no duty payable on programs 'imported' electronically.
(2) Cassette tapes whether or not containing program material are classified within Tariff item 92.12.190 and dutiable at 35 per cent.
(3) Yes.
(4) Software imported as part of a total computer package is dutiable at the rate applicable to the package.

(5) On 11 November 1982 the Minister for Administrative Services forwarded a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission on Computer Office Equipment and Recording Media Industries. This reference covers all kinds of computers, computer media-tapes, discs, discettes and cassettes.
The Government will review the protection accorded to the production of these goods in Australia in the light of the Industry Assistance Commission's report and recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 October 1982:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What initiatives have been taken by the Repatriation Commission to identify bottlenecks and streamline the processing of claims in the various State branches.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Repatriation Commission has taken a wide range of action to improve the determining system and processes including the establishment of a Committee to co-ordinate action by the Department of Veterans' Affairs in identifying bottlenecks and streamlining the processing of claims and appeals.
(2) The Commission has been conducting continuous reviews to improve the situation and the following are among the results so far:
To speed up the determining process, the number of determining authorities has been increased.
There has been increased use of non-departmental medical officers in medical examinations and interstate departmental medical officers have been used to assist hard-pressed States.
Determining authorities have been ecouraged to reduce the length and complexity of reasons for decisions, especially where decisions are favourable.

In relation to the Repatriation Review Tribunal, the Repatriation Act has been amended to provide the Tribunal with a discretion whether or not to refer back to the Repatriation Commission cases where additional evidence is presented. The previous mandatory referral had been a source of serious delays in the past.
The design of a new computer-based processing system is proceeding and this will help to give more detailed and timely information about the processing of claims.

A re-organisation of the top structure of the Department of Veterans' Affairs has been approved and is in the process of being implemented. As part of this re -organisation, it is proposed to locate in Canberra all Commission delegates who handle appeals against decisions of Repatriation Boards. This should allow for earlier identification of potential bottlenecks and should enhance the consistency and speed of decision making at this level.
A 'fast lane' priority for processing claims and appeals has been introduced for those cases which are considered to warrant special consideration on humanitarian grounds.

The Repatriation Review Tribunal, for its part, has decided not to proceed to list an application for hearing until the applicant or his representative has informed the Tribunal that the application is ready to proceed. This is designed to reduce delays caused by unnecessary adjournments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 23 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the usual time delay for applications to be determined by the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board.
(2) What is the backlog of applications from 1981.
(3) What is the anticipated backlog of applications at the end of the 1982-83 financial year.
(4) Have staffing levels of the Board been affected in any way during the recent Federal Government cutbacks; if so, what has been the effect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Applications for commencement grants must be lodged by 30 September each year. Over 1,000 applications are normally received and are processed in order of receipt. In recent years most of these have been settled by the end of the financial year but some 20 per cent have not been settled till the following year. An additional $3m is being provided for expenditure this year to meet the increased number and level of claims and to avoid a major increase in claims carried over.

Applications for project grants may be received at any time during the year and between 20 and 40 are received each month. On average it takes 6 months to finalise a project agreement including 4 months investigation and consideration by the Board and 2 months to agree a form of contract with a company. Hence there are always some applications under consideration at the end of the year. Claims for payment under project contracts are normally settled within 3 months.

(4) No. Nevertheless an additional 7 staff have been temporarily transferred from other areas of the Department to reduce the delays in processing claims. In addition my Department is reviewing the adequacy of the present staff numbers devoted to the task.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 23 November 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is Air Queensland still a general sales agent for Qantas in respect of passenger sales in the north Queensland area; if so
(a) does Qantas make any on-the-spot inspections to see whether Air Queensland is carrying out its obligations as a general sales agent; if so, how often;
(b) how many full-time representatives does Air Queensland employ to fulfil its obligations as a general sales agent for Qantas;
(c) what new services have been introduced by Qantas out of Townsville in recent years and what was the date of introduction; and

(d) to what extent did the increases in revenue mentioned in the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1918 arise because of the services mentioned in (c ) above. (See Hansard, 24 April 1982, page 1431).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Qantas has advised that Air Queensland is still its general sales agent for passenger sales in the north Queensland area and that in relation to the particular questions:

(a) Qantas staff make regular visits and inspections both to support Air Queensland as a general sales agent and to ensure that Qantas' interests are being observed. During 1982 eight separate visits were made by six different staff covering all aspects of passenger sales and management control. In addition, three visits were made by the Qantas Agency Co-ordinator for the purpose of automated equipment development and one visit by a Qantas Training Officer to conduct training of Air Queensland staff;

(b) Air Queensland employs one member of its staff on full-time duties to co- ordinate all of Qantas' interests. In addition, Air Queensland employs eight sales representatives whose duties include sales activities on behalf of Qantas;

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2032) Senator Lewis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which relates to Federal and State financial arrangements, is directed to either the Leader of Government in the Senate or the Minister reresenting the Minister for Defence. I am not sure which Minister is reponsible. The question deals with project Aquarius. Is it a fact that the Victorian Government has withdrawn its support from Project Aquarius, a joint venture in which the Royal Australian Air Force would have been conducting continual aerial fire fighting tests this summer by dropping fire retardant chemicals from C130 aircraft? Would not this fire fighting assistance have been ideal for the control of the disastrous Heyfield fires last weekend? Will the Federal Government give consideration to fitting out a C130 aircraft, without regard to the actions of the Victorian Government, in view of the tinderbox conditions in much of southern and eastern Victoria?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Project Aquarius is a controlled scientific experiment that CSIRO is conducting into the effectiveness of aerial techniques for the suppression of bushfires as compared with conventional fire fighting methods. The CSIRO has advised that the first phase of Project Aquarius took place in the Australian Capital Territory last summer. It involved the calibration of infra-red fire mapping equipment mounted in CSIRO's F27 aircraft. The second phase concerned with the behaviour of high intensity fires will be conducted in Western Australia this summer. The third phase, involving tests of the effectiveness of air tankers dropping water and fire retardants on lit fires, is planned to take place in Victoria in the summer of 1983-84.

The joint project to which the honourable senator refers was a co-operative fire fighting evaluation operation undertaken last summer by the Victorian Government with assistance from the Commonwealth on the basis of operations for one fire season only.

This assistance took the form of providing RAAF aircrew and a C130 aircraft which was used to drop fire retardant chemicals on actual bushfires in Victoria as they occurred. While CSIRO gained experience from these Victorian trials in an observer capacity, their participation was independent of Project Aquarius.

After the evaluation last summer, the Victorian Government commenced negotiations with a private contractor for the provision of a C130 aircraft to continue operations in the 1982-83 fire season. I understand that difficulties have recently arisen in relation to those proposed arrangements and the possibility of the Commonwealth providing assistance to the Victorian Government again this summer is currently being discussed by the two governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2105) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, a question without notice requesting that consideration be given to the attachment of small warning lights to the sides of Australian National Railways locomotives operating in Tasmania as a safety measure to help prevent level crossing accidents after dark.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC), comprised of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for transport matters, has from time to time evaluated studies on the improvement of safety of level crossings. Studies have shown that the installation of warning devices and other improvements at level crossings is more effective in accident prevention than illumination or other means of making the train more visible. In all States procedures exist to evaluate proposals for the improvement or elimination of level crossings and to implement the resulting recommendations. Ministers at the 58th ATAC meeting of 4 July 1980 agreed that these existing procedures were adequate. Nevertheless, Railway Commissioners have a proposal under consideration to attach suitable reflectors to railway rollingstock on an Australia-wide basis.
In December 1980, Australian National announced a new corporate identity program involving the painting of all rollingstock.

The new livery is predominantly green with vertical yellow bands and black contrasts. These colours were selected for their brilliance, and together with the contrast caused by using a vertical band, will have the effect of making vehicles more visible. In addition the bogies of wagons will be painted yellow, and as they are approximately at headlight level, the visibility of trains at level crossings will be improved.
A painting program has commenced, but will take several years to complete since painting is subject to the release of wagons and availability of staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2320) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that legal and technical strategies are being employed to frustrate the purpose and intent of the anti-dumping applications? Further, will the Government consider excluding dumping decisions from judicial review to show the Government's good faith of its intention to have effective, fast track anti-dumping in a climate of world recession?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Exporters of goods to Australia have been able to use the law to prevent the Customs authorities from taking provisional anti-dumping and countervailing securities. The action taken by those exporters operates to the detriment of Australian industry and the Government has therefore decided to legislate as soon as possible to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act and the Customs Act to minimise the opportunities to circumvent the Government's intentions as expressed in the first named Act.

Regulations were recently introduced under the Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act which are designed to remove from the scope of that Act decisions to take cash or other securities under the Customs Act as provisional anti-dumping and countervailing measures.

The amendments will include a provision to exempt provisional decisions on securities from the scope of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act . This provision will supersede the Regulations introduced on 24 November 1982.

Furthermore Section 14 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act will be repealed. This provision imposes an obligation on the Minister not to take action which is inconsistent with the obligations of Australia under international agreements relating to trade.

Removal of this provision will in no way lessen Australia's adherence to its international agreements. It is unnecessary, however, to have such a provision in Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing law. Issues concerning Australia 's obligations under international agreements are more appropriately considered within the context of the dispute settlement provisions of the particular agreements rather than in the Australian Courts.
An amendment to the Customs Act will be made to place beyond doubt that securities may be validly taken under section 42 of that Act for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2716) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning quarantine inspection procedures.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

Imported cargo is sent for fumigation only when quarantine inspection has revealed the presence of live insects. When live insects are found, the Quarantine Inspector acts to ensure that insects do not escape. Depending on the situation, this action may take several lines but would normally consist of stopping unloading and using a spray treatment to immobilise the insects until fumigation is undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1982, Senator Reid (Hansard page 3048) asked Senator Messner a question without notice as to whether reductions in New South Wales electricity charges were to flow on to Australian Capital Territory consumers and whether or not legislation and agreements covering the Snowy Mountains Scheme were appropriate to today's circumstances in the Australian Capital Territory. In addition to information provided by Senator Messner, I provide the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: The yearly allocation of Snowy Mountains Scheme electricity to the Australian Capital Territory is the subject of a contractual agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria entered into under the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 and supporting State legislation.

The question of renegotiating this arrangement has been raised on a number of occasions in the past. Any change to the Territory's allocation of electricity would require the agreement of the two States.

The Scheme is a vital component of peak load electricity supplies to the two States, as we have seen in recent years, and indications are that the States are not attracted to any change in their respective shares of electricity from the Scheme.

The agreement is consistent with the original purpose of the Scheme, namely to provide electricity to the Australian Capital Territory as well as peak load electricity to New South Wales and Victoria. As a result of its entitlement to electricity from the Scheme, the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority is able to supply electricity that is generally cheaper than in New South Wales and Victoria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 15 December 1982 (Hansard, page 3505) Senator Bolkus asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Australian delegate to the United Nations General Assembly vote yesterday against two resolutions calling for a freeze on the production of nuclear weapons? If so, can the Minister either explain or justify the Australian Government's attitude to both of those questions?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Delegation to the General Assembly voted against the two draft resolutions, as did most other Western countries.

Western states opposed the resolutions because a nuclear freeze at current levels would perpetuate an unequal military balance, given the greater momentum of the Soviet weapons program. In the Government's view, freeze proposals which merely confirm existing nuclear and conventional superiority undermine the confidence needed for real arms control and do not provide any increase in security which is an essential basis for any realistic disarmament proposal.

Australia strongly supports the negotiations on strategic arms reductions between the United States and the Soviet Union which began in Geneva in June this year. We see these negotiations as offering the most realistic approach to achieving a stable nuclear balance at the lowest possible level.
